questions.text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks gestation, presents to the outpatient department with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. A wet smear with 10% KOH solution shows the following picture and the vaginal pH is found to be <4.5. What will be the best management in this scenario?

choices.text: Metronidazole 200 mg oral TDS for 7 days

questions.solution:
The patient has candidal vaginitis. The best management in a pregnant woman is topical azoles like clotrimazole or miconazole, applied intravaginally for 7 days.

Although the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis involves oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose or topical azole therapy for 7 days in a non-pregnant woman, only topical azoles are recommended during pregnancy. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include

  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Diabe­tes Mellitus
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Obesity

The clinical symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching with vaginal pH <4.5. The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Candidal vaginitis

pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5

questions.text:
With respect to the Lineweaver- Burk plot shown for a given enzyme and inhibitor, which of the following happens on increasing inhibitor concentration?

where, V is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

choices.text: Decrease in binding affinity of substrate to enzyme
Decrease in the Km value of the enzyme
Decrease in the slope of red line
Decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second

questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents a reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. Increasing inhibitor concentration will lead to a decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second.

In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds the enzyme other than the active site. It causes a change in the activity of enzymes, as a result of which reaction is not catalyzed. The total number of products hence formed are lesser. It however does not affect the affinity (represented by Km value) of the enzyme to bind the substrate.

This can be plotted on a graph. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors where v0 is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

On increasing the inhibitor concentration, the slope of the red line (1/V vs 1/S) increases, or in other words Vmax decreases.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A 54-year-old man died within few days after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumor cells invaded the renal vein and extended as a solid column up to the inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma, is most likely possible?
questions.solution:
The presence of yellow-colored spherical mass associated with tumor cells invading the renal vein is characteristic of clear cell carcinoma. Histopathology shows tumor cells with clear cytoplasm.

Clear-cell carcinoma is the most common type, accounting for 70 to 80% of renal cell cancers. They most likely arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions.

The tumor cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern. The lesion appears usually as a solitary, bright yellow-gray-white spherical masses of variable size. The yellow color is due to the prominent lipid accumulations in tumor cells.

Clear-cell RCC has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein, where, the tumor may grow as a solid column of cells that can extend up the inferior vena cava, sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.

Image: Microscopy of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness for the last 6 days. On examination, Kernig’s and Brudzinski's signs are positive. A petechial rash typical of meningococcus is seen. You perform a lumbar puncture bedside and collect the CSF sample. However, the courier on duty is not there to drop the sample at the bacteriology lab. What should you not do?

choices.text: Keep the CSF sample in refrigerator
Incubate at room temperature in a container in a candle jar
Incubate the sample in Trans-isolate medium

questions.solution:
Fever, photophobia, neck stiffness with positive Kernigs and Brudzinski sign associated with a maculopapular rash of meningococcus are suggestive of Acute bacterial meningitis. In such a case, the CSF sample should not be frozen or refrigerated.

The CSF sample should be plated immediately for culture or within one hour. If a delay is expected, a TI(TransIsolate) biphasic transport medium should be used. If TI medium is not available, the sample should be incubated at room temperature with 5% CO2 in an incubator with screw cap loosened or in a candle jar . CSF should not be exposed to extremes of temperature or sunlight.

However in case of a suspected viral etiology, the CSF sample should be transported on ice.

Related Pearl: Acute bacterial meningitis - causes and empirical treatment

questions.text: A 42-year-old  woman presented with menorrhagia, dyspareunia and progressively increasing, congestive dysmenorrhea . On palpation, the uterus was symmetrically enlarged and around 12 weeks size. Which of the following would you not consider in the management of this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical history is suggestive of adenomyosis and Laparoscopic ovarian drilling has no role in the management of adenomyosis. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is primarily recommended in the surgical management of PCOD (Polycystic ovarian disease).

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

Etiology: Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (SERM)

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous women >40 years
  • Most common symptom - Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Per-Vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy
  • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign - Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical. The uterus is symmetrically enlarged and rarely exceeds 14 weeks in size.
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • TVS or MRI ( MRI is superior to USG in showing hypo or anechoic areas in the uterine wall)

Management:

  • A diagnostic hysteroscopy combined with curettage is the initial step in the management of adenomyosis (because of menorrhagia).
  • Total Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD, Mirena is tried in younger women



The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of hemorrhage. The H&E stained specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis. Uterine size rarely exceeds 14 weeks in adenomyosis.

 

 

 

Note:

Uterine Artery Embolization/Uterine Fibroid Embolization (UAE/UFE) is a promising non-surgical alternative treatment option for patients with menorrhagia and adenomyosis. It is an angiographic interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol microspheres or other synthetic particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. Because vessels serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, these microspheres are preferentially directed to the tumors, sparing the surrounding myometrium. UAE helped in decreasing the uterine size and junctional zone thickness in cases of adenomyosis.

questions.text: Which of the following maneuvers given below is not used to deliver the baby with the presentation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The presentation depicted in the image is a complete breech, and McRoberts maneuver is not used in breech delivery, but is used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Lovset's maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation. Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head. Burns-Marshall method is also used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Frank breech: Breech with flexion at hip joints, extension at knee joints.
  • Complete breech: Breech with flexion at both hip joints, one or both knees at flexed.
  • Incomplete breech: Breech with extension at one or both hips, as a result, one or both feet or knees lie below the breech. Footling is a type of incomplete breech with one or both feet below the breech.

The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Modified Prague’s maneuver is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

The image depicts the McRoberts maneuver used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

McRoberts maneuver consists of forceful abduction and flexion of maternal hips and positioning the maternal thighs on to the abdomen. Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.

It is used to free the impacted anterior shoulder through the following:

  • Straightening of the sacrum relative to lumbar vertebrae.
  • Rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head.
  • A decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after her parents noticed red blood in her stools. Physical examination showed the below finding. Small bowel radiography and histopathology showed multiple, small- to medium-sized hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of red blood in stools, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and hamartomatous small to medium-sized polyps are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception.
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Below is the histologic image of the arborizing pattern seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile polyps are the focal malformations of the epithelium or the lamina propria. They occur in children less than 5 years of age. Microscopy of the polyp reveals dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. 

Option B: Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors like medulloblastomas and glioblastomas.

Option D: Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with the cecum and colon carcinomas. It is a DNA mismatch repair defect. They are also at an increased risk of developing cancers of the endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A 40-year-old multipara was undergoing vaginal delivery. She started to bleed profusely after the expulsion of the placenta. The obstetrician asks you to pass the drugs to manage her immediately. You would pass any of the following drugs to the obstetrician except ______
questions.solution:
Carboprost is not recommended by the WHO in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage as it does not prove beneficial when compared with other uterotonics.

This agent was also associated with a higher incidence of adverse effects such as vomiting and diarrhea.

To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:

  • Oxytocin - (10 IU - IM/IV)
  • Carbetocin - (100 μg - IM/IV)
  • Misoprostol - (400 μg or 600 μg, per-oral)
  • Ergometrine/methylergometrine - (200 μg - IM/IV)
  • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination - (5 IU,500μg - IM)

Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum haemorrhage. When oxytocin is not available, the other drugs mentioned above can be used based on the clinical condition and availability of the drug.

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete due to its unreliability as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or blood in collection devices may be mixed with the amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery)

WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, the latest addition to the treatment of PPH

  • Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for the treatment of PPH.

Note: Carboprost can be used in the treatment of PPH , but not in the prevention of PPH
Since this patient does not satisfy the criteria for PPH diagnosis, the question is asking about the prevention of PPH.

Predisposing factors for PPH :

Atonic PPH Traumatic PPH Coagulopathy
Parity: Primi/Grand multipara Instrumental deliveries Sepsis
Previous PPH Episiotomy IUD
Overdistented uterus: multifetal gestation, hydramnios, macrosomia Precipitate labour HELLP syndrome
Precipitate labour, prolonged labour Macrosomia  

Uterine malformations, fibroid uterus

    
Labour induction with prostaglandins or oxytocin    

Placental anomalies:Placenta previa/accreta/increta/percreta/abruptio placenta

questions.text: A physiologist wants to measure the energy required for various physical activities. Which of the following parameters should he use?
questions.solution:
Physical activity ratio (PAR) measures the energy expenditure for different kinds of physical activities.

It is measured as multiples of BMR. It is also called as Metabolic equivalent of task (MET). Sedentary activities use 1.1-1.2 X BMR, whilst vigorous activities like climbing uphill may cost 6-8 X BMR.

Physical activity level classifies the person based on his daily activities into sedentary or different grades of activity. The overall physical activity level (PAL) is the sum of the PAR of different activities, multiplied by the time taken for that activity, divided by 24 hours.

Basal metabolic rate is the energy required by a body at rest (but not sleeping) after 12 hours of the last meal.

Respiratory quotient measures the carbon dioxide produced per unit of oxygen consumed for a given metabolic substrate (carbohydrate, lipid, protein).

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate

BMR is increased in

BMR is decreased in

Fever

Protein energy malnutrition

Hyperthyroidism

Hypothyroidism

Cold environment

Addison disease

Cachexia

 

Starvation

Cushing’s syndrome

questions.text: A 31-year-old  G3P2 female presents with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is positive and beta HCG levels are >1 lac mIU/ML. The uterus size is larger than expected for her LMP. Her ultrasound finding is shown below. Which of the following can be most likely seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, beta HCG levels >1 lac mIU/ml, the uterus size and the ultrasound finding of snow storm appearance suggest a diagnosis of a complete mole. Theca lutein cysts are present in half of the women with complete mole. They occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high levels of HCG in molar pregnancies.  

Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2 to 4 months following evacuation of a molar pregnancy. Sometimes,  it can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of such cyst has to be done.  

Other effects due to increased levels of HCG:

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Hyperthyroidism

The preferred treatment would be molar evacuation by suction and curettage.

Preoperative cervical dilatation with an osmotic agent is recommended if the cervix is minimally dilated. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied. With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support is imperative.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN
  • Note: Anti D immunoglobulin to be given to Rh negative women. Dose is 50 micrograms in first trimester and 300 micrograms when gestational age is more than 12 weeks.

On transvaginal ultrasonography, Theca lutein cysts seen in the left ovary:

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the hospital with multiple pruritic, small papules on the extensor surface along with lesions as shown in the below image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

choices.text: Tense Blisters and vesicles can be seen.
Granular deposition of IgA at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.
Target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2
Perioral and perianal lesions are frequently seen in young children.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with an image showing a string of pearl appearance, are suggestive of Chronic Bullous Disorder of Childhood or Linear IgA Disease. The diagnostic hallmark is the linear deposition of IgA deposits at DEJ identified by direct immunofluorescence.

Chronic Bullous Disorder of Childhood (CBDC), is an immunobullous disease of childhood, which clinically present as an annular arrangement of vesicles.

  • Tense Blisters, vesicles, and annular erythema are the characteristic triad of clinical features.
  • The blisters are arranged in a circular fashion, hence called crown of jewels, the cluster of jewels, or string of pearls appearance.
  • In young children, the distribution of lesions is perioral, perianal, and in the perineum.
  • Target antigen is BP180 or BPAg2 >> BP230 or BPAg1.

Patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescence in Vesiculobullous disorders are

  1. Linear Pattern (shore-line fluorescence pattern)
  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

2. Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with headaches, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI findings are shown in the image below. Considering the sign seen in the image, what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache, seizures, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI showing a dural tail sign are suggestive of meningioma.

The dural tail sign refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumour, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases). However, it may also be seen in the following non-meningiomatous lesions such as schwannoma, sarcoidosis, primary CNS lymphoma, metastasis, and chloroma.

The image given below shows axial (A) and sagittal (B) contrast-enhanced MRI images of the brain. The arrows point towards the thickening and enhancements of the dura, tapering away from the mass and resembling a tail (dural tail sign).

Radiological features of meningioma:

  • Angiography may reveal a spoke wheel appearance, or a dense, homogeneous, and persistent blush representing meningeal blood supply to the tumor.
  • CT usually reveals a hyperdense extra-axial mass with or without calcification.
  • MRI may show capping cysts, vasogenic edema, and a dural tail sign.
  • PET shows high uptake of 68Ga-DOTATOC, a somatostatin receptor-targeted ligand.

Other options:

Option A: Extradural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the skull and dura mater. It appears as a lenticular, biconvex lesion in acute cases or as a crescentic-shaped lesion in chronic cases.

Option B: Subdural hematoma refers to the collection of blood between the dura and arachnoid mater. It appears as a crescentic concave in acute cases or an elliptical lesion in chronic cases.

Option C: Craniopharyngioma is a benign suprasellar tumor arising from squamous epithelial remnants of Rathke’s pouch. It is commonly located in the hypothalamic region. On MRI, it usually appears as a cystic lesion. It may also present as a mixed cystic or solid lesion. The solid components show intense contrast enhancement.

questions.text: You notice the presence of the following type of lesions over the arms and around the chin in a newborn baby at birth. Microscopic examination of theses lesions will reveal:
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over arms in a newborn baby at birth is suggestive of transient Pustular Melanosis. Microscopic examination of these lesions will reveal Neutrophils.

Transient Pustular Melanosis:

  • These are benign lesion seen predominantly in black neonates.
  • They contain neutrophils and is present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles; it lasts for 2-3 days.
  • No therapy is required

Other Normal findings in a newborn:

  • Erythema toxicum: small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Mongolian spots: Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back.
  • Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.
  • Hymenal tags
  • Physiological phimosis

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of dementia but not pseudodementia, except:

choices.text: Slow progression of symptoms throughout course
Recent memory loss is more severe than remote memory loss

questions.solution:
Patients with pseudodementia (not dementia) present with severe depression. All other options are clinical features of dementia.

Dementia is defined as a disease process, which is marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Ex: Dementia in Alzheimer's disease.

Pseudodementia occurs in depressed people who complain of impaired memory but, in fact, have a depressive disorder.

 

The following table shows differentiating clinical features between dementia and pseudodementia:

Dementia

Pseudodementia

Clinical Course and History

 

Onset can be dated only within broad limits

Onset can be dated precisely

Long duration and slow progression of symptoms

Short duration and rapid progression of symptoms

Usually, there is no history of previous psychiatric dysfunction

There is a history of previous psychiatric dysfunction.

Family is not aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Family is aware of the patient's dysfunction and severity

Complaints and clinical behaviour

 

The patients complain little of cognitive loss, and the complaints are often vague

The patients complain much of cognitive loss, and the complaints are detailed.

Usually labile affect

  

Severe depression on examination

Disability is concealed by the patient

Disability is emphasized by the patient

Patient highlights accomplishments

Patient highlights failures

They struggle to perform simple tasks and rely on notes or calendars etc.

They make little effort to perform even simple tasks

Social skills are often retained

Loss of social skills often early and prominent
Behaviour is compatible with the severity of cognitive dysfunction Behaviour is incongruent with the severity of cognitive dysfunction
Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction common Nocturnal accentuation of dysfunction uncommon

Clinical Features Related to Memory, Cognitive, and Intellectual Dysfunctions

Patient makes errors on cognitive examination

‘Do not know’ answers are more frequent

Attention and concentration usually faulty

 Attention and concentration often well preserved

Memory loss for recent events usually more severe than for remote events

  

Memory loss for recent and remote events usually severe

Memory gaps for specific periods unusual. Confabulation may be present.

  Memory gaps are usually present. Confabulation is rare.

 

Note:

Confabulation refers to the unconscious filling of gaps in memory by imagining experiences or events that have no basis in fact. It is commonly seen in amnestic syndromes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with a diabetic foot ulcer. The surgeon does the ulcer dressing and prescribed him Ciprofloxacin and Aspirin along with strict sugar control measures. Which adverse effect  due to ciprofloxacin is the least likely among the given options?

choices.text: Propensity to cause seizures with history of epilepsy
Clostridium difficile infection due to prolonged antibiotic usage

questions.solution:
Hepatic enzyme elevation is less likely with the usage of Ciprofloxacin because it is eliminated by the kidney.

All Fluoroquinolones except moxifloxacin are eliminated by the kidney and need dose adjustments in renal disease. Moxifloxacin is eliminated by the liver.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones

GI - nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort, Clostridium difficile infection 

Neurologic - headache, dizziness. In patients receiving NSAIDs or theophylline, more chances of seizures, delirium.

Musculoskeletal - joint pains and tendinitis, more frequently in elderly patients over 60 years, transplant recipients or those receiving steroids

 

Related Pearl: Withdrawn fluoroquinolones and the associated adverse events

 

Withdrawn Fluoroquinolones The Associated Adverse Events
Lomefloxacin and Gatifloxacin Phototoxicity, QTc prolongation
Trovafloxacin Hepatotoxicity
Gatifloxacin Hypoglycemia
Grepafloxacin Cardiotoxicity
Temafloxacin Immune hemolytic anemia
Clinafloxacin Phototoxicity

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Drugs Associated with QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes:

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Rilpivirine

Antidepressants:

  • Amitriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Imipramine
  • Doxepin
  • Fluoxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone

questions.text: The population of a country is 100 crores in the year 2023. If this country has an explosive annual growth rate of 3%, the population of the country will most likely double in almost:
questions.solution:
If the annual growth rate is 3%, the population of the country will double in almost 25 years.

Growth rate: When the crude death rate is subtracted from the crude birth rate, the net residual is the current annual growth rate, exclusive of migration. The growth rate is not uniform in the world. A population growing at 0.5 per cent per year will double in about 140 years, a population growing at 3 per cent per year will double in about 20- 25 years.

The relation between growth rate and population:

Rating Annual growth rate Population doubles in
Slow growth <0.5% >139 years
Moderate growth  0.5%-1.0% ~139-70 years
Rapid growth from 1%- 1.5% 70-47 years
Very rapid growth from 1.5%-2% 47-35 years
Explosive growth from 2%-2.5% 35-28 years
Explosive growth from 2.5-3.0% 28-23 years
  3.0%-3.5% 23-20 years
  3.5%- 4.0% 20-18 years

Note: India’s population growth rate as of 2018 is 1.2%. (Acc. to UN data)

questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: An enzymologist is studying the mechanism of action of an enzyme. He uses spectrophotometry to detect the light-absorbing property of the functional groups of the product. He notices increased absorbance at 340nm. What is the likely mechanism of action of the enzyme?
questions.solution:
The likely mechanism of action of this enzyme is hydrogenase with subsequent production of NADPH.

NADPH as a group absorbs light at 340nm. So if NADPH is increased, absorbance increases at 340nm. If NADPH is decreased, absorbance decreases.

If the enzyme had been a dehydrogenase with subsequent consumption of NADPH, absorbance at 340nm would've decreased.

Related Pearl: Reducing Equivalents and Their Uses

Reducing agents

Uses

NADPH

Lipid synthesis

Cholesterol synthesis 

Fatty acid chain elongation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylation of aromatic compounds, steroids, alcohols, and drugs

NADH

Metabolizes alcohol

Glycolysis & Krebs cycle

Oxidative phosphorylation

β- Oxidation of fatty acid

Catalyzes reactions in muscle and liver cells

Electron Transport Chain

FADH2

Krebs cycle

Electron Transport Chain

Oxidative Phosphorylation

Cytochrome P450 hydroxylase cycle

β-Oxidation of fatty acid

questions.text: A 15-year-old male was found to have the following lesion incidentally on an X-ray. Which of the following statements is true about the lesion?

choices.text: The definite stalk is usually directed towards the growth plate
Sessile type is more common than pedunculated type
Lesions are larger clinically than what their XRay appearance suggests

questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows a well-defined exostosis also called osteochondroma. The lesions are usually covered with a cartilaginous cap which cannot be seen radiologically and hence the lesions are larger clinically than what their X-Ray appearance suggests.

Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. Most of these lesions are asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally.

These are of two types: Pedunculated and sessile, pedunculated types are more common. The definite stalk is directed away from the physis. Malignant degeneration is extremely rare.

Management: Most patients are asymptomatic and never seek medical attention. However, symptomatic people may undergo resection.

Interestingly, exostosis developing in a joint is known as Trevor disease(Intraarticular epiphyseal osteochondroma/ dysplasia epiphysealis hemimelica).

questions.text: A young man presented with severe muscle weakness and drooping of eyelids. The symptoms worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest. Chest X-ray revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Biopsy of this mass would most likely reveal which of the following pathologic changes?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is associated with thymic hyperplasia.

Myasthenia gravis is an acquired autoimmune disease characterized by abnormal muscular fatigability that typically worsens with exertion and towards the end of the day. It most commonly involves the extraocular muscles causing diplopia and ptosis.

It is caused due to circulating autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor at the myoneural junction. In about 30% of the patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis, and about 10% have thymoma. 

The thymus normally contains small numbers of myoid cells, stromal cells that express skeletal muscle antigens. In both thymoma and thymic hyperplasia, the normal thymic function is disrupted leading to autoimmunity against ACh receptors expressed on thymic myoid cells. 

Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presented to the Dermatology OPD with the following lesion. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Epidermal turnover time in this condition is 4 days.
Pautrier’s microabscess is seen in this condition.
Beta blockers and antimalarials can aggravate this condition.
Goekerman Regimen is used in the treatment of this condition.

questions.solution:
In this image, a typical erythematous psoriatic plaque is shown with silvery white scales with the site of predilection usually in extensor areas which is characteristic of Psoriasis. Munro microabscess is seen in Psoriasis and Pautrier’s microabscess is seen in Mycosis fungoides.

Histopathological Features of Psoriasis

  • Irregular epidermal thickening (Acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis and Parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Clubbing of rete ridges at the base
  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malphighian layer)
  • Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in Stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in Dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates

 

Epidermal Turnover Time (ETT): It is the time taken for the epidermis to replace itself. This is reduced to just 4 days in psoriasis from the normal ETT of about 27 days.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  • Beta blockers
  • Synthetic antimalarials
  • NSAIDS
  • Lithium
  • ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Interferon alpha
  • Tetracycline
  • Terbinafine
  • Gemfibrozil

The other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger Psoriasis are:

  • Infections : Beta hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and Smoking
  • Emotional Stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter time
  • Sunlight

Goekerman Regimen is used in the treatment of Psoriasis. The modified Goekerman Regimen involves application of coal tar for 5 hours/day in combination with exposure to narrow‐band UVB (NBUVB).

  • Ingram Regimen is another treatment regimen used in Psoriasis. In‐patients are treated with a coal tar bath, suberythemogenic UVB and then dithranol in Lassar’s paste is applied to plaques. 
  • The mechanism of action of dithranol may relate to its antiproliferative and pro‐apoptotic effects on keratinocytes.
  • Dithranol produces brown staining of the skin, which resolves about 2 weeks after therapy is completed.

Both regimens have a good safety profile and are highly efficacious.

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis

Type Drug of choice
Chronic Plaque Psoriasis Methotrexate
Erythrodermic Psoriasis Methotrexate 
Psoriatic Arthritis Methotrexate / Apremilast
Pustular Psoriasis Acitretin
Psoriasis in HIV patients Acitretin
Impetigo Herpetiformis

1. Systemic Corticosteroids

2. Cyclosporine
Erythrodermic Psoriasis in Pregnancy Systemic Corticosteroids

questions.text: The dermatologist prescribes an oral fungicidal agent for a patient diagnosed with onychomycosis as shown below. Which of the following options indicate the likely drug used in its treatment along with its mechanism of action?

choices.text: Itraconazole - Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Amphotericin B - Formation of pore  in cell membrane

questions.solution:
Terbinafine is an oral fungicidal agent and works by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis. It is used in the treatment of Onychomycosis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of “squalene epoxidase”, an early step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene whic is toxic to the organism.

Terbinafine is used to treat Onychomycosis by taking 250mg OD tablets for upto 12 weeks in case of toe nails. The efficacy is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail lacquer in onychomycosis.

It is also used in the treatment of Tinea corporis (2 weeks), Tinea cruris (4-6 weeks), Tinea capitis (4-8 weeks).

Other options:

Though Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in membrane, its not used in dermatophytic infections due to limited activity.

Itraconazole and Griseofulvin are fungistatic against tinea infections.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints that she is excessively worried about her appearance and a belief that her nose is ugly and abnormal. She consulted a few plastic surgeons despite her parents and friends saying that she is good-looking and not to worry. Due to her self-perceived feeling that she looks ugly, she no longer goes out with friends, which distresses her. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in her?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of body dysmorphic disorder. The patients are preoccupied with their appearance and self-perceived flaws, despite being told otherwise by friends and family.

Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is characterized by persistent preoccupations about one or more perceived defects or flaws in one’s appearance, but the defects or flaws appear slight, or not observable to others.

 

Diagnostic criteria (DSM V):

  • Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear slight to others.
  • At some point during the course of the disorder, the individual has performed repetitive behaviours (e.g., mirror checking, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (e.g., comparing his or her appearance with that of others) in response to the appearance concerns.
  • The preoccupation causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The appearance preoccupation is not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight in an individual whose symptoms meet diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient with progressive conductive hearing loss was found to have otosclerotic foci on the entire footplate along with complete involvement of the oval window. What type of otosclerosis is this patient suffering from?
questions.solution:
The otosclerotic foci found on the entire footplate of stapes along with complete involvement of the oval window is an obliterative type of stapedial otosclerosis.

The stapedial type of otosclerosis presents predominantly with a bilateral conductive type of deafness and can be of various types:

  • Anterior focus: Involving only the fissula ante fenestrum
  • Posterior focus: Only fissula post fenestrum
  • Circumferential: Around the margin of the stapes footplate
  • Biscuit type: Entire footplate except for the annular ligament
  • Obliterative: Entire footplate when it completely obliterates the oval window niche.

Otosclerosis is a bony overgrowth involving the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. This condition worsens during stress and conditions with hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis Any site but asymptomatic

 

Clinical features

  • An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis Willisii.
  • In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The image below shows the Schwartze sign.

  • Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne (i.e. BC > AC).
  • Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch. 

The image below shows Carhart's notch in pure tone audiometry. 

  • Tympanometry shows As type of curve indicating that the pressure is normal but compliance is reduced. 

The image below shows As type of curve in tympanometry which is seen in otosclerosis.

  • As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, the stapedial reflex is lost.

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Image below shows stapedotomy procedure.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Exhumation of a grave revealed only a remnant pelvis bone. All of the following options point towards the pelvis belonging to a male except?
questions.solution:
Broad and round pelvic cavity is found in a female pelvis. The male pelvic cavity is conical and funnel-shaped.

Differences between male and female pelvis:

Characteristic Male pelvis Female pelvis
General Morphology Massive,  rougher, marked muscle attachments Less massive, slender, smoother
Overall shape Deep funnel Flat bowl
Preauricular sulcus Narrow, shallow Broad, deep
Acetabulum Large, wider, deeper Small, narrower

Body of pubis

Narrow, triangular, thick

Broad, square
Obturator foramen

Large, oval with base upward

Small, triangular with apex forwards
Subpubic angle V-shaped, narrow, (70o) U-shaped, rounded, wide, (90o)
Greater sciatic notch

Smaller, narrower, deeper

Larger, wider, shallower
Ischial Tuberosity Inverted Everted, more widely separated
Pelvic Brim Heart-Shaped Circular or elliptical
Pelvic outlet Smaller Larger

Sacroiliac articulation

Large extends to 21/2 to 3 vertebrae

Small, oblique, extends to 2 to 21/2 vertebrae

Sacroiliac joint surface

Large and less sharply angulated

 

L-shaped and elevated anteriorly

 

Sacrum

Longer, narrower, with more evenly distributed curvature, promontory well marked. Body of first sacral vertebra larger.

 

Shorter, wider; upper
half almost straight, curve forward in the lower half, promontory less marked. Body of first sacral vertebra small

questions.text: Antibiotic sensitivity report for a sample of purulent discharge from a patient is resistant to Penicillin. You suspect infection with a bacterial strain producing β-lactamases. Which of the following is true regarding β-lactamases?

choices.text: Are of 3 types -A, B and C
Encoded by chromosomal DNA in staphylococcus
Produced more in gram negative bacteria compared to gram positive

questions.solution:
Resistance by lactamases is through the degradation of penicillin, cephalosporins and carbapenems

Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivates β-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring in their structure. They are of 4 types - A, B, C, and D. They are produced in a greater amount in gram-positive compared to gram-negative bacteria They are encoded by plasmid in staphylococcus and maybe plasmid or chromosomally encoded in gram-negative bacteria. The plasmid is transferable by conjugation.

However, the resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactamase is conferred through one of the four mechanisms

  • Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
  • Modification of target PBPs
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs
  • Antibiotic efflux

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient presented with acute renal failure. A dynamic radionuclide renography was ordered to assess the renal perfusion. Which of the following radionuclides are preferred?

99mTc-MAG3 - mercaptoacetyltriglycine 

99m-Tc-MDP - methylene diphosphonate
questions.solution:
99mTc-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for performing dynamic radionuclide renography, to assess renal perfusion.

99mTc-MAG3 dynamic radionuclide renography is the simplest and safest way to assess renal perfusion in patients with renal failure. It helps in differentiating the reversible causes of acute renal failure such as acute tubular necrosis, from conditions like intrinsic parenchymal disease where it is severely impaired or absent.

Dynamic renography:

  • Used to assess split renal function and drainage from the renal collecting systems in suspected obstruction
  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function and hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR

Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 Dynamic Renography:

  • To find divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated
  • To find differential renal function following surgery or procedure. Examples: post pyeloplasty or post removal of a double J stent
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction following renal transplantation

Other options:

Option A- 99mTc-pertechnetate is used in the imaging of the thyroid, salivary glands, and Meckel's diverticulum imaging.

Option B- 99mTc-sulphur colloid is used in liver/spleen imaging, and prosthetic infection.

Option D- 99m-Tc-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is used for bone scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented with vaginal bleeding for the past 3 days. Ultrasonography revealed a dilated endometrial cavity. Suction curettage was done to evacuate the uterus, which revealed grapelike clusters and fetal parts. Cytogenetic examination of this tissue will most likely demonstrate which of the following genetic patterns?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of a partial hydatidiform mole, which usually demonstrates triploidy.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Partial moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents to the clinic with symptoms suggestive of anxiety. She wants to make friends in her new class but is afraid to approach people for fear of being rejected or criticized and usually avoids any such interactions. What is the most likely personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient has the desire to be in relationships and have social interaction but avoids these interactions due to fear of being rejected.

It is characterized by low self-esteem, and reluctance to engage in new activities. The patients are typically timid and avoid social activities and interpersonal interactions due to fear of criticism, disapproval, or rejection. It is colloquially known as having an inferiority complex. It is equally prevalent in men and women. 

Alfred Adler, the founder of individual psychology, coined the term inferiority complex.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

questions.text: What can be the likely cause of ascites if the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG ) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl?
questions.solution:
The cause of ascites when the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl is Congestive heart failure.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1):

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: You are posted as the in-charge medical officer for a special vaccination drive for measles. You would advise avoiding measles vaccination in all of the following individuals except ____.

choices.text: A patient who has a high fever
A patient in early stages of HIV infection
A patient with history of an anaphylactic reaction to gelatin

questions.solution:
A patient in the early stages of HIV infection is not a contraindication for measles vaccination.

Measles vaccination is contraindicated

  • if the patient has a high fever, 
  • pregnant women,
  • severely immunocompromised due to congenital disease,
  • severe HIV infection,
  • advanced leukaemia or lymphoma,
  • serious malignant disease,
  • history of an anaphylactic reaction to neomycin, gelatin
  • treatment with high-dose steroids, alkylating agents or antimetabolites, or immuno-suppressive therapeutic radiation

The measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is safe and effective with no evidence of person-to-person transfer of vaccine strains. In general, live vaccines are contraindicated in immune deficiency diseases and immunosuppressive states(malignancies, steroid therapy, chemotherapy with anticancer drugs, radiation) and in pregnancy.

Measles vaccine can be given in combination with other live attenuated vaccines such as mumps, and rubella vaccines (MMR vaccine), measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV), and measles and rubella (MR).

Measles is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash. Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash at the level of the premolars. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities.

Diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Most of the complications are secondary to bacterial infections. It includes pneumonia, acute otitis media, croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition.

 

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text: A patient with middle ear fluid accumulation is tested using tympanometry. What is the expected tympanogram finding seen in this case?

choices.text: Compliance is high at or near ambient air pressure
Compliance is lower at or near ambient air pressure
Maximum compliance occurs with negative pressure

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of middle ear fluid accumulation, the expected tympanogram finding would be a flat or dome-shaped graph.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube.

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

By changing the pressures in a sealed external auditory canal and then measuring the reflected sound energy, it is possible to find the compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system and thus find the healthy or diseased status of the middle ear.

Tympanometry is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are obtained. They are as follows:

The image given below shows impedance audiometry. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements.

Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels.

  • To deliver a tone of 220Hz
  • To absorb reflected sound
  • To change the pressure in the external auditory canal

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient is not able to perform the test shown in the image given below. Which of the following nerves could be injured?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the card test, which tests adduction by palmar interossei. The ulnar nerve could be injured in this patient who is not able to perform the test.

In the card test, Examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers of the patient. He asks to hold it tightly as possible while he tries to pull the card back. Due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles patient is unable to hold a card between the fingers. This test is used for detecting ulnar nerve injury.

 

The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles, all the palmar and dorsal interossei, and medial two lumbricals. Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of the deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Mnemonic for the action of interossei: PAD and DAB - palmar interossei cause adduction and dorsal interossei cause abduction of the fingers.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.
