questions.text: You are posted in the general surgery ward as an intern where you are learning wound management and dressing. For each patient with a wound, you are to calculate the ASEPSIS score. Which of the following will you not be taking into consideration while calculating this score?
questions.solution:
ASEPSIS wound score does not take bleeding from the wound into consideration.

The ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

ASEPSIS score includes:

  • Additional treatment
    • Antibiotics for wound infection
    • Drainage of pus under local anesthesia
    • Debridement of the wound under general anesthesia
  • Serous discharge
  • Erythema
  • Purulent exudate
  • Separation of deep tissue
  • Isolation of bacteria from the wound
  • Stay as inpatient prolonged over 14 days as a result of wound infection

questions.text: A 20-year-old basketball player collapses during a match and regains consciousness several minutes later. He has occasional dyspnea and recounts that he has had similar fainting episodes before. Echocardiography shows left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet. His older brother, an athlete, passed away at the age of 25 during a soccer game due to a heart ailment. Which of the following is not a risk factor for sudden death in this patient?

choices.text: History of spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a possible diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). LV thickness >30 mm is a risk factor for sudden death.

Risk Factors for Sudden Death in Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy:

  • History of cardiac arrest or spontaneous sustained ventricular tachycardia (>3 beats at rate >120 Exercise)
  • Syncope (nonvagal,  with or after exertion)
  • Family history of sudden cardiac death
  • Spontaneous nonsustained ventricular tachycardia
  • LV thickness >30 mm (present in <10% of patients)- seen on Echocardiography
  • Abnormal blood pressure response to exercise

HCM is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly.

questions.text:
A patient with coronary artery disease who does not tolerate 1st line anti-anginal drugs is prescribed trimetazidine. How would you classify this drug according to its mechanism of action?

pFOX - partial fatty acid oxidation
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor.

Trimetazidine partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the heart by inhibiting the last enzyme in the beta-oxidation pathway. This causes a shift in heart metabolism to use glucose. Since oxygen required is lesser in glucose metabolism, it is believed to be helpful in ischemia by decreasing the oxygen demand of the heart.

It is used as a second-line anti-anginal drug in case of stable angina when 1st line agents are not tolerated.

Side effects include nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal upset. It can also cause hepatic enzyme elevation and thrombocytopenia.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A patient's gall bladder has the following appearance on MRI. What is the most likely interpretation?
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the gallbladder is known as a Phrygian cap, which is a normal anatomical variant.

Phrygian cap refers to an anatomical variant of the gallbladder, where the gallbladder's fundus folds on itself or is separated from the body by a partial or complete septum. A true septum is uncommon and is usually an apparent septum due to the gallbladder wall folding. It is an incidental finding that may be seen on CT, MRI, or ultrasound. It causes no symptoms.

The Phrygian cap is named so, due to the resemblance of the ultrasonographic appearance to a hat or cap that is worn by the inhabitants of ancient Phrygia circa 1200 BC.

The image below shows a Phrygian cap:

 

Other options:

Option a: Cholangiocarcinoma is an adenocarcinoma originating from the bile duct. It is diagnosed based on a CT/MRI. Depending on the type of tumor, the findings may include capsular retraction, biliary dilatation, or wall thickening.

Option b: Choledochal cyst or biliary cystic disease commonly presents in childhood with pain, jaundice, and a right upper quadrant mass. MRCP is the preferred investigation.

Option c: Caroli's disease refers to a sporadic condition characterized by the formation of intrahepatic biliary cysts. USG /CT reveals the beaded appearance of the intrahepatic bile ducts with multiple cystic structures. It is characteristically associated with the central dot sign.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl presented with the delayed eruption of teeth and a reddish discoloration as shown in the image below. The diaper of this baby showed pink-colored staining. She had a history of blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight since the 6th day of birth. Deficiency of which of the following enzyme will lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing erythrodontia is suggestive of Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, which is caused by the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen III synthase.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria ( Gunther disease) :

It is an autosomal recessive porphyria, which is caused by uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocyte, plasma urine, and faeces.

The most characteristic presentation is reddish urine or pink staining of diapers by urine. Reddish-brown teeth is seen under normal light and when illuminated with UV light, the teeth show reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
