Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: You are conducting retrospective research on factors responsible for dry eye disorder.  As a part of your study, you are looking through the files in the clinic of dry eye patients. Which among the following patients would not be included in your study?

choices.text: A 26 year old patient showing decreased levels of lactoferrin in tear samples
A 20 year old patient showing tear film break up at 18-20 seconds
A 24 year old patient showing A pattern stain in Rose bengal staining
A 22 year old patient showing Schirmer test tear strip wet upto 9 mm

questions.solution:
A patient with tear film break up at 18-20 seconds is considered to be normal. All the other patients have dry eye.

Tear film break-up (BUT) time is the interval between a complete blink and the appearance of a first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.

Inference:

  • 15-35 seconds - normal
  • < 10 seconds- unstable tear film

Other options:

Option A: Tear samples can be assayed for the presence of markers known to be decreased (e.g. lactoferrin) or elevated (e.g. matrix metalloproteinase-9) in dry eye. This is known as tear constituent measurement. 

Option C: A patient with A pattern on Rose Bengal staining has severe dry eye. 

Option D: A patient with 9mm wet Schirmer strip has moderate dry eye. 

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and has been taking lithium for the past 5 years. She is currently in remission. However, she now presented to the OPD with worsening depression, fatigue, weight loss, abdominal pain, renal colic, and bone pain. Which of the following tests would most likely reveal the underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypercalcemia due to prolonged lithium therapy. Serum calcium levels should be assessed.

Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorders in combination with other drugs such as antidepressants, antipsychotics, and benzodiazepines. One of the common adverse effects of prolonged lithium therapy is hyperparathyroidism, which presents with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia.

Patients with hypercalcemia, depending on the severity, may present with symptoms, which include: fatigue, lethargy, anorexia, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, bone pain, depression, polyuria, polydipsia, and renal colic. The classic symptoms of hyperparathyroidism are described as 'bones, stones, and abdominal groans'.

The adverse effects of lithium include:

  • Neurological:
    • memory difficulties, tremors, peripheral neuropathy
    • dysarthria, ataxia, seizures
    • benign intracranial hypertension, myasthenia gravis-like syndrome
  • Endocrine: goiter, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism (rare), hyperparathyroidism
  • Cardiovascular: benign T-wave changes, sinus node dysfunction
  • Renal: nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, renal tubular acidosis
  • Dermatological: Acne, hair loss, psoriasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Appetite loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea 

Other options:

  • Serum ferritin levels are not known to be affected with lithium therapy.
  • Some studies have shown that vitamin B12 levels may be reduced with lithium therapy. However, the symptoms given in the question are mostly related to hypercalcemia.
  • Patients with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy, are more likely to develop hypothyroidism. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels may be monitored in these patients. However, as per the given clinical scenario, a patient with hypothyroidism is unlikely to have weight loss and bone pain. Hence serum calcium is the preferred option.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Glucose and galactose are epimers because of difference of -OH group location on carbon number______
questions.solution:
Glucose and galactose are epimers because of difference of -OH group location on carbon number 4

Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other. Example:

Epimers of glucose are –

  • mannose (epimerized at carbon 2).
  • galactose (epimerized at carbon 4).

questions.text: A mother is advised that the baby should be allowed to empty one breast completely before switching over to the other for optimum growth. All the following are reasons for this, except ____.

choices.text: Foremilk is rich in  sugar and vitamins

questions.solution:
While breastfeeding, the mother should allow complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both fore-milk and hind-milk for optimum growth. Hind milk is rich in fats that provide more energy.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

questions.text: A middle-aged man was administered thiopental for induction before a surgical procedure. Induction is faster with thiopental in all of the following, except _______.
questions.solution:
Induction is faster with thiopental in all of the options, except alkalosis.

The rapidity of induction of thiopental is based on how fast it gets redistributed. This depends on the lipid solubility and a higher nonionized fraction of the barbiturates in the blood.

Increased non-ionized fraction as in case of acidosis, contracted central compartment as seen in hypovolemic shock (option D), and low serum albumin as in severe malnutrition or liver disease (option B and C) thus favors rapid induction. 

Thiopental is a barbiturate used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset of action within 15-30 seconds and smooth induction. It is also used to maintain general anesthesia. The dosage is 3-4 mg/kg.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest concentration in the saliva, under resting conditions?
questions.solution:
The concentration of the bicarbonate is highest in the saliva (50 to 70 mEq/L).

Secretion of ions in saliva:

  • Salivary secretion occurs in two stages.
  • The first stage involves acini, which secrete ptyalin and/or mucin together with some ions. The composition of the ions is similar to that of the extra-cellular fluid.
  • The second stage involves the ducts. As the primary salivary secretion flows through the ducts, two active transport processes occur:
    • Na+ is actively re-absorbed and K+ is actively secreted, in exchange for Na+.
    • HCO3- is secreted by the ductal epithelium into the lumen of the salivary ducts. Some of this secretion occurs by passive exchange of bicarbonate for Cl-.
  • As a result, the Na+ and Cl- concentrations are lower than that of plasma, while K+ and HCO3- concentrations are higher than that of plasma.

Composition of ions:

  • Under resting conditions, the concentrations of Na+ and Cl- in saliva are about 15 mEq/L each, which is 1/7th to 1/10th that of the plasma concentrations.
  • K+ concentration is about 30 mEq/L, which is seven times higher than that of plasma.
  • HCO3- concentration is 50 to 70 mEq/L, which is two to three times higher than that of the plasma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with a painless nodule in the outer lower aspect of her left breast, which she noticed for the last 2 months. The nodule is firm and freely movable. Mammogram demonstrates a circumscribed, homogeneous density. A biopsy of the breast mass is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathology of the breast, are most likely suggestive of fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. About two-thirds of the cases occur due to driver mutations in MED12 gene.

Morphology:

Gross features:

  • The tumor may vary in size ranging from 1cm to replacing almost the entire breast.
  • The tumors are well-circumscribed, rubbery, grayish-white nodules that bulge above the surrounding tissue.

Microscopic features:

  • Tumors often contain slit-like spaces lined by epithelium.
  • The stroma is often myxoid and resembles the normal intralobular stroma.
  • The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern).
  • In elderly women, the stroma becomes densely hyalinized and the epithelium may become atrophic.

The histopathology image below shows proliferation of intralobular stroma, which surrounds, pushes, and distorts the epithelium.

Clinical features:

  • They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women <30 years of age.
  • They are hormonally responsive and may grow in size during pregnancy and regress after menopause.
  • Almost half of women who receive cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple, bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.
  • Fibroadenomas are associated with an increased risk of carcinoma if there are complex features such as cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

 

Other options:

Option a: Phyllodes Tumor arises from intralobular stroma, like a fibroadenoma. However, it is less common. The tumors vary in size from a few centimetres to massive lesions. The larger masses have bulbous protrusions due to the presence of nodules of proliferating stroma covered by epithelium. Due to the protrusions, the shape of the tumour resembles a leaf, hence the name Phyllodes tumour (phyllodes is Greek for “leaf-like”).

Option c: Ductal carcinoma in situ is characterized by clonal proliferation of epithelial cells, which are limited to ducts and lobules by the basement membrane. Myoepithelial cells are preserved, but may be decreased in number. Histology shows zones of necrosis and calcifications, which fills several ducts. In micropapillary DCIS, there may be papillary projections that lack fibrovascular cores.

Option d: Medullary carcinoma of the breast is a histological subtype of invasive breast carcinoma. They are soft compared to other tumors. Histologically, the tumor consists of solid sheets of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei and prominent nucleoli, frequent mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate surrounding and within the tumor, with a pushing border.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatry OPD with symptoms suggestive of severe depression together with psychotic symptoms including hallucinations for the past 3 months. Her parents reported that earlier in the second month, for about three weeks, she was not depressed but had auditory and visual hallucinations. She was not using any drugs or medications. Which of the following disorders best describes the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The concurrent presence of psychotic symptoms together with depression for three months, in which there was a three-week episode of psychotic symptoms in the absence of depression is most likely suggestive of schizoaffective disorder.

Schizoaffective disorder:

DSM-5 criteria:

  • An uninterrupted period of illness where there is a major mood episode (depression or mania) concurrent with psychosis (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc.)
  • Delusions or hallucinations (psychotic symptoms) for at least two weeks in the absence of a major depressive or manic episode during the lifetime course of the illness.
  • Major mood episode is present for the majority of total illness.
  • Not due to intake of substances or another medical condition.

Note: According to DSM -5 guidelines, for a definitive diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, there have to be two psychotic episodes. One of the psychotic episodes has to be concurrent with a major mood episode (depression or manic). The other psychotic episode should be for two or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode. And the major mood episode should dominate the major part during the life time course of the illness.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: A patient on chloroquine treatment for malaria suffers a category II dog bite. He approaches you for immunization. Which among the following would you consider as correct regarding the rabies vaccination in this case?

choices.text: Vaccination needs to be delayed till completion of chloroquine dose
Patient may receive the vaccine intradermally as usual
Patient should receive the vaccine intramuscularly

questions.solution:
The patient should receive the vaccine intramuscularly in this case.

People receiving chloroquine for malaria treatment or prophylaxis have a reduced response to intradermal rabies vaccination. Therefore, these patients should receive the vaccine intramuscularly.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: An 82-year-old male patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological processes is likely to have resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum calcium levels, occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e. the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis and areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in aging or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A - Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on Congo red staining.

Option B - Monckeberg medial sclerosis is a vascular pathology of aging characterized by calcifications accumulating in the medial layers of muscular arteries. Since there is no vascular compromise (no luminal narrowing), it is usually an accidental finding.

Option D - Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

questions.text:
A 35-year-old  patient presents to the emergency department with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination, he is hypotensive, the heart sounds are muffled, JVP is increased, with
a prominent "x"  descent but an absent "y" descent.  Which of the following will be the most likely finding seen on the ECG of this patient?

choices.text: Low ECG voltage and electrical alternans
Raised ST segment with upward concavity

questions.solution:
A 35-year-old  patient with acute breathlessness, falling BP, rising JVP (with a prominent "x" descent but an absent "y" descent), and soft heart sounds suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. In a cardiac tamponade, the ECG findings are low voltage and electrical alternans.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intrapericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

The diastolic dip-and-plateau pattern, also known as a square root sign, is produced when early rapid diastolic inflow into the ventricle commences but is then abruptly halted by an opposing force. It is seen in constrictive pericarditis.

In constrictive pericarditis : Right atrial pressure is elevated with a prominent “y” descent, indicating rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole. 

ECG showing pericardial effusion with tamponade; arrows indicate electrical alternans:

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient complains of a burning sensation in both legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling, and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles." Which of the following drugs is used in the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has painful diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the drugs used in the first-line treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as a burning, excruciating, stabbing, or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A newborn developed cyanosis soon after birth. Chest x-ray showed the characteristic egg-on-a-string appearance, as shown in the below image. Which of the following options indicates the relation of the aorta with respect to the pulmonary artery in the given condition?

choices.text: Aorta lies posterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the left of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies posterior and to the right of pulmonary artery
Aorta lies anterior and to the right of pulmonary artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an x-ray showing egg on a string appearance is characteristic of transposition of great arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta generally lies anterior and to the right of the Pulmonary artery. Therefore it is also referred as D-TGA.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve passes through:
questions.solution:
The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve passes through foramen rotundum, labelled as 'A' in the above image.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal
  • Optic nerves
  • Ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure
  • Lacrimal nerve (V1)
  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)
  • CNs III, IV, VI
  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein
Foramen rotundum
  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI
  • Sigmoid Sinus continuing as IJV 
  • Middle meningeal branch of occipital artery
Hypoglossal canal
  • Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Foramen magnum
  • Osseo-ligamentous (anterior) compartment: 
    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: A peripherally inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this catheter?
questions.solution:
The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena cava.

Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest Xray is taken to confirm the position of the tip.

PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed.

The image below shows (A) a typical PICC line (B) Illustration showing insertion of PICC line (C) A patient with PICC line inserted through the upper arm.

The image below shows the chest X-ray confirming the position of the tip of the PICC line (arrows), in the superior vena cava.

Ideal positions of the tip of some commonly used catheters or tubes that can be confirmed on a chest X-ray:

Catheter Position of tip
Endotracheal tube

3-8 cm above the carina

Swan-Ganz catheter

Right or left pulmonary artery

Central venous pressure (CVP) catheter

Superior vena cava

Peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line

Superior vena cava

Left atrial catheter

Left atrium

Mediastinal drains

Anterior mediastinum or posterior pericardium

Pleural tubes

  In pleural space, directed anteriorly for pneumothorax and posteriorly for effusion

Temporary pacing wires

  

Over right heart

Nasogastric tube

  

Left upper quadrant of the abdomen, with side holes in the stomach

questions.text: A farmer presents to you with a grossly contaminated wound, 2 days after his foot was crushed by a tractor, as shown below. It is associated with sweet-smelling discharge,  is tender on palpation, and crepitus is elicited on movement. Which of the following is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: It is most commonly caused by Clostridium perfringens
Sample of the discharging exudate need to be collected in a sterile universal sample container
It shows positive reverse CAMP test
Metronidazole +Clindamycin is used in patients allergic to penicillin

questions.solution:
The given image shows a contaminated wound with necrotic material, involving toes that are blackened, with blebs formation, and is likely a case of gas gangrene or clostridial myonecrosis. 

Sample collection is done in a swab stick or Robertson cooked meat medium as it is anerobic bacteria. Though it is an anaerobe and might tolerate a little oxygen, it should preferably be collected in such a way that it gets little exposure to open air unlike in a universal sample container.

Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridum perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram positive bacteria without spores. It is an anaerobe and grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis. The reverse CAMP test is positive with hemolysis arrow pointing towards Clostridial streak. Naegler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridum. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium.

Treatment of gas gangrene:

  • Emergent surgical exploration and thorough debridement are extremely important.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered after surgery and antibiotics (penicillin G plus clindamycin; 600–900 mg IV q6–8h), and anti-gas gangrene serum has to be initiated after debridement.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient sustained a head injury in a road traffic accident. During the examination, the patient was unable to recall his name, the name of the place he lives in, or his date of birth. However, he was still able to remember the events such as his marriage. His non-declarative memory is intact. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient had a loss of memory associated with the facts (semantic memory), suggestive of injury to the prefrontal cortex or anterior/lateral temporal cortex.

Forms of memory are classified into two types, explicit and implicit.

Explicit/declarative memory is the memory of factual knowledge about people, places, things, and events. It is associated with consciousness/awareness. They are of two types:

  • Semantic memory (facts) e.g., knowing the capital of India, date of birth, names of people, etc. The parts of the brain involved are the lateral & anterior temporal cortex and prefrontal cortex.
  • Episodic memory (events) e.g., recalling the events that occurred on the first day in college. The parts of the brain involved are the hippocampus, medial temporal lobe, and neocortex. 

Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory does not involve consciousness or awareness. They are of 4 types:

  • Procedural memory refers to skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic, such as riding a bicycle or driving a car. It is processed in the striatum.
  • Priming refers to the facilitation of the recognition of words or objects by prior exposure to them. It is dependent on the neocortex.
  • Non-associative learning includes habituation and sensitization. It is dependent on various reflex pathways.
  • Associative learning includes classical and operant conditioning in which one learns about the relationship between one stimulus and another. It is dependent on the amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department, where the resident asks you to bring the following instruments for a procedure. What is the most likely procedure planned?
questions.solution:
Pipelle aspirator (a) and Vabra (b) aspirator are shown in the image above which are used to obtain endometrial sampling.

It is performed as an outpatient procedure without anesthesia or under sedation. The cervix is not dilated and a biopsy curette is inserted and a strip or two of the endometrial tissue is obtained for histological study. It should be done preferably 1 or 2 days before the onset of menstruation. The material removed should be fixed immediately in formalin saline and submitted for histological examination.

In a postmenopausal woman, the normal endometrium should not exceed 4 mm in thickness (In a perimenopausal woman, it should not exceed 10 mm). If it exceeds 4 mm in a postmenopausal woman, then histopathological examination (HPE) of the endometrium is mandatory, irrespective of the presence or absence of symptoms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents in the emergency following two episodes of painless spotting per vagina preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She complained of lightheadedness and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and the pulse rate is 138 beats/minute, with a positive urine pregnancy test.  What should be the management of this patient?

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate
Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is implying a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy and the management of this patient would be a laparotomy.

The given clinical scenario is implying a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, suggested by:

  • History of amenorrhea for 8 weeks: Clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically appear six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.
  • Bleed per vaginum: amenorrhea of >4 weeks preceding the current vaginal bleeding suggests an ectopic gestation.
  • A positive urine test: suggestive of pregnancy.
  • Unstable vitals: suggestive of internal blood loss.

An unstable patient with this finding should undergo urgent surgical consultation and exploration ie, laparotomy. It reduces hemorrhage and hemodynamic instability, also giving a better view of the operating field for the surgeon.

Other differentials :

  • In Abruptio placenta there is painful vaginal bleeding that is associated with contractions and uterine hypertonicity which have not been mentioned in the question, which is basically a shock scenario due to an underlying a condition.
  •  In Placenta previa the classic presentation is painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that often stops spontaneously and then recurs with labor. The bleeding most likely occurs in 3rd trimester and does not lead to a shock-like condition.
  • In an un-ruptured ectopic pregnancy, there is no history of shock-like symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was referred to cardiology OPD for the management of hypertension. His BP was not controlled with spironolactone and laboratory investigations revealed hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. His BP comes down when spironolactone is replaced with amiloride. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, responding to amiloride but not spironolactone, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome (also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism) is most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone. Although its presentation is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone is nearly undetectable in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism.

Other options:

Option A: Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) occurs due to the activation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol, like in 11-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. It also presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but mineralocorticoid receptor blockade with spironolactone is successful in treating SAME. Spironolactone does not work in Liddle syndrome because the defect is downstream to where spironolactone acts.

Option C: Addison's disease refers to adrenal insufficiency and decreased levels of aldosterone. It presents with hyponatremic volume contraction (which may lead to hypotension), hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: During a measles epidemic, a 5-year-old boy, Rohan is posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. On the day of surgery, he is found to have an acute infection in the upper respiratory tract. His Hb level is 10.5 g%. Which of the given history/findings is a contraindication for the operation?
questions.solution:
Tonsillectomy is contraindicated in the presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: Health propaganda is being planned by the Public health authority to spread a particular systemized doctrine. This approach will not ______________

choices.text: Instill Knowledge in the minds of people

questions.solution:
Health propaganda develops reflexive behaviour, not reflective behaviour.

 

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour; Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour The process is behaviour centred  The process is information centred

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with excessive sweating, absent knee jerk on the right side, and anisocoria as shown in the below image. A senior resident advises you to perform a 0.1% pilocarpine test on her. On performing this pharmacological test you would notice
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with diaphoresis (excessive sweating), absent deep tendon reflex (absent knee jerk), and the image showing tonically dilated right pupil (Adie's tonic pupil) is highly suggestive of Holmes - Adie Syndrome. Therefore, application of 0.1% pilocarpine results in constriction of the right pupil.

In Adie’s tonic pupil, the affected pupil is larger (right pupil is larger than the left in the given image). On applying a weak solution of pilocarpine (0.1%), the affected pupil becomes smaller than the other pupil due to denervation hypersensitivity, while the normal pupil remains unaffected.

Holmes - Adie Syndrome:

It is characterised by a classic triad of diaphoresis, absent deep tendon reflexes, and Adie's tonic pupil. It is usually unilateral and is more common in young women. 

In this condition, the reaction to light is absent and to near reflex is very slow and tonic. It is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the pupillary sphincter.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was being administered hydrocortisone for the treatment of autoimmune disease. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone may cause elevation of the plasma protein levels. All other options are incorrect.

Effects of cortisol/hydrocortisone:

On carbohydrate metabolism:

  • Increases gluconeogenesis
  • Decreases utilization of glucose by the cells.
  • Elevates blood glucose (option d)concentration.
  • Increases insulin secretion (option a).

On protein metabolism:

  • Causes decreased protein synthesis and increased catabolism of cellular proteins, especially in the extrahepatic tissues such as muscles and lymphoid tissue.
  • This leads to decreased muscle mass, and muscle weakness (patient may not be able to rise from a squatting position). 
  • Enhances amino acid transport into the liver, leading to increased liver proteins. As a result, there is increased production of plasma proteins in the liver, which are then released into the blood (option c).

On Fat metabolism:

  • Promotes mobilisation of fatty acids from the adipose tissue
  • Increases oxidation of fatty acids.
  • There may be deposition of fat in the chest and head regions of the body, giving a buffalo-like torso and a rounded moon face appearance.

High plasma levels of hydrocortisone, causes suppression of CRH and, consequently, reduces ACTH secretion (option b).

questions.text: An intern enumerates the steps to place an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Intercostal tube is to be placed along the upper border of lower rib
Identify 5th intercostal space posterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Direct the tube posteriorly to prevent injury
Local anesthesia should include the pleura

questions.solution:
An intercostal tube is placed in the triangle of safety which is the safest site for insertion of a drain that lies in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line, above the level of the nipple, and, below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

Inserting and managing a chest drain.

Insertion of an intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is the standard management.

The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the Triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: A  primigravida with 38 weeks of pregnancy came to the hospital after she perceived decreased fetal movements. The ANC period has been uneventful. CTG was done and a partogram was plotted for her by the junior resident on duty. Which should be the management in this case?

choices.text: Wait and watch for the progress of labor
Give a trial for forceps/ventouse delivery
Plan for elective cesarean section at 40 weeks
Shift the patient to the OT for immediate cesarean section

questions.solution:
The above situation is a case of obstructed labor and management is urgent cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

The above partogram shows secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and also arrest of descent for >1 hour. The patient has adequate uterine contractions as shown.

The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is a fall in fetal heart rate which indicates that the baby is in distress.

The WHO partograph is a graphic record of the progress of labor and relevant details of the mother and fetus. It is a repeatedly tested topic in the NBE and Central Institute exams.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the needle shown below and the procedure it is used for?

choices.text: It is used in obstetric anesthesia
It causes rapid onset of anesthesia within 1-2 minutes
It is used along with catheter for continuous infusions for pain management
The blunt tip needle prevents accidental dural puncture

questions.solution:
The image shown is the 18 G Tuohy needle, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It does not cause rapid onset of anesthesia, instead has a slower onset of action ranging from 10-20 minutes compared to spinal anesthesia which has a relatively faster onset of action.

Identification points:

  • It has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture.
  • The needle shaft is marked in 1-cm intervals so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

It is used in obstetric anesthesia, segmental blocks, and chronic pain management.

Image below shows epidural anesthesia set with Touhy's needle and epidural catheter:

 

Other epidural needles: Crawford needle (straight needles without a curved tip): has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: A patient who had a left supracondylar fracture of the humerus a few years back now presents with a progressed deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the deformity?

choices.text: Most commonly involved tendons are flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus
The deformity exaggerates on flexing the wrist
Most commonly involved nerve is median nerve
Max Page's operation is done for moderate deformities

questions.solution:
The given deformity is a claw hand seen as a result of Volkmann's ischemic contracture. The deformity exaggerates on extending the wrist(not on flexing).

Ischemic contracture of muscles affected by arterial injury or compartment syndrome is known as Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture (VIC). VIC in the forearm is most commonly seen following supracondylar humeral fractures. The most common nerve involved in VIC is the median nerve. The most common tendons involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus and Flexor Pollicis Longus.

The classical clinical picture of established Volkmann contracture includes elbow flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, thumb adduction, metacarpophalangeal joint extension, and finger flexion. 

Volkmann's sign: The deformity disappears on flexion and appears on the extension of the wrist.

Treatment of VIC

  • Mild deformities - passive stretching of the contracted muscles with a turn-buckle splint (Volkmann’s splint)
  • Moderate deformities - soft tissue sliding procedures (Max Page operation)
  • Severe deformities - early excision of all necrotic muscles, combined with complete median and ulnar neurolysis. This is followed by a secondary procedure of tendon transfers to restore function. If motor activity is not present in these tendons, a free innervated Gracilis muscle transfer may be considered.

questions.text: A 29-year old G2P1 female, at 12 weeks of gestation, comes to you for a regular ANC visit. In her previous pregnancy, she had undergone a cesarean section with a T shaped incision for some unknown indication. She requests you for conducting a normal vaginal delivery but is open to know the best option. What will you tell her regarding the mode of delivery that will be used for her present pregnancy?

choices.text: A trial of labor at 40 completed weeks is recommended
The baby should be delivered by cesarean section

questions.solution:
The baby will be delivered by cesarean section as vaginal birth is contraindicated in a patient who has undergone a classical or a T incision in previous cesarean section.

Women who have undergone classical cesarean section, are at a high risk of scar dehiscence and uterine rupture and have lesser chances of successful vaginal birth in subsequent pregnancies. Importantly, in some women, a classical scar will rupture before labor onset, and this can happen several weeks before term.

In these patients, any form of a trial of labor is contraindicated. Both forceps/vacuum-assisted Vaginal birth is contraindicated (option b and c)

Women who have undergone an LSCS (lower segment cesarean section) are allowed a trial of labor due to a lower risk of uterine rupture.

Risk factors for a vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) :

Low risk High risk

●      Transverse incision

●      Prior vaginal delivery

●      Sufficient personnel and equipment

●      Classical or T incision in prior cesarean

●      Prior rupture

●      Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa

●      Inadequate facilities (most consider these high-risk factors as contraindications)

Classical cesarean indications:

Maternal:

  • Densely adhered bladder from previous surgery
  • Leiomyoma occupies the lower uterine segment
  • Cervical cancer
  • Massive maternal obesity
  • Placenta previa with anterior implantation

Fetal:

  • A transverse lie of a large fetus
  • Impacted shoulder
  • Multiple fetuses

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was subjected to hysterosalpingography and the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis and classification of the anomaly seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Uterus didelphys, Class III of Mullerian duct anomalies is seen on hysterosalpingography in the image given above.

Uterus didelphys occurs as a result of the non-fusion of paramesonephric ducts of both sides. Structures developing from the paramesonephric duct are the fallopian tube, uterus, cervix, and upper 2/3rds of the vagina and hence a patient with uterus didelphys will have 2 of each, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.

The following classification of Mullerian duct anomalies was proposed by Buttram and Gibbons :

  • Class I—Müllerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Müllerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

In the images given above:

A-Normal, B-Unicornuate, C-Arcuate, D to G-Septate uterus of different grades, H-Bicornuate, I-Didelphys

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of this patient is 6.

The given findings contributed to the score as follows:

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decerebrate posturing/abnormal extension - 2

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Decorticate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain.
  • The upper limbs are flexed, lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • It is caused due to damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons.
  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response in the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with a rash on her hand as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Gottron papules on the hand. With a history of breast cancer, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is dermatomyositis.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis include:

  • Eyelid erythema and edema - heliotrope rash
  • Gottron’s papules
  • V-sign
  • Shawl sign
  • Nail bed changes with dilated capillaries

The aboce image shows characteristic upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash, which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

The above image shows a macular rash on the anterior chest in dermatomyositis, known as V-sign.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

Skin condition Most commonly associated malignancy
Acanthosis nigricans Gastric adenocarcinoma
Acanthosis palmaris Bronchial carcinoma
Sign of LeserTrélat Gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma
Acquired-ichthyosis Hodgkin disease
Pityriasis rotunda Hepatocellular carcinoma
Paraneoplastic pigmentation Small cell bronchial carcinoma
Acrokeratosis paraneoplastica Squamous cell carcinoma of the upper respiratory or gastrointestinal
tracts
Erythema gyratum-repens Lung cancer
Necrolytic migratory erythema Glucagon secreting
pancreatic islet cell adenoma
Dermatomyositis Lung cancer in men, breast and gynaecological tumours in women and colorectal cancers in both sexes
Scleroderma‐like skin changes Carcinoid syndrome
Paraneoplastic pemphigus B‐cell proliferations and thymoma or thymoma‐like neoplasms; specifically Non Hodgkin's lymphoma (42%)
Dermatitis herpetiformis Lymphoma
Porphyria cutanea- tarda and variegate porphyrias Hepatocellular Carcinoma
Erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis Mycosis fungoides or Sézary syndrome
Pyoderma gangrenosum Hematological malignancy
Sweet syndrome Hematological malignancy
Migratory thrombo-phlebitis (Trousseau's syndrome) Carcinoma Pancreas

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

  Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion Body Myositis
Age of onset Adulthood and childhood >18 years >50 years  
Familial Association No No Yes
Skin Manifestation Yes No No
Muscle involvement

Symmetric

Symmetric

Asymmetric
Histopathological Findings

Perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates 

Perivascular infiltrates  

Endomysial CD8+ cellular infiltrates

Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles   
Association with connective tissue disease Scleroderma and mixed connective tissue only Yes Yes
Association with other autoimmune diseases Infrequent Frequent  Infrequent
Association with malignancy Yes (breast, ovarian, lung) and ILD  Yes (incidence much lesser than dermatomyositis)  No
Immunotherapy  Responsive  Responsive  Resistant

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: The postmortem phenomenon seen in image is-
questions.solution:
The image shows the post mortem phenomenon of marbling.


Adipocere: also called corpse wax, grave wax or mortuary wax, is a wax-like organic substance formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis of fat in tissue by bacteria.


Post mortem lividity or hypostasis is the settling of blood under the influence of gravity.


Petechial hemorrhage is a 1–2 mm red or purple discoloration on the skin, caused by a minor bleed from broken capillary blood vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is formed by co-translational modification. It is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA. 

Selenocysteine is an analog of cysteine and is synthesized from serine.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinase. Since Glutathione peroxidase contains selenocysteine and hence it is an antioxidant.

Impairments in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis and are associated with selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease).

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on antitubercular therapy. She returns 2 months later for a repeat check-up during which her urine pregnancy test turns out to be positive. She regularly takes oral contraceptive pills. Which of the following drugs might be implicated in contraception failure?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is likely implicated in the contraception failure of this patient. It might have increased the metabolism of OCPs and decreased its concentration needed for maintaining contraception.

Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, CYP2C19. As a result, it hastens the metabolism of its own and multiple other drugs including OCPs, steroids, HIV protease inhibitors, phenytoin which are metabolized by this microsomal enzyme.

A strategy to prevent failure of contraception in this case is, either to use higher estrogen-containing pills or to use other method of contraception.

Amongst rifamycins, the order of drug interactions is given as rifampicin> rifapentine> rifabutin. Hence, rifabutin is used when other drugs are used to decrease the likelihood of drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: Your senior resident while screening for cervical cancer in a 36-year-old female, advises for a  pap smear test. She asks you regarding the prerequisites of this test. Which of the following is not required in this case?

choices.text: A vaginal examination is required before taking a pap smear
The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test

questions.solution:
Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Pap smear should be done before performing a vaginal examination because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report.

Pap/ Papanicolaou test

  • It is a screening test only.
  • A positive test requires further evaluation - colposcopy, cervical biopsy, fractional curettage should be done.
  • It can be used for screening premalignant and malignant conditions and can also identify other local conditions.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • Ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have intercourse 24hr prior to the test.

Procedure

  • The patient is put in dorsal position & labia parted.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 1 or 2 glass slides.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

Ayres spatula:

  • One end is blunt and the other end is bifid.
  • Blunt end is used to take samples for vaginal cytology.
  • Bifid end is used to take Pap smear (from squamocolumnar junction, portion vaginalis of cervix)

Endocervical brush: to take endocervical sample.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient diagnosed with orbital varix was referred to an ophthalmologist for further management. During the ophthalmic workup of this patient,  you would notice _________
questions.solution:
The type of proptosis seen in the orbital varix is non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis.

Orbital varices:

  • They are venous malformations of the orbit caused by vascular dysgenesis.
  • Patients usually presents with non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis. On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully, hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, they regress on shifting to a non-dependent position.

Treatment:

  • Small lesions generally do not require treatment
  • Surgical excision is technically difficult and often incomplete because the lesions are friable and bleed easily; Specialized techniques such as embolization and carbon dioxide laser surgery may be helpful.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with a large, rapidly progressing abdominal mass, and ascites. He complains of night sweats and fatigue for 2 months. CT Scan of the abdomen shows a mesenteric enlargement of the abdomen. A lymph node biopsy is done, as shown below.  Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Increased MYC protein levels are seen in this condition
It can present with three distinct clinical forms
Characteristic "starry sky" pattern is seen in lymph node biopsy
Tumor cells are  negative for BCL6

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the lymph node biopsy are indicative of Burkitt lymphoma. Tumor cells are mature B cells that are positive for BCL6; hence, Option D is incorrect.

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the c-Myc gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14). (Option A )

It can occur in 3 forms which have distinct clinical characteristics:(Option B)

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. It can also spread to bone marrow and meninges.
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it has an abdominal presentation with massive disease, ascites, and renal, testis, and/or ovarian involvement. It can also spread to CNS and meninges.
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology: Tumor cells show round or oval nuclei, coarse chromatin, small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky). The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. These phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. (Option C)

The tumor cells are mature B cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin. (Option D)

Related Pearl: Burkitt's Lymphoma

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

 Parameter  Features
Genetic factors

Translocations - t(8;14), t(2;8), t(8,22)
Clinical types

Endemic - affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated

Sporadic - in adults in western countries 

Immunodeficiency associated - HIV infection
Clinical features

Peripheral lymphadenopathy

Intrabdominal mass

Rapid CNS metastasis 
Histology

Starry sky pattern

Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (due to rapid proliferation)
Immunophenotype

B cell-associated antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a)

Germinal center-associated markers (CD10 & BCL-6)

CD43, BCL-2 in up to 20% of cases

Expression of CD21 (the EBV/C3d receptor) depends on EBV status of the tumors:

  • Endemic type (EBV+) - CD21
  • Non-endemic type (EBV-) - lack CD21
 Treatment

Started immediately after diagnosis

Intensive chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
 Prognosis  Good - 70-80% cure rate

A variant of this condition with bone marrow involvement is called Burkitt's leukemia (ALL-L3). It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.

questions.text: All of the following serve as a landmark in the intra-op identification of facial nerve trunk by the anterograde method except:
questions.solution:
The parotid duct has the buccal branch of the facial nerve in close relation to it and can be used as a landmark for a retrograde method of facial nerve trunk location, not anterograde. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer: It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Squamotympanic fissure: It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process: The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
  • Mastoid process: Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch: It lies in relation to the parotid gland.
  • Marginal mandibular branch: It lies in relation to the facial vessels.
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with painless axillary lymphadenopathy. A lymph-node biopsy was done and histopathology revealed the following. Immunophenotyping revealed CD20+, BCL6+ ,CD15-  and CD30-. The findings are suggestive of which of the following subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with immunophenotype positive for CD20 & BCL6 and negative for CD15 and CD30, and the histopathology picture showing lymphohistiocytic variants of Reed Steenberg cell, also called popcorn cell, is characteristic of nodular lymphocyte-predominant subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

The nodular Lymphocyte predominance subtype is a non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma commonly seen in young males <35 years of age. Common presentations include cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy.

It is characterized by lymphohistiocytic variants with multilobed nuclei. They resemble popcorn kernels and are are positive for CD20 and BCL6 while negative for CD15 and CD30. 

The below histopathology image shows popcorn cells of NLPHL.

Hodgkin's lymphomas are a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising from a single or group of lymph nodes and can spread to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The distinctive feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells.

Reed-Stenberg cells are neoplastic cells derived from the germinal center or post–germinal center B cells. They appear as large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes. Each cell contains a large inclusion-like nucleolus and abundant cytoplasm.

WHO classifies Hodgkin's lymphoma into 5 subtypes:

  • Nodular sclerosis: Frequent lacunar cells
  • Mixed cellularity
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominance

The first 4 subtypes are considered classical Hodgkin's lymphoma. The RS cells are CD 15+ and CD30+. The lymphocyte predominant type is considered non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma with CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EB -. 

Other options: 

Option A: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype equally affecting young males and females. Histology shows frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells with the background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, plasma cells, and fibrous bands. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option B: Lymphocyte-rich is an uncommon subtype seen in older-aged adults with increased occurrence in males. Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells and background infiltrates rich in T lymphocytes are seen. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Option C: Lymphocyte depletion is an uncommon subtype seen in older men. A reticular variant is observed in this subtype with frequent diagnostic RS cells and a small amount of background reactive cells. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of Reichert cartilage?
questions.solution:
Tensor veli palatini is not a derivative of the Reichert cartilage/hyoid arch (second pharyngeal arch).

Tensor veli palatini is a derivative of the first arch.

The second pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles 
  • Posterior belly of digastric
