questions.text:
A 35-year-old female had recurrent abortions. On evaluation, she was diagnosed with APLA syndrome. Now she came with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days. She also had an episode of seizure. Her BP and temperature were higher than normal. What is the diagnosis and the investigation of choice respectively, for this condition?

APLA: antiphospholipid antibody
questions.solution:
A 35-year-old female who was diagnosed with APLA syndrome now presenting with complaints of severe headache for the past 2 days, an episode of seizure with BP and temperature higher than normal is suggestive of cortical vein thrombosis that is diagnosed by MR venography.

It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilias or antiphospholipid antibodies. Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom, neurological deficits are common, and up to a third of patients have convulsions.

Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and often in association with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressive swelling over the right upper leg associated with pain. His radiographic image is shown below. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which among the following is false?

choices.text: Radioisotope scan would show marked increase in activity
It is mostly seen on femoral or tibial metaphysis
The condition is a form of chronic osteomyelitis
Staphylococcus aureus would mostly be involved

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiographic image showing a lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim are suggestive of Brodie's abscess which is a form of subacute osteomyelitis, not a chronic form.

The patient is usually a child or adolescent, who would present with pain and swelling on the affected limb. The temperature, WBC counts, and blood cultures are usually normal, with sometimes elevated ESR. There is often very little to suggest an infection.

The radioisotope scan shows markedly increased activity. The organism mostly involved would be staphylococcus aureus.

It most commonly involves the metaphysis of the proximal tibia and distal femur. The patient presents with intermittent pain and tenderness in the affected area. A biopsy is often needed to confirm the diagnosis.

Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) IV for 4-5 days and followed by orally for another 6 weeks. The healing may take up to 12 months.

Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was diagnosed with a urogenital tumor. History revealed that the patient had cryptorchidism in his childhood. Which of the following tumors is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common cancer in patients who had cryptorchidism in childhood is seminoma.

The most common type of testicular cancer to develope in untreated undescended testes is seminoma. The cancer risk for adults who have history of cryptorchidism in childhood depends on the time of orchidopexy. 

  • Risk is 2-3 times greater if orchidopexy is done before puberty.
  • Risk is 5-10 times greater if orchidopexy is done after puberty.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT) (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: The given image shows the muscles present in the palmer aspect of the left hand. Which among the following is the nerve supply of the muscle marked as "A"?

choices.text: Superficial branch of the ulnar nerve

questions.solution:
The muscle marked as "A" in the above image is Abductor digiti minimi. It is innervated by the deep branch of ulnar nerve.

Abductor digiti minimi arises from the pisiform bone,the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris and the pisohamate ligament.

It is an abductor of the little finger. It plays an important role when the hand is grasping large objects with outspread fingers.

questions.text: In a modern sewage treatment plant, a light green oxidized flocculent material is formed after secondary treatment with the trickling filter method. This material is called as____.
questions.solution:
The light green oxidized sewage formed after secondary treatment (trickling filter method) is called humus. It is then led towards the secondary sedimentation.

Other options:

Option B- Sludge is the organic matter that settles down in the tank during the sedimentation step of the primary treatment of sewage.

Option C- The effluent, formed from the primary sedimentation tank, contains a proportion of organic matter in solution or colloidal state and numerous living organisms.

Option D-Sullage is the waste water that doesn't contain human excreta.

Related Pearl: Modern Sewage Treatment

Primary treatment:

  • Screening
    • A large metal screen is used to intercept large floating objects like dead animals, wood, rags, etc., so as to prevent clogging
  • Grit chamber
    • It is also called detritus chamber
    • It allows for the settlement of heavier solids like gravel or sand and permits the organic matter to flow through
    • The grit that is collected at the bottom is then disposed of
  • Primary sedimentation
    • In a primary sedimentation tank, sewage is allowed to flow slowly so that suspended matter that sediments form sludge which is then removed
    • Biological action takes place here and breaks down complex organic solids
    • Scum in the form of grease and fat collects on top of the tank
    • Sometimes, chemicals like lime are added to the effluent to enhance precipitation

Secondary treatment:

The effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation by trickling filter method or activated sludge process.

  • Trickling filter method
    • The trickling or percolating filter is a bed of crushed stones or clinker
    •  Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is spread over the filter bed and as it percolates through it, it gets oxidized by bacterial flora. There is no actual filtration that occurs.
    • The oxidized sewage forms a light green material called humus. It is then led into secondary sedimentation tanks.
  • Activated sludge process
    • The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tank
    • In these tanks, the effluent from primary sedimentation is mixed with activated or return sludge (sludge from the final settling tank) and is then exposed to aeration for 6 to 8 hours.
    • During aeration, organic matter is oxidized into carbon dioxide, nitrates and water with the help of aerobic bacteria in the activated sludge.
  • Secondary sedimentation
    • From the trickling filters or aeration tanks, the oxidized sewage is allowed into a secondary sedimentation tank where it is held for 2 – 3 hours
    • Here, aerated sludge or activated sludge is formed, part of which is pumped back into an aeration tank
  • Sludge digestion
    • Sludge digestion can be done by incubating it under favourable conditions to allow anaerobic auto-digestion. This is done in sludge digestion tanks.
    • Disposal of sludge is also done by sea disposal
    • Sludge can also be disposed of by composting with solid refuse
  • Disposal of effluent
    • Disposal of effluent can be done by dilution in water bodies which has to then be chlorinated
    • Disposal on land is possible if the effluent can be used for irrigation purposes

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with fever, lethargy, progressive sensorymotor polyneuropathy, back pain, and loss of libido. On examination,you notice generalised skin hyperpigmentation and hepatomegaly,splenomegaly and gynecomastia are present. Radiological imaging shows sclerotic bone lesions. Histopathological picture of the bone-marrow aspirate is given below. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The HPE image and the clinical features are suggestive of POEMS Syndrome. The image shows malignant plasma cells with a Mott cell, a plasma cell with intracytoplasmic Russell bodies (an eosinophilic uniformly staining membrane bound body which contains immunoglobulin).

POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin changes) syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic condition associated with a plasma-cell dyscrasia.

For diagnosis, all of the following four criteria must be met:

1)Polyneuropathy

2) Monoclonal plasma cell proliferative disorder

3)Any one of the following: 

  • Sclerotic bone lesions
  • Castleman’s disease
  • Elevated levels of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)

4) Any one of the following: 

  • Organomegaly (splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, or lymphadenopathy), 
  • Extravascular volume overload (edema, pleural effusion, or ascites),
  • Endocrinopathy (adrenal, thyroid, pituitary, gonadal, parathyroid, and pancreatic),
  • Skin changes (hyperpigmentation, hypertrichosis, glomeruloid hemangiomata, plethora, acrocyanosis, flushing, and white nails)
  • Papilledema
  • Thrombocytosis/polycythemia

Other options:

Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a malignancy of lymphoplasmacytoid cells that secrete IgM. It is also associated with lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly, but the major clinical manifestation is hyperviscosity syndrome.

Malignant and smouldering myeloma do not present with other features like organomegaly or endocrinopathy like POEMS syndrome.

questions.text: As a public health officer, you are evaluating the implementation of the expanded program on immunization (EPI) covering 9 diseases. You assess the proportion of infants in the community who are fully immunized under this program. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
The proportion of fully immunized infants against the 9 Expanded Program on Immunization (EPI) diseases is an example of utilization rates.

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who actually receive it in a given period. It gives an indication of the care needed and the health status of a population. The utilization rates are affected by the availability and accessibility of health services and public health awareness. 

The following are examples of utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of pregnant women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate (average daily in-patient census) at a healthcare facility 
  • Average length of stay at a hospital
  • Bed turnover ratio (discharges/average beds) at a hospital

Other options:

Option A: Health care delivery indicators reflect the provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country. Examples: Doctor- population ratio, Doctor-nurse ratio

Option B: Indicators of quality of life are difficult to define or measure. The physical quality of life index is an example that consolidates three indicators, i.e., infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy. 

Option D: Basic needs indicators are indicators involving "basic needs performance," i.e; calorie consumption, access to water, life expectancy, deaths due to disease, illiteracy, etc

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a remnant of the paramesonephric duct in males?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to you for a regular ANC check-up at her first trimester. She asks you to prescribe the regular medication given during pregnancy. According to Ministry of Health & Family Welfare (MoHFW), what is the timing to start prophylactic IFA supplementation and the duration for which it should be continued during the postpartum period?

choices.text: Starting from 3rd month and continued till 90 days of postpartum period
Starting from 4th month and continued till 180 days of postpartum period
Starting from 1st trimester and continued till 4 weeks of postpartum period
Starting from 4th month and continued till 9 weeks of postpartum period

questions.solution:
The guideline recommends prophylactic IFA supplementation should be given daily starting from the 4th month of pregnancy and continued throughout pregnancy and this must also be followed for 180 days postpartum.

Each tablet contains 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 μg of folic acid.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presenting with halitosis and regurgitation, underwent a barium swallow scan as shown below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition​?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with halitosis and regurgitation with the GIF of an X-ray showing the barium swallow filling a sac in the posterior pharyngeal wall is highly suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding thin-layer chromatography?

choices.text: It is based on polarity and most polar moves faster
It is based on polarity and Least polar moves faster
It is based on size and thinnest piece moves faster
It is based on size and thickest piece moves faster

questions.solution:
Thin-layer chromatography separates proteins based on their electrical polarity, and the least polar move the fastest.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: A surgical resident presents to you for advice regarding post-exposure prophylaxis after a needlestick injury from a hepatitis B patient. He had also suffered a similar injury in his internship following which he developed hepatitis B infection and was treated as per guidelines. What will you do now?

choices.text: Post exposure prophylaxis should not be given as vaccine would neutralize his immunity developed from past infection
No need of giving vaccine as it doesn't offer any protection in a previously infected individual
Full course of vaccination needs to be given irrespective of previous exposure
Giving antibodies to hepatitis B will suffice

questions.solution:
In an individual with hepatitis infection in past, vaccination does not confer any protection and need not be given.

Other options:

The vaccine does not harm the individual if it is given to an individual who was previously infected.

A full course of vaccination is given if no history of previous exposure to Hepatitis B is there.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presented with lethargy and myxedema. Her TSH levels are low. However, after administration of TRH, the TSH levels have increased. Which of the following conditions is most likely possible?

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to abnormality in pituitary gland
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in pituitary gland
Hyperthyroidism due to abnormality in hypothalamus
Hypothyroidism due to abnormality in hypothalamus

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of hypothyroidism due to abnormality in the hypothalamus.

Thyroid function is controlled by the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH, thyrotropin), which is secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary. The secretion of this hormone is stimulated by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. TSH secretion is also subject to negative feedback control by high circulating levels of thyroid hormones acting on the anterior pituitary and the hypothalamus.

Lethargy and myxedema are clinical features seen in hypothyroidism. The TSH levels may be low either due to abnormality in the pituitary gland or hypothalamus.

However, the response of pituitary gland to the administration of TRH, indicates that the pituitary gland is normal. This suggests that the reduced levels of TSH in this patient are due to the reduced TRH production due to abnormality in the hypothalamus. TSH levels may not be elevated following a test dose of TRH, in rare cases, where there is a depressed response of pituitary gland to TRH.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

questions.text: The resolving power of the given microscope is primarily limited by_____

choices.text: Stain used to visualise the object

questions.solution:
The resolving power of a light microscope, shown in the image, is limited by the wavelength of the light.

Resolving power is the ability to discriminate between 2 closely located objects. Human eye can discriminate 2 objects if they are 200micrometer apart. With a light microscope in the best possible magnification, the resolving power becomes 300nm (0.3 micrometer). In order to discriminate or delineate an object, it should have a minimum size of more than or equal to half the wavelength of light.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient had a stroke involving the medulla and pons, which led to the complete obliteration of the vagal input to the esophagus. Which of the following changes in esophageal peristalsis are likely to be seen after a few days?

choices.text: Elimination of primary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of secondary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of both primary and secondary esophageal peristalsis
No change in primary or secondary esophageal peristalsis

questions.solution:
The absence of vagal input to the esophagus will result in the elimination of only primary peristalsis of esophagus. The secondary peristalsis will remain intact due to the activity of the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus. Within a few days, the excitability of the myenteric plexus increases, resulting in strong secondary peristaltic waves.

There are two types of esophageal peristaltic movements: primary and secondary.

A. Primary peristalsis occurs as a continuation of the peristaltic wave that begins in the pharynx and spreads into the esophagus during the pharyngeal stage of swallowing. It passes from the pharynx to the esophagus, within about 8 to 10 seconds. However, due to the effect of gravity in an upright position, the food passes within 5 to 8 seconds.

B. Secondary peristalsis occurs if the primary peristaltic wave failed to empty the food from the esophagus into the stomach. Secondary peristalsis is initiated by the distension of the esophageal wall by the retained food. Waves continue until all the food is emptied into the stomach. Secondary peristaltic waves are initiated partly by intrinsic neural circuits in the myenteric nervous system and partly by reflexes that begin in the pharynx. 

Control of peristaltic waves: The musculature of the pharyngeal wall and upper third of the esophagus is striated muscle. These regions are controlled by skeletal nerve impulses from the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.

The musculature of the lower two-thirds of the esophagus is smooth muscle. This region is strongly controlled by the vagus nerves, which act through connections with the esophagal myenteric nervous system.

Effect of obliteration of vagal input to the esophagus: When the vagal nerves are cut, or the vagal input is obliterated by any other cause such as stroke, the primary peristalsis, solely dependent on the vagal innervation, is eliminated. 

However, the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus of the esophagus becomes excitable within days, causes strong secondary peristaltic waves. Therefore, even after paralysis of the brain stem swallowing reflex, food fed by a tube into the esophagus passes into the stomach due to the secondary peristaltic movements.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presented with itchy vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination revealed organisms as shown. Which of the following is true regarding the infection?

choices.text: The organism shows jerky motility with its 2 flagella
Presents as fishy odor and curdy precipitate
Green kit is used for syndromic treatment

questions.solution:
The above scenario of a patient with itchy vaginal discharge with the presence of flagellated trophozoites on microscopy indicated a diagnosis of trichomonas vaginalis. Green kit containing secnidazole is used for the syndrome treatment of trichomonas vaginalis.

Trichomonas is transmitted from person to person. Trophozoites are infective forms. They exhibit jerky motility by means of 5 flagella. It classically causes petechial hemorrhage and mucosal capillary dilatation giving a 'strawberry cervix' appearance.

Diagnosis can be established by a wet mount smear of vaginal discharge. In doubtful cases, culture can be done to establish the diagnosis.Treatment of trichomonas can be done with a Tablet Metronidazole or tinidazole 2gm single dose or secnidazole 1gm daily for 2 days. Partner treatment is required when symptomatic and sexual contact with an infected partner should be avoided.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient on oral contraceptives presented with abdominal pain and increasing abdominal girth for the past five days. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and ascites. A liver biopsy showed severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis and organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of hepatic vein thrombosis or Budd-Chiari syndrome.

Obstruction of the major hepatic veins due to thrombosis leads to a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome. It presents with a triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly and ascites. The damage to the hepatic tissue is a result of increased intrahepatic blood pressure. It principally affects young women with an underlying hypercoagulable state such as deficiency of protein C, S or anti-thrombin. Oral contraceptive intake increases the risk of hepatic vein thrombosis. Hepatic vein thrombosis is also associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms like polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Grossly the liver is swollen, red-purple in color and has a tense capsule. Microscopically, there may be areas of hemorrhage alternating with areas of preserved parenchyma. Centrilobular congestion and necrosis is seen. The major hepatic veins contain thrombi and they may get organized into the wall of the vessel.

Other options:

Option B: Metastatic liver disease - It typically presents with multiple liver lesions and is not associated with centrilobular congestion, organized thrombi in the major hepatic veins, or the clinical picture described in the scenario. 

Option C: Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is an autoimmune disease associated with inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It usually presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. 

Option D: Secondary biliary cirrhosis refers to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring, secondary to chronic obstruction of the extrahepatic bile ducts.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

questions.text: In the below-given project, which pathway if delayed causes a delay in the entire project?

choices.text: Start-->task A--> task D--> task E--> Finish
Start--> task B--> task C--> Finish

questions.solution:
Here the longest pathway is option C as it consists of (5+6)11 days, and so is the critical path.

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. The critical path method is a type of network technique. 

The other common type of network technique is the program evaluation and review technique. An arrow diagram that depicts the logical sequence of events that must take place is constructed. The time duration that can be allotted to each activity is easily calculated. This helps to minimize any delays in the implementation of the plan.

Other options:

Option A: It is only 2 days, so it cannot be the critical pathway.

Option B: It adds up to 10 days and therefore is not the critical pathway.

Option D: Although task D is the longest activity, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presented to a local clinic in her village with complaints of weakness, abdominal pain, and a weight loss of 10 Kgs during the past one month. Physical examination revealed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. She was referred to a tertiary center. However, the patient neglected and died after a few weeks. The autopsy of the liver is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows multiple nodular metastases, suggestive of metastatic malignancy of the liver.

Metastatic malignancy of the liver is more common than primary hepatic neoplasia. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas. However, primary malignancy from any organ may spread to the liver.

In most cases, multiple nodular metastases may be seen, causing hepatomegaly. The liver weight can exceed several kilograms. In some cases, a solitary metastatic nodule may be present, which can be surgically resected. Massive destruction of hepatocytes or direct obstruction of major bile ducts may cause jaundice.

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was one hour ago. What pattern of gastric mucosal injury would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The area marked in image 2 depicts the most likely pattern of gastric mucosal injury in this patient.

The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach. This is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place, in corrosive injury. 

In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus (image 3).

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presented with shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray revealed pulmonary metastases as shown in the image below. Which of the following primary tumours is most likely possible?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows numerous calcified pulmonary metastases, which is commonly seen usually due to osteosarcoma.

Pulmonary metastases usually occur from thee primary tumours involving the breast, GI tract, kidney, testes; head and neck tumours or bone and soft tissue sarcomas. The metastases may spread either through a haematogenous route (common) or a lymphatic and endobronchial route (rare).

Radiological features of pulmonary metastases:

 

A. Haematogenous metastases: They usually appear as multiple discrete pulmonary nodules measure up to a few cms in size.

Appearance:

  • The nodules are usually spherical, with a well-defined margin. However, an irregular edge may be seen with metastatic adenocarcinoma, and an ill-defined margin is suggestive of haemorrhage, classically choriocarcinoma (option a).
  • Cavitation of the pulmonary nodules may be seen with metastatic squamous carcinoma, such as carcinoma of the cervix (option c).
  • Calcification is rarely seen. If present, it is commonly due to osteosarcoma. Rarely, calcified deposits may be seen due to chondrosarcoma or mucinous adenocarcinoma.

Location:

  • Metastases are usually bilateral, and within the sub-pleural region, where the tumour cells are trapped in the smallest vessels.
  • The pulmonary nodules may be seen predominantly in the bases due to greater gravitational perfusion.
  • Presence of pneumothorax together with cavitation of subpleural metastases may occur due to a soft-tissue sarcoma (option d).

 

B. Endobronchial metastases:

  • They are rare and may occur due to primaries such as melanoma, renal, colorectal and breast carcinomas.
  • The metastases may appear as a hilar mass, with or without airway obstruction.

 

C. Miliary metastases:

  • They appear as multiple, small parenchymal nodules measuring approximately 2 mm in size, resembling 'millet seeds'.
  • They are rare and may be seen with thyroid and renal carcinomas.

 

D. Tumor emboli:

  • In rare cases, the tumour emboli may block pulmonary arteries leading to pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • It may occur in primaries such as hepatocellular carcinoma, or tumours involving breast, renal, stomach, prostate, or choriocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling is reducible in the neck and increases in size on coughing and performing the Valsalva maneuver. The given presentation is due to an enlarged diverticulum in ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests laryngocele, and it occurs due to the abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx).

Ventricle/Sinus of the larynx:

It is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds. The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane, which starts from the anterior part of the ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When abnormally enlarged and distended, the saccule may form a laryngocele—an air-containing sac that may present in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. Laryngocele in adults may be associated with carcinoma. 

CT scan helps in assessing the extent of the lesion.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization, and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

 

Other options:

Option A: The vestibule is the upper portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the laryngeal inlet and the vestibular folds. It is related to the posterior surface of epiglottis anteriorly, aryepiglottic folds laterally, and the anterior surface of arytenoids posteriorly.

Option C: The infraglottic larynx (subglottic space) is the lower portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. Histologically, it is the transition zone between the stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords and the respiratory epithelium of the trachea.

Option D: Rima glottidis (glottis) is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity measuring 24 mm in men and 16 mm in women anteroposteriorly. It is present between the two vocal cords. Anterior two-thirds of the glottis, known as phonatory glottis, is formed by membranous cords, while the posterior one-third, known as respiratory glottis, is formed by the vocal processes of arytenoids.

The image given below shows the glottis.

Related Pearl: Sites and subsites of the larynx (AJCC Classification)

Sites

Subsites

Supraglottis

Suprahyoid epiglottis

Infrahyoid epiglottis

Arytenoids

Aryepiglottic folds with the corniculate and cuneiform cartilages

False/Ventricular cords

Glottis

Subglottis

Image :  A top view of the larynx (seen with a mirror).

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with the rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. You also noticed Vogt’s striae on slit-lamp examination, along with Fleischer's rings. These Fleischer's rings are seen due to ______.

choices.text: Copper deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane
Iron deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient showing Vogt’s striae and Fleischer's rings on slit-lamp examination is suggestive of keratoconus.

Fleischer's rings occur due to the deposition of iron in the corneal epithelium. These are seen as brownish rings at the base of the cone of keratoconus, best seen under cobalt blue light.

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which central or paracentral corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism.

Other signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Vogt’s striae: Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane
  • Munson’s sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy

The image below shows Fleischer's ring (indicated by the arrow) under cobalt blue light:

 

Note: Kayser-Fleischer rings are caused by copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea and are indicative of Wilson's disease.

The image below shows Kayser-Fleischer ring:

questions.text: A 25-year-old female who received an MMR vaccination, mentions that she plans to conceive soon. What would you advise her regarding this?

choices.text: There is no contraindication for pregnancy
Not to become pregnant over the next 3 months
Not to become pregnant over the next 1 month
Not to become pregnant over the next 6 months

questions.solution:
The recipients of the MMR vaccine should be advised not to become pregnant over the next 1 month (4 weeks). 

Rubella vaccination is usually done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of rubella. It is usually administered in combination with measles and mumps as the measles, mumps, rubella vaccine (MMR) vaccine. After live vaccines such as MMR and varicella vaccinations, women are advised to avoid pregnancy for 1 month. They should not be given during pregnancy. 

Conditions that are seen if infection occurs in 1st trimester:

  • Abortions
  • Stillbirth
  • Skin lesions: Blueberry muffin lesions
  • Triad of congenital rubella syndrome
    • Sensorineural deafness
    • Congenital heart defects 
    • Cataracts

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with complaints of fever and fatigue for the past few weeks. Examination revealed hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Acute myeloid leukemia is a spectrum of hematological malignancies where poorly differentiated cells of the hematopoietic stem cells infiltrate the blood and bone marrow. They are the most common acute leukemias in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the progranulocytes. There is also presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Auer rods are predominantly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia which is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with t(15;17)(q22;11-12), which results in the formation of the fusion gene called PML-RARa. The condition is associated with a high incidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Treatment includes administration of all-trans retinoic acid.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphocytic leukemia present with a hypercellular marrow that is packed with lymphoblasts. These lymphoblasts, when compared to myeloblasts, have more condensed chromatin with less prominent nucleoli. Histochemichal staining show that lymphoblasts are myeloperoxidase-negative and often contain a periodic acid–Schiff–positive cytoplasm.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by scattered macrophages with green-blue colored cytoplasm called sea blue histiocytes. 

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia usually contain proliferation centers that are pathognomonic for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Smudge cells can also be seen. They are small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm that gets disrupted during the process of smearing.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of hypertension, presented with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed an aortic dissection involving only the descending thoracic aorta, not extending into the abdominal aorta. According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection is classified as ______.
questions.solution:
According to DeBakey's classification, the aortic dissection limited to the descending thoracic aorta is classified as DeBakey type IIIa.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear, which allows blood to penetrate into the medial layer, producing a cleavage plane (false lumen) between the inner two-thirds and outer one-third of the media. The true lumen is separated from the false lumen by an intimo-medial flap. It most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing chest/back pain. It is associated with diaphoresis. Other symptoms are syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.

On examination, there can be hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, findings of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological manifestations. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the extremities may be seen due to changes of flow in the true and false lumens. 

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

In hemodynamically stable patients, diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

The image given below shows aortic dissection in the thoracic aorta with the true lumen as well as the false lumen. The true lumen is often the smaller of the two because of being compressed by the false lumen.

The flowchart given below sums up the management algorithm for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with infertility, and a cervical mucus study was performed on the 24th day of her menstrual cycle (she has a regular 28 days cycle). Which of the following is not true regarding the interpretation of the findings shown in this test?

choices.text: This finding is due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus.
This phenomenon occurs under the influence of estrogen.
This test indicates that ovulation has occurred in this patient.
Corpus luteum is absent during this time of her cycle.

questions.solution:
The image shows a specimen of dried cervical mucus with ferning. It occurs under the influence of estrogen. The persistence of ferning beyond day 22 indicates anovulation. In this patient, ferning is present on the 24th day, which indicates that her cycles are anovulatory.

Fern test:

A drop of cervical mucus is spread and dried on a glass slide and observed under the low-power microscope. 

In the preovulatory (estrogenic) phase, a characteristic pattern of fern formation is observed due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus secreted under the estrogenic effect.

Following ovulation, ferning disappears due to progesterone activity. The disappearance of ferning is presumptive evidence of corpus luteum activity.

Insler devised a scoring system by just taking into account various properties of cervical mucus such as amount, ferning, and viscosity as an inexpensive test of ovulation.

questions.text: A child presents at 6 weeks of age for vaccination and the clinician decides to give a combination vaccine of diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus toxoid. How does this affect the body's immune response against tetanus toxoid compared to if it was given alone?

choices.text: Remains the same whether given alone or in combination as DTP
Decreases as the immune system is divided to make antibodies against 3 antigens instead of one
Increases as multiple antigens increases the immune response

questions.solution:
The immune response against the tetanus toxoid increases if given as a combination of DTP when compared to given singly.

Since this vaccine is given for the first time, the response to tetanus toxoid would be enhanced. If it was given to an older child with a history of other vaccinations, immune response would differ.

The immune response is variable in response to multiple antigens depending on the antigenic competition.

  • If 2 bacterial vaccines (say cholera and typhoid) are given, antibodies are produced as if they are given separately.
  • If 2 toxoids (say tetanus and diphtheria) are given with one in excess, the antibody response to the other is diminished
  • If a toxoid is given with a bacterial vaccine (say DTP vaccine), the antibody response to the toxoid is potentiated
  • If a toxoid is administered earlier (say diphtheria toxoid), and then later given as a triple vaccine (DTP), the antibody response to the pertussis and tetanus antigens will be diminished.

Other factors may also play a role in antibody response:

  • Size and number of doses - a minimum critical dose is required, to elicit a response against an antigen. It increases with an increase in dose, up to a certain point, after which it rather induces tolerance.
  • Route of administration- parenteral route induces a better antibody response compared to the oral or nasal route.
