questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a high fever, vomiting, and an episode of seizure that lasted for 2 minutes. She appears confused and is unable to answer questions properly. Her medical history is significant and an image of her thyroid scan is given below. Her family members also tell you that for the past few days she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. What is the most appropriate management for this patient, in addition to supportive care?

choices.text: Levothyroxine (T4) single IV bolus of 500 μg

questions.solution:
The thyroid scan shows diffusely increased uptake suggestive of Grave’s disease. This patient has Graves disease and an acute infection, now presents with high fever, vomiting, one seizure and confusion. This is suggestive of thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crises. Management includes supportive measures and large doses of propylthiouracil (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) given orally or via an NG tube and propranolol (60–80 mg PO every 4 h; or 2 mg IV every 4 h). 

Other options:

Methimazole is used if propylthiouracil is not available. Although identificantion and treatment of the precipitaing factor is important, antibiotics and propranolol alone are not enough - anti-thyroid drugs should be given. 

Levothyroxine (T4) is used for the treatment of Myxedema coma and can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 μg. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding AGEs (Advanced Glycation End Products) seen in diabetes?

choices.text: Formed as a result of enzymatic attachment of glucose residue to amino acids in proteins
Formation of AGE products is independent of blood glucose level
Increased pro coagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages
Implicated only in diabetic microvascular complications

questions.solution:
Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages is one of the detrimental effects of the AGE products within the vascular compartment. 

Advanced Glycation End-products (AGEs) are formed as a result of nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose- derived dicarbonyl precursors with the amino groups of both intracellular and extracellular proteins.

AGEs bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that is expressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smooth muscle. The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signaling axis within the vascular compartment include:

  • The release of cytokines and growth factors, including transforming growth factor β (TGFβ), which leads to deposition of excess basement membrane material.

  • Generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in endothelial cells

  • Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages

  • Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrix.

AGE products formation increases with increases in blood glucose level due to poor glycemic control. This fact is used to measure glycated hemoglobin as a marker of diabetes severity. It is implicated in both microvascular and macrovascular complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the triangle of doom?

choices.text: The apex is at the deep inguinal ring
Lateral border is formed by vas deferens
Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is also a content

questions.solution:
Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection
  • Apex is at the deep inguinal ring

The contents of the triangle of doom include

  1. External iliac vessels
  2. Deep circumflex iliac vein
  3. Femoral nerve
  4. Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Surgical importance of triangle of doom: Staples and sutures to fix the mesh in hernioplasty are avoided in this space , to avoid injury to the external iliac vessels and the femoral nerve.

Note:

Myopectineal orifice is an Osseo-Myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel all groin hernias occur.

It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and a yellow, friable, hemorrhagic, solid mass was removed. The histopathological slide from this specimen is given below. What is the likely finding shown in this image?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies is suggestive of a Yolk sac tumor. It is also called a Endodermal sinus tumor.

It is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It occurs in ovaries or testes and sacrococcygeal areas in young children.  On appearance, these tumors are yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. 

50% of the tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic when present.  This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

Krukenberg tumor: Numerous signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. It is the carcinoma of the stomach metastasized to the ovary.

The tumor is thought to spread via 1 of the 3 mechanisms:

  • The lymphatic system,
  • The hematogenous system, or
  • The transcoelomic pathway

It is usually bilateral, has a smooth surface, retains the shape of a normal ovary and has waxy consistency.

The image below shows the presence of Call Exner’s seen in Granulosa cell tumor:

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A  first-born, 5-weeks-old male infant presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. Which of the following will be the preferred investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. First-born male infants are at the highest risk.

Infants usually present with 

  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction, most commonly between 3 and 6 weeks of age.
  • Olive-shaped mass palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
  • Visible peristalsis after feeding, moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Metabolic abnormalities include hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm.

Ultrasound signs seen in Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis are:

  • Target sign (Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa)
  • Cervix sign
  • Nipple sign.
  • Antral nipple sign

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

The ultrasound image given above shows hypertrophied pylorus resembling that of the uterine cervix (cervix sign) and double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach, (Nipple sign).

The ultrasound image given above shows redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the antrum - Antral nipple sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A resident asks you to assist while performing an e-FAST on a patient with multiple rib injuries due to an RTA. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium are assessed
It is reliable in detecting even less than 100 mL of free blood
It is unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
e-FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.

e-FAST (extended-focused assessment with sonography for trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Disadvantages:

  • It is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.
  • Does not directly identify injury to the hollow viscus.
  • Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma.
  • It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

If there is a doubt, eFAST may be repeated or supplemented with other investigations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primi in her 27th week of gestation is advised the two-step approach and takes the glucose challenge test (GCT) for screening gestational diabetes mellitus. Which of the following option indicate the correct step performed while doing glucose challenge test (GCT)?

choices.text: Patient is asked to take 100gm of oral glucose
Patient is asked to take 50gm of oral glucose
Patient is asked to take 50gm followed by 75gm of oral glucose
Patient is asked to take 75gm followed by 50 gm of oral glucose

questions.solution:
The patient is asked to take a 50gm of oral glucose for performing the glucose challenge test (GCT).

Two-step approach: The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). In the second step, the patients who meet the threshold value in OGCT are subjected to 100gm three hours OGTT, which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

Glucose challenge test:

  • Procedure: The patient is asked to take 50gm of oral glucose and Venous plasma glucose is measured one hour later.
  • Cut off values: OGCT values of ≥140mg/dl is taken as a cut-off value for doing OGTT.

Glucose tolerance test:

  • Patients who meet the threshold value in GCT are subjected to 100gm three hour OGTT for the diagnosis of GDM.

Note :

The one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presented with a 5-day history of severe, sharp, and constant abdominal pain. An ultrasound scan showed a healthy fetus and several large fibroids. A subsequent MRI revealed changes in the fibroid as given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The fibroid has a purple red colour and a fishy odour.
This degeneration has a "womb-stones’ in graveyards" appearance.
Appendicitis in pregnancy is an important differential diagnosis
It is managed conservatively with analgesics.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. The "womb-stones’ in graveyards" appearance is seen calcareous degeneration, due to the deposition of phosphates and carbonates of lime.

Red degeneration is a complication (secondary change) of fibroids that often develop during pregnancy or over the age of 40. The myoma becomes tense and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple red colour and a fishy odour.

It needs to be differentiated from appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis and accidental haemorrhage.

It is managed conservatively with analgesics.

Myomectomy at caesarean section carries the risk of uncontrolled bleeding and hence is not done except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid.

Hyaline degeneration is the most common type of secondary change whereas sarcomatous change is the least common.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents at 34 weeks of gestation with bleeding per vaginum (PV). The bleeding was bright red, painless, spontaneous, and minimal. She had 3-4 episodes of spotting during this pregnancy, which resolved on their own and she was advised bed rest for this condition.  On examination, her vitals were stable and the fetal heart rate is 144 beats/min.  According to Macafee and Johnson's, what will be the management in this case regarding the termination of pregnancy?

choices.text: Give corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity
Immediate termination irrespective of gestational age

questions.solution:
This woman’s history is suggestive of placenta previa. Mcafee and Johnson's expectant management in case of placenta previa advocates termination of pregnancy at 37 weeks.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Placenta previa and abruptio placenta together account for 70% of the cases of antepartum hemorrhage.

 In Placenta previa the classic presentation is painless, bright red vaginal bleeding that often stops spontaneously and then recurs with labor. The bleeding most likely occurs in 3rd trimester and does not lead to a shock-like condition.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites:

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health(Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk
    • Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He had sustained a pelvic fracture and injured his perineum and is unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the meatus and on digital rectal examination, there is a high-riding prostate. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The site of injury, in this case, is the membranous urethra.

Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture. Pelvic fracture is most commonly caused by road traffic accident. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and on digital rectal examination, there will be a high riding prostate called as vermooten sign . Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum and pubic area is commonly associated.

Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. 

Management is by inserting a suprapubic catheter. If there is an associated bladder rupture, the bladder will not be seen on the ultrasound, and management in such a case is by exploration, repair, and placement of a suprapubic catheter.

Other options:

Option A: Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to straddle injury (cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents). Clinical features include perineal bruising, butterfly hematoma, bleeding from urethral meatus, and retention of urine is present.

Option C: Penile urethral injury is a type of distal urethral injury caused due to straddle injury. Clinical features are same as bulbar urethral injury. 

Option D: Urinary bladder rupture can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

questions.text: Complement fixation can be done by all of the antibodies except:
questions.solution:
Complement fixation cannot be done by IgG4.

Complement cannot bind to the antigen directly. It binds once the antibody fixes or activates it. The actual binding of the complement on antibody occurs on the Fc portion of the Ig molecule.

Compliment fixation involves IgM, IgG3, IgG1, and IgG2 in this order. IgG4, IgA, IgD, and IgE cannot fix complement.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department one hour after the spillage of hot oil on his hands while cooking. On examination, multiple burn injuries are present on his right hand as shown in the image. The injuries are extremely painful when touched with gloves and the capillary refilling is normal.  Which layers of skin are involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The degree of burns is second-degree superficial burn. The points that favor the diagnosis are the presence of multiple blisters, tenderness over the injured skin, and the normal capillary refilling time. Epidermis and papillary dermis (the upper part of the dermis) are involved in this case.

According to the depth and the extent of tissue damage, burn injuries can be classified as follows:

  • First degree burns: In this, there is damage to the epidermis. These injuries are extremely painful but do not blister. They have a normal capillary refilling time.
  • Second-degree burns (Partial-thickness burns): In this, there is damage to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the extent of the dermal involvement, they can further be divided as superficial or deep.
    • Superficial partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and upper part of the dermis (papillary). These injuries are red, moist, extremely painful and blisters are present. The capillary return is clearly visible when the injured skin is blanched.
    • Deep partial-thickness burns: They involve the epidermis and the deeper dermis. These injuries are less painful and some sensation is preserved. The capillaries do not blanch on pressure.
  • Third-degree burns:  In this degree, there is damage to the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous tissue. The injuries have a hard leathery feel with the absence of sensation.
  • Fourth-degree burns: In this degree, there is damage to the underlying soft tissues.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female comes to the PHC where she is prescribed the contraceptive pill strip shown in the image below. What is the mechanism of action of this form of contraception?

choices.text: Prevents ovulation by preventing LH surge
Spermicidal action on the uterine cavity
Prevents fertilization by decreasing sperm motility

questions.solution:
The contraceptive pill which the woman has is Chhaya which has 30 mg of centchroman. Centchroman is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive which does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

It is started on the first day of menses and taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter.

To begin the use of Chhaya, the woman is advised to take the first pill on the first day of the period and the second pill three days later. This pattern of days is repeated throughout the first 3 months. Starting from the fourth month, the pill is to be taken once a week on the first pill day and should be continued on the weekly schedule regardless of her menstrual cycle.

Effects:

  • It does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.
  • It exhibits a strong antiestrogenic and a weak oestrogenic action peripherally at the receptor level
  • The return of fertility occurs soon after stoppage of the drug (within 6 months)

Centchroman is not teratogenic or carcinogenic, exerts no pharmacological effect on other organs. The drug can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 h of coitus (two tablets repeated 12 h later with a failure rate of 1%). 

Side effects include Gain in weight, some delay in the return of fertility (up to 6 months). It does not protect against HIV and STD. Prolonged use can result in hyperplasia and atypical endometrium.

Contraindications includes PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, allergy to the drug.

Update: Saheli is renamed as Chhaya and is now available in two packages: ASHA supply (for home distribution) and free supply (for distribution at health facilities).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about positron emission tomography-computed tomography(PET-CT)?

choices.text: Enhanced whole body CT is followed by whole body PET imaging
It combines cross sectional anatomic information with metabolic information
Imaging is done after administration of oral glucose solution
Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging

questions.solution:
Oral glucose solution is not given prior to PET-CT. Blood glucose should be in the normal range as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose. For this reason, the patient is asked to fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium are optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man working in the ship repair industry presents with a gradually progressive cough and difficulty in breathing. The flow-volume curve after spirometry in the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Pink line - Patient's response
Green dashed lines - Normal response
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 48-year-old patient working in a ship repair industry with a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve is asbestosis. Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The flow-volume curve of the above (patient 1) shows decreased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease. Airflow is greater than normal at comparable lung volumes because the increased elastic recoil of the lungs holds the airways open.

Asthma, COPD, emphysema, and endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow patterns. Although all airflow is diminished, expiratory prolongation predominates, and mean expiratory flow < mean inspiratory flow. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity, and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to the left.

Vocal cord paralysis causes a variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction in which only the inspiratory curve would be flattened.

 

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung directly related to the intensity and duration of exposure. 

Asbestos fibers induce oxidative injury due to the generation of reactive oxygen species by the transition metals on the surface of the fibers as well as from cells engaged in phagocytosis. These mechanisms result in lung fibrosis.

Irregular or linear opacities initially in the lower lung fields are the hallmark of asbestosis in chest radiographs. A ground glass appearance in the lung fields may be seen.

The chest X-ray below shows bilateral calcified pleural plaques consistent with asbestos-related pleural disease:

 

No specific therapy is available for asbestosis. They are managed with supportive therapy. The most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure is lung cancer. Pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma are also associated with asbestos exposure. 

Other options:

Options A and B: Emphysema and asthma are obstructive lung disorders. In these conditions, the flow-volume loop would be a scooped-out curve.

Option D: Vocal cord paralysis causes variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction. The flow-volume loop would have a flat inspiratory curve.

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

PFT

Obstructive disease

Restrictive disease

FVC

Decreased

Decreased (<80% predicted)

FEV1

Decreased (<80% predicted)

 Decreased

FEV1% (FEV1/FVC)

Decreased (<0.7)

Normal/ increased (>0.7)

FEF 25-75

<50% predicted

Normal/ decreased

TLC

Normal/ increased

Decreased

RV

Increased

Decreased

DLCO
  • Normal or increased in asthma
  • Decreased in emphysema
  • Decreased in intrinsic restrictive disease
  • Normal in neuromuscular or musculoskeletal restrictive disease

FVC: Forced Vital Capacity

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FEF 25-75: Forced expiratory flow at 25-75% vital capacity

TLC: Total lung capacity

RV: Residual volume

DLCO: Diffusion capacity of lung for Carbon monoxide.

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: In a 35-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident with facial injuries, radiological investigations show a complete separation between the facial bones and the cranial bones. What type of Le-Fort's classification is associated with this pattern of injury?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing complete separation of facial and cranial bones is suggestive of Le-Fort III maxillary fracture. It signifies craniofacial disjunction.

Clinical features include malocclusion of teeth, elongation of the midface, mobility in the maxilla, and CSF rhinorrhoea.

Diagnosis is made with x-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan.

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort III fracture.

 

The image below shows the fracture line in Le-Fort I fracture.

The image below shows the fracture line in the Le-Fort II fracture.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: In developing countries like India, most children would have acquired their first episode of rotavirus diarrhea before the age of:
questions.solution:
In developing countries, 75% of the children acquire their episode of first rotavirus diarrhea before the age of 12 months. In developed countries, the first episode is delayed until the age of 2-5 years.

Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is most often seen in children aged 6-24 months.

Rotavirus is the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhea in children aged <5 years globally. 

The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows the clean water supply and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission. In tropical areas, rotavirus diarrhea occurs throughout the year.

Transmission primarily occurs through the fecal-oral route, person-to-person contact, or indirectly through fomites. Infected individuals shed very high concentrations of the virus (>1012 particles/gram) for many days in their stool and vomit.

Note: Bacterial pathogens causing acute diarrhoeal disease in children are enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), campylobacter jejuni, shigella, and vibrio cholerae 01.

questions.text: You are planning to enroll yourself in the Vandematharam scheme. Which among the following points is not true regarding this scheme?

choices.text: You can provide safe abortion services at your clinic
You, as an MBBS doctor, can also volunteer for this service
You will display 'Vandemataram logo' at your clinic
You can prescribe Iron and Folic Acid tablets, OC pills etc. for free

questions.solution:
Vandematharam scheme is a voluntary scheme for providing safe motherhood services.

  • Can be volunteered by an OBG specialist, maternity home, nursing home, lady doctor/ MBBS doctor.
  • IFA tablets, OC pills, and TT injections will be provided by the respective DMO to the Vandematharam doctors/ clinics for free distribution to beneficiaries.
  • Cases needing special care and treatment can be referred to government hospitals.

Vande Mataram scheme is expected to improve the access of pregnant women to antenatal check-up and reduce maternal and neonatal deaths.

11th of April is being observed as the National Safe Motherhood Day.

questions.text: While assisting in an amputation procedure during your orthopedics rotation, you notice the surgeon vertically sections the calcaneum, and removes its anterior part. He rotates the remaining posterior part along with the heel flap about 90 degrees forward and upward so that it comes in contact with the denuded distal end of the tibia. As he is about to close, he asks you the eponymous name of the procedure you just assisted. You would answer as:
questions.solution:
The ankle amputation described above as an arthrodesis made between the tibia and a part of the calcaneum is called Pirogoff's amputation.

Related Pearl: List of Names of Amputations and Their Levels

TYPE 

LEVEL OF AMPUTATION 

Lisfranc

Tarsometatarsal joint 

Chopart 

Transverse tarsal joints (articulation of calcaneus with cuboid and talus with navicular)

Pirogoff

Calcaneum is rotated forward to be fused with tibia after vertical section through its middle 

Syme 

Distal tibia & fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. Involves removal of both medial and lateral malleoli.

Boyd 

Talectomy, forward shift of the calcaneus and calcaneo-tibial arthrodesis 

Sarmiento 

Distal tibia and fibula: 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of medial and lateral malleoli

questions.text: An oncologist plans to use a pyrimidine analog for a patient with acute myeloid leukemia. Which of the following drugs will he choose?
questions.solution:
Cytarabine is a pyrimidine analogue. Rest all given options are purine analogues.

Cytarabine (cytosine arabinoside) is the single most useful drug in AML and is used to induce remission in AML. It is also used in pediatric ALL.

Other options:

Cladribine is a derivative of deoxyadenosine. Used in Hairy cell leukemia and CLL.

Fludarabine is a derivative of Vidarabine (arabinofuranosyl adenine) and used in CLL and as an immunosuppressant.

Nelarabine is a derivative of guanine and used in T-cell leukemia.

Related Pearl: Classification of antineoplastic drugs

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient previously treated for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with similar symptoms. Radio-imaging confirms a recurrence with an inaccessible intracranial extension. Which of the following treatment approaches is considered now?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is considered for recurrent inaccessible juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

JNA is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with:

  • Epistaxis (most common presentation): Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous
  • Mass: A mass may be present in either the postnasal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed.
  • Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves: May occur

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

 

Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery or radiotherapy when the tumor is inaccessible.

Other options:

Option A: Hormonal therapy can be used as primary or adjunctive treatment. Since it is commoner in adolescent males in their twenties, the tumor may be testosterone dependant. Therefore, hormonal therapy with diethylstilbestrol and an androgen blocker like flutamide may be considered.

Option B: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option C: Endoscopic approach is not useful as the stem clearly mentions that the tumor is inaccessible.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female is started on mechanical ventilation after presenting with acute respiratory failure.  The ventilator is set to deliver a tidal volume of 500 mL at a frequency of 10 times per minute. After transferring the patient to ICU, the physician increased the tidal volume to 600 mL without changing the respiratory rate. Considering that the patient's V ̇ /Q ̇ is normal, which of the following changes would you expect?
questions.solution:
Increase in tidal volume causes decreased dead space fraction.

Dead space fraction refers to the fraction of each breath occupied by the anatomical dead space. The alveolar ventilation can be increased by increasing either the tidal volume or respiratory frequency or both.

Dead space fraction = Anatomical dead space / tidal volume.

When the tidal volume alone is increased, without increasing the respiratory rate, the volume of air inhaled with each breath is increased. However, since anatomical dead space remains the same, the dead space fraction is reduced.

If the respiratory rate alone is increased, without a change in tidal volume, then alveolar ventilation increases. However, since both tidal volume and anatomical dead space remain the same, there is no change in dead space fraction.

Other options:

  • Option a: Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of all the space of the respiratory system other than the alveoli, that do not participate in gas exchange. The anatomical dead space is not altered with a change in ventilation.
  • Option b: Alveolar dead space refers to the volume of gas in the alveoli that does not equilibrate with the blood, as in patients with poor perfusion. However, in the given case, the patient has a normal ventilation-perfusion ratio. Therefore, there is no change in alveolar dead space.
  • Option c: Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space. In the given case, physiological dead space remains unaltered.

questions.text: Few residents of a village presented with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the last couple of months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination, some had hepatosplenomegaly. Most of them complained that they suffered bites from insects similar to the one shown below. Which of the following tests would help in surveillance in their area for the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image of a sandfly, suggests the diagnosis of leishmaniasis. Aldehyde test of Napier is used widely for surveillance of leishmaniasis.

The Aldehyde test of Napier is done by taking 1 to 2 ml of serum from a case of kala-azar and a drop or 2-40% formalin is added. A positive test shows jellification to milk-white opacity. If it occurs within 2 to 20 minutes, it is said to be strongly positive. If it occurs after 30 minutes, it is not significant. This test is widely used for surveillance because it is a simple test, not used for diagnosis as it is not-specific.

The rapid dipstick test has become the mainstay in the serological diagnosis of Kala Azar (Visceral leishmaniasis) and is the method of choice for the diagnosis of the disease.

 Leishmaniasis:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis – (Kala-azar) – L.donovani
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis – (Oriental sore) – L.tropica
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis = L.braziliensis
  • Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis - L.donovani

Kala Azar is endemic in 54 districts in India, in the states of Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal, and Uttar Pradesh.

Indian Kala Azar: Reservoir –man

Vector – Phlebotomus: sandfly

Incubation period – 10 days to 2 years

Extrinsic incubation period – 6 to 9 days

Laboratory diagnosis of Kala Azar:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies- confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Recent update: DOC in Kala Azar control programs:

  • The national control programs in India utilize single-dose liposomal amphotericin B (10 mg/kg intravenous [IV] infusion) as the first-line treatment. 
  • A combination regimen (Injection Paromomycin - Miltefosine for 10 days) is also recommended.
  • High-level resistance to antimonial drugs sodium stibogluconate (SSG) is seen and monotherapy with antimonial agents is no longer a first-line treatment for VL when other less toxic drugs are available, hence it is not used now.
  • Synthetic Pyrethroid is used for indoor residual spraying, in all the endemic areas.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old diabetic and hypertensive patient with an average BP of 150/90 mmHg had a transient ischemic attack that lasted for 30 minutes. His speech was slurred, but there was no motor weakness in his limbs. Calculate the ABCD2 score for this patient to determine the risk of developing a stroke in the future.
questions.solution:
The ABCD2 score for this patient is 5. The risk factors contributing to the score are as follows.

  • Age >60 years - 1 point
  • Systolic blood pressure >140 mmHg - 1 point
  • Slurred speech without motor weakness - 1 point
  • Duration of 30 min - 1 point
  • Diabetes - 1 point

The total score adds up to 5 points which suggests a 12% risk of developing a stroke in the next 3 months.

The ABCD2 score is used to calculate the risk of stroke after transient ischemic attack (TIA). TIA is defined as episodes of stroke symptoms that last for only a brief period of time (<24 hours) and most often <1 hour.

Related Pearl: ABCD2 Score

The risk of stroke following TIAs is determined by ABCD2 score:

Risk factors Score
Age > 60  1
SBP>140 mmHg or DBP >90 mmHg 1
Clinical symptoms:
  • Unilateral weakness
 2
  • Speech disturbances without weakness
 1
Duration:
  • >60 minutes
 2
  • 10 - 59 minutes
 1
Diabetes 1
Total score Sum each score
ABCD2 Score Total 3-months Rate of stroke (%)
0 0
1 2
2 3
3 3
4 8
5 12
6 17
7 22

questions.text: You have been asked to perform fundoscopy by your senior resident in one of his patients diagnosed with hypermetropia. Which of the following options represent the findings that could be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis can be seen on fundal examination of the hypermetropic eye.

Hypermetropia is a refractive error of the eye in which parallel rays of light from infinity focus behind the retina when accommodation is at rest. Fundoscopy findings in hypermetropia include shot silk appearance (retina may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections) and pseudopapillitis (optic disc is small, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins without disc edema).

Other signs of hypermetropia include small eyeball, small cornea and short anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

questions.text: Select the pharmacologically correct usage of the following anti-microbials________.

choices.text: Lopinavir boosted with ritonavir used to increase the drug permeability into virus
Aminoglycosides given in small divided doses to decrease the nephrotoxicity
Ceftriaxone used with less frequent dosing because of longer t1/2
Penicillin given as single undivided doses to increase the microbial killing

questions.solution:
Ceftriaxone has a longer t/12, hence dose frequency can be decreased (OD dosing) while still maintaining the drug concentration and time-dependent killing.

Lopinavir boosted with ritonavir increases the duration of action of Lopinavir. This is because ritonavir inhibits the CYP3A4 enzyme which metabolizes Lopinavir.

Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect. Peak concentration above MIC(Minimum Inhibitory Concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for its antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property. (option B)

Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of the drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins and 5-fluorocytosine have this property (Options D).

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presented to an ART clinic with the complaint of primary infertility despite trying to conceive for 10 years. You prescribe her a series of tests to rule out premature ovarian failure. Which of the following values is incorrect regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: Day 3 serum FSH should be 10–15 IU/L or more
Day 3 serum Estradiol should be 60–80 pg/mL or less

questions.solution:
For the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure, the LH levels should be <10 IU/L.

Causes of premature ovarian failure:

  • Defective migration of premature eggs from the yolk sac during embryogenesis.
  • Early or increased apoptosis of eggs.
  • Radiotherapy
  • Hysterectomy—deprives blood supply to the ovaries (by causing kinking or obliteration)
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation

Diagnosis of premature ovarian failure:

  • Day 3 serum FSH should be 10–15 IU/L or more for the diagnosis.
  • LH <10 IU/L 
  • Day 3 serum E2 should be 60–80 pg/mL or less.
  • Anti-Müllerian hormone is low (normal 0.2–0.7 ng/mL)
  • Inhibin B is low <40 pg/mL.
  • Antral follicular count measuring 2–9 mm in both the ovaries and number of follicles and size. Count less than 4–5 on day 2–5 denotes poor response to hormones.
  • Ultrasound ovarian volume should be low
  • Progesterone on 21st/22nd day should be >15 ng/mL.

questions.text:
A newborn with a family history of hearing loss was subjected to BERA testing. The waves produced were as shown below. Wave III in the following image represents activity in which of the following?

BERA - Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry
questions.solution:
Wave III in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is due to the neural activity of the cochlear nucleus.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A lady comes to the police with a complaint against a particular man for non-consensual anal penile penetration. On examination, the man was found to be a Hijrah. What is true regarding the given case?

choices.text: On examination the anal canal would be dilated and tender to touch
Anal sex in this case can be confirmed by presence of semen in anal canal
The man is punishable under the provisions of rape
The man is not guilty as he is a hijrah with absence of male genitalia

questions.solution:
As per the given clinical scenario, it is less likely that the anal penile penetration is performed by a hijrah with the absence of male genitalia.

The lady in the question is accusing the other person of non-consensual anal penile penetration i.e., she is claiming that the other person inserted penis in her anal orifice. For this to happen, the other person needs to have a penis, which on examination was found to be absent as he is a hijrah.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD with a history of a lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with the following appearance and no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump shows increased stromal cellularity and typical leaflike architecture. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor or cystosarcoma phyllodes of the breast.

Phyllodes tumor, also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes, presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and tense due to swelling. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition.

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of the low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors, and malignant type- Mastectomy

The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of a phyllodes tumor.

 

Other options:

Giant fibroadenomas are usually seen in the early reproductive years. These are benign solid encapsulated tumors. It is a slow-growing tumor and presents as a painless lump in the breast.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The pathologic hallmark of inflammatory cancer is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics. Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Patients with inflammatory carcinoma usually have a history revealing the rapid onset of the disease with progression over weeks to 3 months.

The hallmark of inflammatory breast cancer is diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatic channels within the breast and overlying skin, often without an underlying tumor mass. Inflammatory breast cancer manifests clinically as erythema, edema, and warmth of the breast as a result of lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: The muscle marked as 'X' in the image below inserts at ________

choices.text: Lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus
Medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus

questions.solution:
The muscle in the given image is teres major, its insertion is at the medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus.

The muscle in the image can be identified as teres major as it originates from the posterior surface of the inferior angle of the scapula. In relation to the infraspinatus muscle which arises from the posterior surface of the scapula, below the spine.

  • It arises from the dorsal surface of the inferior scapular angle.
  • The fibres of the muscle ascend laterally and get attached to the medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus in the humerus.
  • It is supplied by the lower subscapular nerve which branches out from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

 

The floor of the intertubercular sulcus  - Site of insertion of Lattisimus Dorsi

The medial lip of the intertubercular sulcus - Site of insertion of Teres major

The lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus - Site of insertion of pectoralis major

(remembered by “Lady between two majors”, i.e - Lattisimus Dorsi between pectoralis major and teres major)

Coracoid process of the scapula - site of insertion of pectoralis minor.

questions.text: You are examining the injuries in a suspected case of homicide. The shape of the stab wound that you notice is depicted in the image below. What type of weapon might have caused this injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a wedge-shaped wound, which is caused by injury with a single-edged knife.

A stab wound occurs when the force is applied into the depths of the body, along the long axis of narrow or pointed weapons like knives, daggers, swords, etc. The depth of the stab wound is more than its length and width.

The size and shape of a stab wound depend on the weapon, the body part that is stabbed, the depth of insertion, angle of withdrawal, the direction of thrust, and the condition of tension or relaxation of the skin. 

The shape of the wound usually corresponds to the weapon used, but the shape of the wounds made by the same weapon may differ on different parts of the body. 

Single-edged weapons cause triangular or wedge-shaped wounds. One angle of the wound will be sharp, while the other will be rounded, blunt, or squared off. If the back edge of the blade is stout, small splits in the skin at the corners of the blunt end of the wound may be seen. These are referred to as fishtailing.

Other options:

Option B - A double-edged knife would produce a slit-like or elliptical wound. Both the edges of the wound are likely to be sharp.

Option C - An ice pick would produce a single small circular wound resembling wounds caused by a small caliber gun.

Option D - A screwdriver would produce a slit-like wound with squared edges.

The types of wounds produced by different weapons are summarized in the image below:

questions.text: You were asked to do a pediatric evaluation of milestones attained by the children in the pediatric ward. After a thorough evaluation, you would be able to categorize all the following children as less than or equal to 3 years of age except in ___________

choices.text: Child who is able to walks upstairs and downstairs with 2 feet/step
Child who is able to tell its name and gender but can't tell stories
Child who is able to builds a tower of 9 blocks and can't copy a cross
Child who can play cooperatively in a group but can't dress on its own

questions.solution:
The child given in option 4 is able to play cooperatively in a group, which is usually attained by 4 years of age. All other milestones given in other 3 options are attained by a child less than or equal to 3 years of age.

Other options:

Normally, a child less than or equal to 3 years of age would be able to,

  • Walks upstairs and downstairs with 2 feet/step, which is attained by 2 years. (option A)
  • Tell its name and gender, which is attained by 3 years.(option B)
  • Build a tower of 9 blocks, which is attained by 3 years. (Option C)

questions.text: Where are blood bags and urine bags discarded, according to biomedical waste management?

choices.text: Both are disposed of in yellow container
Both are disposed of in red container
Urine bag in red container and blood bag in yellow container
Urine bag in yellow container and blood bag in red container

questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management, the urine bags are supposed to be disposed of in the red container and blood bags in the yellow container.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

questions.text: You diagnose retinopathy of prematurity in a child born at 31 weeks. In all the following conditions of ROP, you would advise for observation and weekly regular follow-ups except

choices.text: Zone I, stage 3 non plus disease
Zone II, stage 3 non plus disease

questions.solution:
Stage 3 ROP to any extent within zone I require treatment with laser photocoagulation.

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP): It is a proliferative retinopathy seen in premature infants with low birth weight who often have been exposed to a high concentration of oxygen

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1: Demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3: Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment

"Plus" disease" signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus.

Concentric zones centered on the optic disc are described.

  • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the center of the macula.
  • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the center of the disc to the nasal ora Serrata.
  • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

 

ROP that requires treatment with Laser photocoagulation (usually within 72 hours)

  • Zone I, any stage ROP with plus disease or
  • Zone I, stage 3, with or without plus disease
  • Zone II, stage 2 or 3 ROP, with plus disease

Not to treat, but weekly follow up:

  • Zone I, stage 1 or 2 non-plus disease or
  • Zone II, stage 3 non plus disease

questions.text: A senior paediatric consultant shows the following pedigree chart and asks you to name a few conditions which shows similar pattern of inheritance.  You could name all the following conditions except __________
questions.solution:
The pedigree is representative of an x-linked dominant type of inheritance. Of the options mentioned, Agammaglobulinemia shows an x-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

In the x-linked dominant pattern of inheritance, The affected female is capable of transmitting the disease to half of the sons and half of the daughters. The affected male can transmit the disease to all of his daughters and none of his sons.

Examples include:

  • Incontinentia pigmenti
  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets
  • Alport syndrome
  • Rett’s syndrome
  • Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is under treatment with amiodarone for refractory ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following is not necessary to detect the side effects of chronic amiodarone therapy?

choices.text: Slit lamp examination to detect corneal microdeposits
Liver function test to detect hepatic dysfunction
Skin biopsy to detect precancerous pigmentation

questions.solution:
Precancerous pigmentation is not one of the side effects of chronic amiodarone therapy. It is associated with blue-gray skin pigmentation due to amiodarone deposition but it is not precancerous.

Option A -Pulmonary fibrosis is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. It can rapidly progress and become fatal. Regular monitoring should be done with spirometry to detect fibrosis associated decrease in pulmonary function.

Options B - Other adverse effects include corneal microdeposits which can be detected on slit lamp examination.

Option C - Baseline and serial LFT should be done to  detect hepatic dysfunction

Other side effects include peripheral neuropathy, proximal muscle weakness, photosensitivity, and hypo/hyperthyroidism

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presents to the surgical ward with multiple tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Which of the following is the most common pancreatic islet tumor seen in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
MEN 1 syndrome is characterized by the triad of tumors involving the parathyroids, pancreatic islets, and anterior pituitary. Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome.

Most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the first and second part of duodenum.

Gastrinoma if associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcer is called Zollinger Ellison syndrome.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: After a certain vaccination, there had been a surge of patients with abscesses. The infectious disease specialist found that a batch of vaccines were contaminated with an acid-fast bacteria which grew within 7 days on LJ medium, reduced nitrates, gave a negative test for niacin, and did not produce pigments. Which of the following could be the possible organism?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium fortuitum is the likely contaminant in the above scenario as it belongs to the rapid grower (IV) category of runyoun classification.

The rest of the organism are slow growers:

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a slow grower and would show positive niacin test.
  • Mycobacterium avium complex is a slow grower and would not reduce nitrates.
  • Mycobacterium scroflaceum may give rise to cervical adenitis which can be confused with abscesses. It however is a slow grower.
  M.tuberculosis M. scrofulaceum M.avium M.fortuitum
