questions.text: A 12-year-old boy was playing with his siblings when he slipped and fell from a height and landed on his feet. He complains of pain in the right ankle joint. X-ray of the joint appears normal. He was managed with the cast but continued pain and persistent tenderness were noted during the review, therefore a growth plate fracture is suspected. What Salter-Harris fracture does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a Salter-Harris type V fracture.

Salter-harris type V fracture involves compression or rammed fracture of the growth plate, this is an uncommon fracture. When this occurs, growth arrest usually follows.

X-rays may appear normal in Salter types I and V. If x-rays appear normal but a growth plate fracture is suspected, patients are assumed to have a fracture, a splint or cast is applied, and patients are re-examined in several days. Continued pain and tenderness suggest a growth plate fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A diabetic male patient was admitted with complaints of breathing difficulty. Blood investigations show positive reports for 1,3 beta D Glucan assay and raised galactomannan antigen levels. A CT scan shows a pulmonary consolidation and a CT-guided biopsy is done. Which of the following findings can be seen in the histopathology of the sample?

choices.text: Fungal hyphae are septate and branch at acute angles
Ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pulmonary consolidation and positive 1,3 beta D Glucan assay and raised galactomannan antigen points towards a diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species are narrow, septate, and have branching at acute angles.

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection seen in the immunosuppressed hosts. Aspergillus has a tendency to invade blood vessels. Thus, widespread hematogenous dissemination with the involvement of the heart valves and brain is common.

Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children.

Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

β 1-3 glucan assay is mainly used for invasive aspergillosis, candidiasis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. It detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, except those which lack the glucan entirely or produce it at a minimal level like: 

  • Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Zygomycetes like mucor species
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis

Image below shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species which are narrow, septate, and have branching at acute angles.

Other options:

Option B: Pseudohyphae are seen in candidiasis. Though 1,3 Beta D Glucan assay is used for invasive candidiasis, it doesn't show galactomannan antigen positivity.

Option C: Ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles is seen in Mucormycosis. 1,3 beta-D-glucan assay, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Option C: Encapsulated yeast forms are seen in cryptococcosis. 1,3 beta-D-glucan assay, cannot be used for the diagnosis of cryptococcosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with abdominal pain, peripheral edema, and ascites. History revealed a loss of appetite, weight loss, and diarrhea. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of gastrin. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed the following appearance involving the fundus and body of the stomach, sparing the antrum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are diagnostic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease, also called hyperplastic hypersecretory gastropathy is a disorder of the stomach characterized by enlarged rugae (gastric folds). It is caused due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor (TGF)-α, which is an EGF receptor (EGFR) ligand, and hyperactivation of the epidermal growth factor receptor on gastric epithelial cells.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

The condition is characterized by diffuse hyperplasia of foveolar epithelium within the body and fundus, causing enlarged gastric folds as shown below. The antrum is usually spared. 

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option a: Infiltrative type of gastric adenocarcinoma is characterized by a thickened gastric wall and partial loss of rugal folds. These changes impart a leather bottle appearance, termed linitis plastica.

Option b: Zollinger–ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumor. The tumors are found in the small intestine or pancreas. increased gastrin secretion causes, changes in gastric wall, characterized by an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Opition d: Whipple disease is an intestinal disease characterized by the triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. The disease is caused due to accumulation of bacteria-laden macrophages within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes leading to lymphatic obstruction. Impaired lymphatic drainage causes malabsorption.

questions.text: During your ophthalmology postings, you notice an ophthalmologist using the following tray for testing the color vision. All the following statements about this test is true except___

choices.text: Most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired colour vision defects
Greater the error score poorer will be the colour vision.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the tray used in the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test. Despite the name, it consists of 85 caps of different hues arranged in four racks.

The Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test:

  • It is a spectroscopic test.
  • It consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks and the subject is asked to rearrange the colored chips in ascending order.
  • It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired color vision defects.
  • An error score is used to judge the color vision, i.e. greater the score poorer will be the color vision.

 

Note:

Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test is similar the above test but it utilizes only 15 hue caps.

Few other commonly employed color vision tests includes,

  • Ishihara’s plates
  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  • Edridge-Green lantern test.
  • City University test
  • Holmgrens wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope

questions.text: The number of stereoisomers of the given compound is
questions.solution:
The given image shows the chemical structure of glucose with 4 Asymmetric carbon atoms.

Using Van't Hoff rule, the number stereoisomers is 2 to the Power n where n is the number of asymmetric carbon atoms. As there are 4 asymmetric carbons here, 16 stereoisomers.

Two enantiomers each of eight different diastereomers: allose, altrose, glucose, mannose, gulose, idose, galactose, and talose.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old post-cholecystectomy patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the third postoperative day. Evaluation reveals a collection in Morrison's pouch. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in this case?

ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography

HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid 

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
ERCP is the most useful investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks. It has the advantage of being diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and or temporary stenting may be required. 

ERCP allows the insertion of a stent in the bile duct to manage the biliary leak. 

The most common post-cholecystectomy biliary leak is from the cystic duct. This can be managed by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin.

Other options:

Option A- MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) can demonstrate fluid collection arising from the biliary leak but, it can not differentiate these from other fluid collections. 

Option C and Option D- Both HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scintigraphy and CT can demonstrate biliary leaks. HIDA is more sensitive and CT provides more anatomical information.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient with COPD was admitted to the ICU with acute exacerbation of COPD and development of sudden onset palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. Which of the following is the least useful in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The ECG and the clinical history point towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia. Electrical cardioversion has no effect on the management of this condition.

The ECG shows discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies, HR >100, P waves return to the baseline separated by isoelectric intervals and variable P-P, P-R, and R-R intervals.

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia:

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image) with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min. MAT is associated with significant lung disease in 60% of the cases. The clinical features are most commonly related to the underlying precipitating illness (COPD in this case). Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves. It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness.

Treatment of MAT:

  • Treating the underlying disease 
  • Correcting any metabolic abnormalities. 
  • Calcium-channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem can be used ( they decrease the atrial and ventricular rate).
  • Amiodarone is also used to treat MAT (but long-term therapy is avoided due to its toxicities like pulmonary fibrosis).
  • Electrical cardioversion has no effect.

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents for ophthalmic evaluation due to the findings shown in the below image. The patient is very tall, with long limbs and long, slender, spiderlike fingers. Slit-lamp examination in this patient reveals bilateral ectopia lentis. What is the usual site of lens subluxation in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with blue sclera as shown in the image along with long limbs, tall height, and slender fingers with ectopia lentis is likely to have Marfan's syndrome. In Marfan's syndrome, ectopia lentis is usually superotemporal.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. It involves a mutation in the fibrillin 1 gene (FBN1). It has classic cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities. 

The most common ocular change in Marfan syndrome is bilateral ectopia lentis, seen in 80% of patients. Ectopia lentis is a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position. It may be partially or fully displaced. In Marfan syndrome, it is usually a superotemporal subluxation. The zonules are intact so accommodation is not affected. However, in severe cases, the lens may also dislocate into the anterior chamber or the vitreous. 

Other causes of ectopia lentis are as follows: 

Acquired: 

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye due to myopia or buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumors

Without systemic associations: 

  • Familial ectopia lentis
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae
  • Aniridia

With systemic associations:

  • Marfan syndrome
  • Homocystinuria - inferonasal
  • Weill-Marchesani syndrome - inferior subluxation

Other ocular manifestations of Marfan syndrome are glaucoma due to angle anomaly, lattice retinal degeneration and detachment, hypoplasia of the dilator pupillae. 

The most characteristic cardiac abnormality is aortic root dilation, which leads to regurgitation, aneurysmal dilation, and dissection, which is a cause of mortality. Mitral valve prolapse can also occur. There is also excessive linear growth of long bones leading to long extremities in proportion to the trunk. They also have joint laxity and scoliosis. 

Blue sclera is also seen in osteogenesis imperfecta, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan's syndrome, and pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is undergoing parathyroidectomy. After the removal of multiple parathyroids, the surgeon wants to autotransplant the remainder parathyroid tissue into the patient's forearm to prevent hypoparathyroidism post-surgery. What should be the ideal size and the total number of tissue pieces respectively, to be transplanted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle of the non-dominant hand post surgery. Parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and 1-2 pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

questions.text: A 45 year old iron smelter, presents to the OPD with history of rice water diarrhoea. The image shows the clinical finding that the doctor notes during examination. Which of the following clinical features would be consistent with the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning. Tremors are consistent with a diagnosis of arsenic poisoning which should be suspected in a patient of with Aldrich Mees lines, red velvety mucosa, and rice water stools.

Hyperpyrexia, Hyperpigmentation, and Anorexia are associated features.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: Pseudomonas is intrinsically resistant to all except _____________
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas is sensitive to Piperacillin.

Intrinsic resistance is the innate ability of a bacterial species to resist the activity of a particular antimicrobial agent through its inherent structural or functional characteristics, which allow the tolerance of a particular drug or antimicrobial class.

Clinical implications: Intrinsic Resistance

Knowledge of the intrinsic resistance of a pathogen of concern is important in practice to avoid inappropriate and ineffective therapies. For bacterial pathogens that are naturally insensitive to a large number of classes of antimicrobials, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Related Pearl: List of intrinsic drug resistance in bacteria

 

Organism Intrinsic Drug Resistance

Acinetobacter baumanii

Ampicillin,Amoxicillin,Ertapenem,Trimethoprim,Chloramphenicol
Pseudomonas aeruginosa Ampicillin,Amoxicillin-Clavulanate,Ceftriaxone,Ertapenem,Tetracyclines/Tigecyclines, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole,Chloramphenicol
Bacteroides fragilis Aminoglycosides,Ampicillin
Gram positive bacteria Aztreonam
Staphylococcus saprophyticus  Novobiocin
Enterococcus fecalis/fecium Cephalosporins,Aminoglycosides,Clindamycin,Polymyxin B
Clostridium species  Aminoglycosides
Gram negative bacteria Vancomycin
Klebsiella pneumoniae Ampicillin
Enterobacter Ampicillin
Aerobic bacteria Metronidazole
Lactobacillus & Leuconostoc Vancomycin
Burkholderia Polymyxins and aminoglycosides

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining of a sputum sample for diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Decolourising with iodine is not a step involved in Ziehl-Neelsen staining. 

Steps involved in Ziehl-Neelsen stain are:

  1. Place sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
  2. Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
  3. Apply carbol fuchsin stain
  4. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  5. Decolourise with alcohol 
  6. Apply methylene blue stain 
  7. Wash with water to remove excess stain
  8. View under microscope

Kinyoun modified it so that heat fixing is not required, it is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. It is then washed with water and decolourised with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope.

The image below shows the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining.

The best diagnostic procedure of M. tuberculosis is sputum culture.

  • Sputum microscopy is the most dependable and conventional method for demonstration of AFB(Acid-fast bacteria) by ZN staining method.
  • The smears are made from thick purulent part of the sputum and then are air dried, fixed by heating, and finally stained by ZN technique.
  • The stained smear is examined under oil immersion lens (100). Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
  • At least 10,000 bacilli should be present per mL of sputum in order to be demonstrable in direct smears.
  • Atleast 300 fields should be examined taking about 10 minutes before giving a negative report.
  • The presence of at least two or more typical bacilli in the smear is reported as positive for AFB (Acid-fast bacteria).

The smears are graded depending on the number of tubercle bacilli present in a stained smear on examination by oil immersion lens.

Grading of ZN- stained smears for AFB:-

Number of AFB per oil immersion field Grading Number of fields Result
>10 / field 3+ 20 Positive
1-10 / field 2+ 50 Positive
10-99 / 100 field 1+ 100 Positive
1-9 / 100 field Scanty 100 Positive
Nil AFB / 100 field   1000 Negative

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with a painless mass in the parotid region. Examination revealed a 5-cm rounded, well-demarcated tumor. Biopsy of the tumor revealed myoepithelial cells intermingled with myxoid, mucoid, and cartilaginous areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and the parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Therefore they are also termed mixed tumors.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

On microscopy epithelial and mesenchymal components are visible. Epithelial components resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells that are arranged in the form of ducts, acini, irregular tubules, or sheets of cells. These components are dispersed in the mesenchymal components consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing cartilage or bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Other options:

Option A: Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells. The inner layer contains columnar cells while the outer layer contains cuboidal cells.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient presents with irregular periods, hirsutism, and infertility. Her ultrasound scan revealed the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following options is not correct regarding the USG criteria for this condition?

choices.text: At least 10 follicles should be present for diagnosis
Each follicle should be 2 to 9 mm in size
Ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on OCPs

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound shows multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern, which is a feature of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). At least 12 follicles each measuring 2 to 9 mm should be seen on an ultrasound.

 USG Criteria: 

  • Increased ovarian stroma 
  • ≥12 follicles(Rotterdam criteria)/ ≥20 follicles(New criteria) each measuring 2 to 9 mm arranged in a necklace pattern
  • Ovarian volume ≥10 ml
  • These ovarian changes are not applicable if the woman is on combined oral pills, as these pills alter the ovarian morphology.
  • A single ovary meeting these criteria is enough to diagnose PCOD.

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology, 2003):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria for diagnosing polycystic ovarian syndrome:

National Institute of Health (NIH, 1990):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation

Androgen excess and PCOS society (AE-PCOS):

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Necklace appearance of right ovary on USG in PCOD:

questions.text: The structure marked in the cadaveric image given below, arises at the ______
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein. The superior mesenteric artery originated from the abdominal aorta at the level of the lower border of the L1 vertebra, about 1 cm below the celiac trunk .

Their branches are:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note - Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following events is not likely to be seen in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
Atrial repolarization is not likely to be seen on a normal ECG.

Atrial repolarization occurs during ventricular depolarization. However, the voltage of the atrial repolarization is very low and is masked by the QRS complex representing ventricular depolarization. 

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: A young man with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago, is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks. His weakness began in the toes and ankles and progressed to involve his knee and hip joints. His upper limbs are not affected and cranial nerves are intact. On examination, there is an absent knee jerk. Which of the following would you consider as the initial therapy?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain Barre syndrome (GBS). Intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) would be considered as the initial therapy in this patient.

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. Most of the cases occur after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies are produced against external antigens like infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, HHV) and vaccines (Influenza). These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue (called molecular mimicry).

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia) with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves leading the bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

igh-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record. It contains anti-idiotypic antibodies against autoantibodies. It is administered as five daily infusions for a total dose of 2 g/kg body weight.

Other options: 

Option B - Mechanical ventilation is reserved for those who develop respiratory insufficiency or patients who develop early bulbar weakness. This patient has no bulbar weakness (normal cranial nerves).

Option C - Corticosteroid administration has not been shown to provide many benefits in GBS. 

Option D - Antibiotic administration would not be useful in GBS as the pathophysiology involves axonal degeneration due to a immune cause, not infective. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida with twin gestation presents to the clinic in active labor. Her obstetric history and antenatal scans indicate dichorionic diamniotic twins. The first twin is in vertex presentation while the second has a transverse lie. Which of the following is correct regarding how to proceed further in this case?

choices.text: Deliver first twin through vaginal delivery, deliver second by cesarean section
Deliver first twin through vaginal delivery, deliver second by assisted forceps/ventouse
Deliver first twin through vaginal delivery, correct transverse lie by internal version

questions.solution:
In this scenario, deliver the first twin (in vertex presentation) through vaginal delivery and perform internal podalic version and breech extraction of the second twin under GA. 

Scheme of management of twins in labor:

1. If the first twin is in vertex presentation: Deliver the first twin through vaginal delivery and do not give methergine post-delivery of the first baby. Delivering the second twin, If it is in,

  • Breech: Deliver through breech extraction
  • Transverse lie
    • If the obstetrician is skilled in podalic version: Internal podalic version and breech extraction under GA. 
    • If the obstetrician is unskilled: External version into a longitudinal lie preferably cephalic or if that fails podalic. 
  • Vertex: Vaginal delivery, assisted forceps/ventouse.

2. If the first twin/ both twins are in the non-cephalic presentation: deliver through cesarean section.

Other indications of cesarean section: Cord prolapse, monoamniotic, monochorionic twins with TTTS, severe preeclampsia, placenta previa, etc.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of which of the following hormone is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution:
Serum levels of the gastrin are most likely to be reduced.

Gastrin is secreted by the G cells in the gastric antrum. Gastrin has two main actions:

  • Stimulates secretion of H+ by gastric parietal cells
  • Promotes growth of the gastric mucosa (trophic action)

Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa. Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.

Secretin, cholecystokinin, and motilin are released by various cells in different parts of the small intestine and remain unaffected by the atrophy of gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A cadaveric specimen of the circle of Willis is given below. Which of the following marked structures represents the superior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric image is of the vascular structures(Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain. The structure marked as 'A' can be identified as the superior cerebellar artery as it is arising from the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries(marked as B).

The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The characteristic oral cavity examination finding of a fever with rash is shown in the image. The strain of vaccine used for the prevention of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Koplik spots opposite 2nd molar is a characteristic oral cavity finding in  Measles.

The vaccine for measles has 3 strains (Edmonston Zagreb strain, Schwartz strain, Moraten strain).

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the mapleson circuit shown below?

choices.text: It is the circuit of choice for controlled ventilation
It is also known as Magill circuit
Only mapleson circuit with fresh gas flow near the bag and away from the patient
Most efficient Mapleson circuit for spontaneous ventilation

questions.solution:
The circuit shown above is Mapleson's A or Magill circuit. It is considered a poor choice for controlled ventilation.

Modified co-axial variety of Type A - Lack's circuit.

SMAL - For Spontaneous, Magill's circuit, Mapleson's Type A, Lack's co-axial circuit.

It is the only Mapleson circuit with fresh gas flow near the bag and away from the patient. It is the most efficient Mapleson circuit for spontaneous ventilation because a fresh gas flow equal to minute ventilation is sufficient to prevent rebreathing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who has completed her family wants to undergo a permanent method of sterilization. She wants to know about the Essure device which is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilisation.  What is the mechanism of action of this form of sterilization?

choices.text: Local growth of fibrous tissue occluding the fallopian tube
Local spermicidal action of titanium alloy

questions.solution:
The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. The mechanism of action is the local growth of fibrous tissue responsible for the occlusion of the fallopian tube. This is an irreversible and permanent technique. 

Essure is done through the hysteroscopic method and so the abdominal scar is avoided. It involves a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of two coils – an inner coil made of flexible stainless steel and an outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol). The inner coil contains polyethylene terephthalate (PET) fibers, which stimulate the growth of harmless local fibrous tissue, leading to the blockage of the fallopian tube. A guidewire helps to guide the device into the fallopian tube. After three months, a hysterosalpingography is conducted to confirm the blockage of the fallopian tube.

Disadvantages:

  • Hysteroscopy is required
  • Cost and expertise required
  • Permanent method
  • HSG to confirm blockage
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with diabetic neuropathy, on examination, was found to have a loss of sensation to tap and vibration at low frequency (20 Hz). But he has an intact vibration sense at a higher frequency (200 Hz). Which of the following somatosensory receptors is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Sensations of tap and low-frequency vibration (flutter, 5-40 Hz) are sensed by the Meissner's corpuscles. Hence, a loss of sensation of tap and flutter is most likely due to the disease affecting the Meissner's corpuscles. 

Cutaneous mechanoreceptors: There are four types of mechanoreceptors for sensing touch and pressure. They include:

  • Meissner corpuscles
  • Merkel cells
  • Ruffini corpuscles
  • Pacinian corpuscles 

Meissner corpuscles are dendrites encapsulated in the connective tissue beneath the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to tap and flutter (low-frequency vibration - 5-40Hz). They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Merkel cells are expanded dendritic endings in the epidermis of glabrous (non-hairy) skin. They respond to sustained pressure and touch. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Ruffini's corpuscles are enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They respond to stretch and fluttering vibrations. They are slowly adapting receptors.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor, measuring about 2mm in length and 1mm in diameter. They are present in the dermis of glabrous (non-hairy) and hairy skin. A Pacinian corpuscle consists of a nerve ending encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving it an onion-like appearance. They respond to fast vibration (60-500Hz) and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: Select the wrongly matched antigen -parasite pair
questions.solution:
Among the given options, WKK is wrongly matched to Wucherria bancrofti. 200kDa Ag and OG4C3 are used to detect Wuchereria bancroftii.

The respective Antigen-Parasite pairs are:

  • WKK and rk39 antigens - leishmania
  • HRP-2 antigen - Plasmodium falciparum
  • Galactose lectin antigen - Entamoeba histolytica
  • Vivax specific pLDH - Plasmodium Vivax

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was admitted for bacterial pneumonia with a pleural effusion. The pleural fluid analysis revealed a specific gravity of 1.031 and contained a large number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following best characterizes the pleural effusion in this patient?
questions.solution:
The specific gravity of 1.031 (>1.020) is suggestive of an exudate. The presence of a large number of neutrophils indicates a purulent exudate.

Purulent exudate is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells; and microbes.

Exudate:

  • Increased vascular permeability, caused by inflammatory mediators, may lead to the accumulation of protein-rich fluid called an exudate.
  • It has a high specific gravity of >1.020.
  • An exudate may be further classified into the following types:
    • Serous exudate: The exudative fluid does not contain microbes or leukocytes. Serous exudate is usually seen in spaces created by cell injury or into body cavities lined by pleura, pericardium, or peritoneum.
    • Fibrinous exudate: It occurs in inflammation associated with large vascular leaks and local procoagulant stimulus (Ex: caused by cancer cells). With a greater increase in vascular permeability, fibrinogen may pass out of the blood into the exudate. The fibrin formed is deposited in the extracellular space. A fibrinous exudate is characteristic of inflammation in the lining of body cavities, such as meninges, pericardium, and pleura.
    • Purulent exudate: It is an inflammatory exudate rich in leukocytes, mostly neutrophils; the debris of the dead cells, and microbes.

Transudate:

  • Transudate is extravascular fluid, which is essentially an ultrafiltrate of blood plasma. It results from increased fluid pressures or diminished colloid oncotic forces in the plasma, and not due to the increased vascular permeability.
  • It has low protein content and low nucleated-cell counts (less than 500 to 1000 per microliter) and low specific gravity (<1.012).
  • Noninflammatory edema and effusions (transudate) are common in many diseases, including heart failure, liver failure, renal disease, and severe nutritional disorders.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome 

Related Pearl: Causes of predominantly unilateral pleural effusion

Predominantly right-sided pleural effusion

Predominantly left-sided pleural effusion

(hepatic hydrothorax)

questions.text: A bodybuilder presented with complains of fatigue, muscle pain increased thirst, and urination. His calcium levels are 10mEq/L. He has a history of consumption of vitamin D sachets of 60,000IU by himself for making his bones stronger.  Which of the following is  not used in the treatment?
questions.solution:
Calcium gluconate infusion should not be done in case of hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.

Vitamin D toxicity is a likely diagnosis in this case with history of excess vitamin D supplementation.

Clinical manifestations: Symptoms of acute intoxication are due to hypercalcemia and include confusion, polyuria, polydipsia, anorexia, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Chronic intoxication may cause nephrocalcinosis, bone demineralization, and pain.

Laboratory findings: Hypercalcemia, elevated 25-D levels, hypercalciuria, suppressed PTH

Management: Should focus on control of hypercalcemia 

  • Adequate rehydration with normal saline. Loop diuretics may be added It increases urine output thereby increasing urinary calcium excretion.
  • Eliminating the source of excess vitamin-D like fortified food etc.
  • Glucocorticoids like Prednisolone and Dexamethasone to limit action of vitamin D.
  • Calcitonin and bisphosphonates lower bone resorption thereby reducing serum calcium levels.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with hypertension 3 years back. He was started on ACE inhibitors and he takes them regularly. His blood pressure readings have been regularly monitored since and he has been on regular follow-up without any complications. His current blood pressure readings are 124/78 mmHg. This case will fall under ___________ in the given image below.

(In the given image, 1 represents the whole community/population)
questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves. The given scenario describes a patient that is being adequately treated. Therefore, it would fall under the cases depicted as 9 in the image.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect regarding ROME IV criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent abdominal pain, on average should be present for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months
Associated with a change in stool form
Associated with a change in stool frequency
Abdominal pain for the last 3 weeks with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:

  • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
  • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant
  • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet
  • Fecal calprotectin levels help distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from IBS

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: Unlocking of the knee is by:
questions.solution:
Unlocking of the knee is mediated by the popliteus muscle.

Locking of the knee joint: When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is the quadriceps femoris, especially the vastus medialis part.

Unlocking of the knee joint: It is the lateral rotation of femur on tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of popliteus muscle.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the Medicine OPD with hypertension, abdominal masses, occasional hematuria and flank pain. His abdominal radiological imaging is given below. What should be the target blood pressure recommended according to the guidelines of the JNC VIII reports for reducing the complications in this condition?
questions.solution:
The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the history and age of the patient are suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Blood pressure control to a target of 140/90 mmHg is recommended according to the guidelines of the JNC VIII reports for reducing cardiovascular complications in ADPKD and renal disease progression.

Adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)

Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with a mutation in the genes PKD1 (chromosome 16p, produces a protein called polycystin1) and PKD2 (chromosome 4q, polycystin 2).

Clinical features: The disease does not usually manifest before the age of 30 years, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed.

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Irregular upper quadrant mass
  • Loin pain
  • Hematuria
  • Infection
  • Uremia

Extrarenal manifestation: Cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, and spleen. Berry aneurysm (Intracranial aneurysms), colonic diverticuli may also occur.

Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease (PKD).

Intracranial aneurysms are frequently seen in patients with PKD. Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid haemorrhage.

Mitral valve prolapse is seen in up to 25-30% of patients with ADPKD.

ADPKD is an important cause of renal failure, and these patients may require haemodialysis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who is a chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. The abdominal pain is persistent and intractable. CT-scan revealed pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. The given condition is likely to be caused due to disturbance in which of the following phases of nutrient absorption?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. In chronic pancreatitis, the phase of intraluminal digestion is affected in which proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into forms suitable for absorption. Fat malabsorption in patients with chronic pancreatitis is often associated with steatorrhea.

Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive faecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-coloured stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn disease.

Long-standing malabsorptive disease is accompanied by nutritional deficiency, including weight loss, anemia, osteomalacia, and a tendency to bleed.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

  • Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.
  • Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy developed severe bleeding into the knee joint. Investigations revealed reduced serum levels of factor IX, but normal levels of factor VIII. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Factor IX deficiency is suggestive of hemophilia B.

Hemophilia B, also known as Christmas disease is caused by mutations in coagulation factor IX.  It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait and is clinically identical to hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency) as both factor VIII and IX function together to activate factor X.

Similar to Hemophilia A, in Hemophilia B, PTT is prolonged and the PT is normal.

Diagnosis is made by assay of the factor levels.

Treatment includes infusions of recombinant factor IX.

Other options:

a. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder caused due to deficiency in factor VIII.

c. Henoch–Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a childhood syndrome characterized by purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain and intestinal bleeding, and arthralgias along with renal abnormalities.

d. Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant bleeding disorder caused due to defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF)

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A 6-month-old  infant is being evaluated for recurrent lower respiratory tract infections, dysphagia, and regurgitation. Barium swallow revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow is suggestive of double aortic arch.

The frontal chest radiograph shows two impressions on the barium-filled oesophagus, one impression on the right side due to the higher right-sided arch, and the other impression on the left-side due to the left-sided arch.

Double aortic arch is a congenital anomaly, characterized by the presence of persistence of both aortic arches, with the formation of a vascular ring. The right-sided aortic arch is usually higher and larger, while the normal left-sided aortic arch, is lower, and maybe hypoplastic or atretic.

Both the right and left arches, join the descending thoracic aorta after giving off the left subclavian artery.

The vascular ring may cause compression of the trachea and oesophagus. Depending on the degree of compression, the onset of symptoms may be in infancy, early childhood, or even adulthood.

Diagnosis is made on barium swallow, which shows compression of the oesophagus, on both the right and left sides.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was treated with the given technique for limb lengthening. On follow-up, he was noted to have developed a pin-tract infection. He was prescribed antibiotics, a few weeks after this, the infection still persists. On performing radiograph what kind of sequestrum would you most likely find?
questions.solution:
The given image is of an external fixator. Infection at a pin site in an external fixation construct leads to a ring sequestrum.  

Sequestrum is a fragment of dead bone lying within a cavity formed by necrosis. Various types of sequestra and their causes are given in the following table:

Type of Sequestrum Cause
Tubular or diaphyseal sequestrum Acute pyogenic osteomyelitis
Ring sequestrum

Amputation stump and at Steinmann pins

External fixator
Ivory sequestrum Syphilis
Fine sandy sequestrum Viral osteomyelitis
Coarse sandy sequestrum Body of vertebra (cavity of tuberculosis)
Flake or Feathery sequestrum

Tuberculosis of rib (cavity of tuberculosis)
Kissing sequestrum Peridiscal tuberculosis of vertebra
Button-hole sequestrum Radiation
Black sequestrum Actinomycosis

 

The image below shows a ring sequestrum formed at the site of a pin used in the diaphysis of tibia (black box).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal pain radiating to the right quadrant and raised liver enzymes, AST, and ALT >2 times the normal limit. Investigations did not reveal any evidence of gallstone disease, but the common bile duct was dilated and the biliary drainage time was prolonged. Which classification will be used for the assessment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction which is given in the clinical scenario above.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is a clinical syndrome in which pain, biochemical abnormalities, and dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to abnormal functions of the sphincter of Oddi.

The true incidence of SOD is unknown. Females are more commonly affected than males.

Etiology:

SOD may result from stenosis of the sphincter or from dysmotility. Scarring or stenosis of the sphincter can result from passage of stones, pancreatitis, or prior endoscopic sphincterotomies.

Milwaukee classification of the sphincter of Oddi (SOD) dysfunction:

Biliary type SOD:

  • Type I:
    • Typical biliary type pain
    • Liver enzymes (aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT), or alkaline phosphatase (ALP)) >2 times normal limit documented on at least 2 occasions during episodes of pain.
    • Dilated common bile duct (CBD) >12 mm in diameter
    • Prolonged biliary drainage time (>45 min)
  • Type II:
    • Biliary type pain, and
    • One or two of the above criteria
  • Type III:
    • Biliary type pain only

Pancreatic type SOD:

  • Type I:
    • Pancreatic type pain
    • Amylase and/or lipase >2 times the upper normal limit on at least 2 occasions during episodes of pain.
    • Dilated pancreatic duct (head >6 mm, body >5 mm)
    • Prolonged pancreatic drainage time (>9 min)
  • Type II:
    • Pancreatic type pain, and
    • One or two of the above criteria
  • Type III:
    • Pancreatic type pain only

Note:

Cystic tumors of the pancreas are classified according to the Klöppel’s classification system.

Choledochal cysts are classified according to the Todani classification system.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location.

This is a recent NEET question. Classifications used for particular diseases are frequently being asked in almost all the examinations, especially in NEET, making them high-yield.

questions.text:
A female with 8 weeks of gestation was found to be positive for falciparum malaria. You would treat her with:

ACT- Artemisinin-based combination treatment
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy should be treated with quinine.

Treatment of falciparum malaria during pregnancy:

  • 1st trimester: Quinine
  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT-AL (ACT in the form of Artemether (20 mg) and Lumefantrine) in northeastern states and ACT-SP (ACT in the form of Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine) in other states.

Other options:

Option C- Chloroquine is used for the treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy.

Option D- Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnant women.
