questions.text: The marked muscle inserts to_____.
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis and it gets inserted into the greater trochanter of the femur

 The piriformis muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It is inserted into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibres or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle

The following image shows different muscles and of the pelvis and their attachments

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had persistent headaches,  gait disturbances and cognitive difficulties. CT scan revealed a cystic mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere which was resected. The biopsy of the specimen showed cells with long, hairlike processes that stained positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and histopathological findings showing cells with long hair-like processes positive for GFAP are suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign (grade I) astrocytoma that typi­cally occurs in children and young adults. It is usually located in the cerebellum, optic nerves, brainstem and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

Clinically, any brain tumour can present with some general symptoms like headaches, gait disturbances, and cognitive and personality changes. These symptoms may be a result of increased intracranial pressure due to tumour enlargement or edema which may result in hydrocephalus. Seizures usually occur in cases of metastasis. 

The imaging method of choice is cranial MRI with gadolinium contrast administration. It reveals a cystic and well-demarcated mass. The tumour is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork. Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions) and eosinophilic granular bodies (mulberry-like inclusions) are characteristic findings. It has biphasic architecture, with both loose microcystic and compact fibrillary areas.

These tumours grow very slowly with limited brain invasion and can be treated by resection alone. The image below shows the histopathology of pilocytic astrocytoma, with characteristic bipolar cells with long hair-like processes.

 

Other options:

  • Option B: Hemangioblastoma is a fluid-filled cystic lesion that typically arises in the cerebellum and in the retina. It may be associated with polycythemia and von Hippel-Lindau disease.
  • Option C: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour occurring exclusively in the cerebellum. Rapid growth may occlude the flow of CSF, leading to hydrocephalus.
  • Option D: Ependymoma arises in proximity to the ependyma-lined ventricular system, typically on the floor of the fourth ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma

Most common primary CNS tumor in children - pilocytic astrocytoma

Most common primary CNS tumor in adults - astrocytoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in children - medulloblastoma

Most common primary malignant tumor of the brain in adults - glioblastoma

questions.text: A female patient on medication for recurrent muscle pain presents with hematuria and flank pain. Investigations revealed a shrunken kidney with papillary necrosis and calcification. Which of the following drugs was she most likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the findings of papillary calcifications and necrosis is suggestive of analgesic nephropathy. The patient was most likely on phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine.

Analgesic nephropathy is a renal disease characterized by tubulointerstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. It occurs due to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics, especially phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine. Paracetamol is another drug that is implicated. It is more common in women and a history of chronic headaches, arthralgias, and abdominal pain which necessitated the chronic use is usually present. 

Flank pain with or without hematuria might indicate a ureteral obstruction due to the sloughed papilla secondary to necrosis. It increases the risk for urinary tract malignancies. 

NSAIDs are a group of drugs with analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties. The effects are exerted by blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins. The COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes are inhibited. These enzymes are the first steps in the production of prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins.

Other side effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) include agranulocytosis, cystitis, hematuria, thrombosis, and dyspepsia.  

Other options:

Options A and C: Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors (CNI), used as immunosuppressants that can cause CNI nephrotoxicity. Acute kidney injury can be due to thrombotic microangiopathy or toxic tubulopathy. Chronic CNI nephrotoxicity is seen commonly in transplant patients. It presents with a decline in glomerular filtration rate, hypertension, and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Lithium, commonly used in manic-depressive disorders can lead to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Rarely, it can cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.

questions.text: An insured 35-year-old woman, who is working in a newspaper establishment, is undergoing a tubectomy procedure. According to the Employees State Insurance Act, she would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the productive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as enhanced sickness benefit. 

The enhanced sickness benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization for 7 days for male and 14 days for female workers. 

Other options: 

Option B: Extended sickness benefit is offered to insured people who are suffering from certain chronic diseases, for a maximum period of 2 years, in addition to the 91 days of leave they are entitled to under the sickness benefit. During this period, they are paid about 80% of the average daily wages. The insured person should have been working for a continuous period of 2 years. There are 34 listed diseases for which the extended sickness benefit can be availed. 

Option C: Maternity benefit is payable in cash to an insured woman for confinement/miscarriage or sickness arising out of pregnancy, confinement, or premature birth of a child or miscarriage. The benefit is allowed at full wages for a period of 26 weeks for confinement, 6 weeks for miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of confinement.

Option D: Dependant's benefit is offered to the dependants of an insured person who died as a result of an employment injury. Pension up to 90% of daily wages is paid to the dependants on a monthly basis. Children are entitled to this benefit up to 18 years of age. 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: In a society, people follow certain customs which they think are the right ways of doing things in the less vital areas of human conduct. These customs are called:
questions.solution:
The customs that are considered as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct are called folkways.

Customs are the practices promoted by the conveniences of the individuals in a society. They can be folkways or mores. Folkways refer to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores (option B) are stringent customs followed by society.

Culture is the learned behavior that is socially acquired. It is passed onto generations through formal and informal learning. Culture is the representation of customs, beliefs, laws, arts, and moral values of a society. Cultural factors have a large part to play in health.

Other options:

Option C- Acculturation means "culture contact".There is a diffusion of culture when there is contact between two people with different types of culture. Different ways by which culture contact takes place are, 

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Propagation of religion
  • Education
  • Conquest.

Option D- The role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

questions.text: All of the following instruments are sterilized using glutaraldehyde, except:
questions.solution:
All of the given instruments are sterilized by glutaraldehyde except for thermometers. Thermometers are sterilized using isopropyl alcohol.

Plastic endotracheal tubes, endoscopes, bronchoscopes, rubber anesthetic tubes, and cystoscopes are sterilized using glutaraldehyde. It is one of the most commonly used disinfectants and is highly effective against tubercle bacilli, viruses, and fungi.

questions.text: A nutritionist is studying the blood levels of various lipoproteins. One of the samples shows elevation of LDL and total cholesterol levels. Which of the following might be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia shows increased levels of LDL and total cholesterol.

Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial hypercholesterolemia occurs due to a defect in LDL receptors. It is an autosomal dominant condition. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and total cholesterol rise. Clinical features include the presence of tendon xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and coronary heart disease.

LDL receptors (apo B100 and apo E) are expressed on multiple types of cells. They are expressed when the cell needs cholesterol for metabolic needs. LDL molecule binds to this receptor and is endocytosed. 

It is a tightly regulated step and involves PCSK9. Therapy targeting PCSK9 has been developed to control the blood levels of LDL.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency in a drowsy state. You check the vitals of this patient and send an ABG. The Lab values are as follows: pH=7.2 PCO2=30 mmHg HCO3= 7 mEq/L Cl= 111 mEq/L Na= 135 mEq/L

What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap with respiratory acidosis

questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap with respiratory acidosis.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. Normal pH is 7.35-7.45

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L( normal = 22-28)  together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate(i.e. base).Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(111+7)

=17 mEq/L

Normal anion gap is 8-12 mEq/L

Hence anion gap is increased.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

In metabolic acidosis, an appropriate respiratory compensation is to decrease PCO2, by excretion of volatile acid by hyperventilation. Expected PCO2 is calculated by the Winters formula:

PCO2=  [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

= [1.5 X 7] + 8 ± 2

=16.5-20.5mm Hg

Since PCO2 is 30 Hg, it signifies inappropriate retention of CO2 indicating a respiratory acidosis in addition to a metabolic acidosis.

Anion gap

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulphate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap.

Anion gap = [Na+] −([Cl-]+[HCO3-])

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic acidosis is of two types:

(1) Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

  • Diarrhea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

(2) High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

  • Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)
  • Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)
  • Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of multiple motor and vocal tics for the past 18 months. His mother informed that sometimes the child would also utter socially unacceptable words suddenly during a conversation. The tics increased and decreased in frequency during this period. The child has normal social and academic skills. How do you manage?

choices.text: Psychoeducation with wait and watch strategy
Botulinum toxin injection to decrease tic severity

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Tourette's syndrome. In mild cases, which do not affect the academic or social life, the first-line of management, is to provide psychoeducation and follow a watch and wait strategy.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder named after the French neurologist Georges Gilles de la Tourette. The condition is characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to vocal tics that can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting or barking noises or shouted words, which may be obscenities.

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at the same time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before age 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).

The management of Tourette's syndrome depends on the severity of the disease.

Mild cases:

  • In mild cases, where the disorder does not affect academic performance or social life, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a watch and wait strategy. A large proportion of patients the severity of tics wane in adult life becoming less of a medical problem.

Moderate to severe cases:

  • In moderate to severe cases, where the disorder significantly affects the child's academic performance and social life, the first line of management includes behavioral and psychological treatment.
  • Some commonly used methods for behavioral treatment include habit reversal, and exposure & response training.
  • In severe cases, both behavioral and pharmacological treatment may be provided.
  • Drugs commonly used include typical and atypical antipsychotics, nor-adrenergic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are implicated in causing retinopathy except?
questions.solution:
Dexamethasone does not cause retinopathy. It is rather implicated in cataract formation.

Both systemic and topical steroids cause cataract formation. The opacity starts forming in the posterior subcapsular region at first and later in the anterior subcapsular area. Glucocorticoids are covalently bound to the lens proteins causing them to destabilize and eventually oxidise, causing cataract formation.

Other options can cause different types of retinopathy

Chlorpromazine - pigmentary retinopathy

Above image showing Chloroquine induced bulls-eye maculopathy

Image showing Thioridazine induced salt and pepper retinopathy

questions.text: A consultant asked a junior resident to assess the ease of endotracheal intubation in a patient to be operated. The findings were similar to the schematic image given below. The resident should grade the oral opening as Mallampati class ___________
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, the base of the uvula, and the hard palate are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class III.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to classes I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded.

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of a difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 13-months-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition, who weighs 7.5 kgs is being given a micronutrient supplement of vitamin A. He should receive the vitamin A dose of ______
questions.solution:
A child with SAM(severe acute malnutrition), with age more than twelve months and weight less than 8 kg, should be given 100,000 IU orally, irrespective of age.

Recommended vitamin-A dose in children suffering from SAM are:

  • 50,000 IU for children less than 6 months,
  • 1 lakh IU for a child between 6 months to 12 months or weight less than 8 kgs and
  • 2 lakh IU for a child above 12 months is given at the time of diagnosis.

The same dose of Vitamin A is repeated the next day and on the 14th day.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with loss of developmental milestones, hypotonia, seizures, failure to thrive, and has a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge. The microscopic appearance of his hair strand is given below. What is the most likely cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease which is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Copper is an essential co‐factor for several metalloenzymes in the human body, including tyrosinase and lysyl oxidase. The primary manifestation of acquired copper deficiency is a myeloneuropathy that affects both sensory and motor nerves.

Hair changes can be the first sign of disease at 1–2 months of age. Scalp and eyebrow hair resemble steel wool, appearing short, sparse, lustreless, tangled and depigmented. Pili torti is the classic finding on trichogram.

At 2–3 months of age, children with Menkes disease present with loss of developmental milestones, hypotonia, seizures, and failure to thrive. These infants have a characteristic cherubic appearance with a depressed nasal bridge, pudgy cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip and doughy skin.

For Menkes disease, if treatment is initiated during the neonatal period or early infancy, neurological deterioration can be halted.

Nutritional deficiencies may cause the following:

  • Zinc deficiency: Hair is dry and brittle, and large areas of alopecia may arise.
  • Keshan's disease: Selenium deficiency presents as brittle hair and may be associated with exfoliative dermatitis on the scalp.
  • Kwashiorkor: Hair develops a lustreless, red‐brown color that may show alternation with more normal color; this so‐called ‘flag sign’ corresponds to alternating periods of significant undernutrition and improved nutrition.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the ER after a road traffic accident. He has decreased sensations over the anterior aspect of neck/ supraclavicular fossa prompting you to suspect a nerve root injury. Which nerve root injury, do you think, is likely involved?
questions.solution:
Decreased sensations over the supraclavicular fossa suggest C3 nerve root injury.

Road traffic accidents, though commonly associated with cord injuries, can at times, as above, be also associated with isolated nerve root injuries

Following is the list of sensation lost due to involvement/injury of a particular level.

C3: leads to decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the neck, specifically tested for over the supraclavicular fossa.

C2: leads to decreased sensation over the back of the scalp.

C4: leads to decreased sensation over the lateral aspect of the neck and inferiorly over clavicles down to the rib space.

C5: leads to decreased sensation over the deltoid.

The American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) has recommended the essential minimal elements of neurologic evaluation for all patients with a spinal injury:

  • Motor examination: Total 20 muscles (10 muscles on each side).
  • Sensory examination: Total 56 points (28 sensory points on each side). 

ASIA scoring helps to evaluate the sensory and motor levels for each side of the body and the overall neurologic level (see image).

questions.text: The transport media shown in the image below can be used for all except ________
questions.solution:
The shown image is of a Cary Blair transport media. Neisseria can't be transported using this.

We need Stuart's medium for Neisseria. Stuart's medium is a non-nutrient, soft agar with added charcoal and reducing agent. It prevents the growth of other organisms and oxidation of Neisseria.

Transport media are used to transport clinical samples whenever fastidious organisms (difficult to grow) are suspected. Cary blair medium is a buffered solution containing sodium chloride, sodium thioglycollate, disodium phosphate, and calcium chloride useful for transporting samples suspected of having vibrios, salmonella and shigella.

Related Pearl: Organisms and their transport media

Streptococcus Pike’s media
Neisseria Stuart media

Cary Blair medium

questions.text: A G2P1 whose blood group is A negative gave birth to a baby with an Rh-positive blood group with direct Coomb's test positive. There were no antenatal care visits during this pregnancy and she is unable to give a clear history regarding the intake of prophylactic anti-D immunoglobulin. Which of the following is not an indication for exchange transfusion in this newborn?

choices.text: Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL
Rising rate of bilirubin  over 1 mg/dL/hour despite phototherapy
Total bilirubin level - 15 mg/dL or more.
Hemoglobin level is less than 11 g/dL

questions.solution:
Exchange transfusion is an indication when the total bilirubin level is 20 mg/dL or more.

Indications for Exchange transfusion:

Done for Rh-positive with direct Coombs’ test positive babies having:

  •  Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL 
  •  Hemoglobin level is less than 11 g/dL
  •  Bilirubin rate is rising- over 1 mg/dL/hour despite phototherapy
  •  Total bilirubin level 20 mg/dL or more.


Exchange transfusion is helpful because of the following factors:

  • To stop hemolysis, and decrease bilirubin production
  • Correction of anemia 
  • Improve congestive cardiac failure of the neonate
  • Removes the circulatory antibodies
  • Removal of the sensitized RBCs
  • Elimination of the circulatory bilirubin

questions.text: A patient undergoes reconstruction surgery after removal of a tumor from the right breast. Which of the following is incorrect about the flap used in the patient, which is shown in the image?

choices.text: It is a variant of the TRAM flap.
It is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.
Increased risk of abdominal wall weakness.
No muscle is taken in this technique.

questions.solution:
The given image is of deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP). When DIEP is used, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness.

The DIEP flap is a variant of the transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap; it is based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. It is harvested using a microvascular technique, in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessel is dissected out. As muscle is spared in DIEP, there is reduced risk in abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications.

Other flaps using autogenous tissue in breast reconstruction are TRAM flap and latissimus dorsi (LD) flap:

The TRAM flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM).

 

Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

questions.text: In spirometry, during forced expiration, the FEV1 is independent of which of the following?
questions.solution:
FEV1 is independent of the expiratory effort due to dynamic compression of the airways.

Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) is reduced in conditions associated with

  • Reduced elastic recoil of the lung, or
  • Increased airway resistance.

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

Dynamic compression of airways in forced expiration:

  • The forced expiratory flow is largely independent of muscular effort, as the flow is determined by the difference between alveolar and pleural pressure (transpulmonary pressure).
  • Before inspiration, the pressure in the airway is 0, while the intrapleural pressure is -5 cm H2O. Thus, a transpulmonary pressure of +5 keeps the airway open.
  • During inspiration, both alveolar and intrapleural pressure drops by 2 cm of H2O, however, in the airway, there is a pressure drop of -1 cm. Therefore, the transpulmonary pressure of +6 cm H2O keeps the airway open.
  • At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure becomes 0, while the transpulmonary pressure is +8.
  • During forced expiration, an increase in muscular effort causes an increase in the pleural pressure by 38 cm of water, which is transmitted to the alveloi. However, as the flow begins there is a pressure drop in the airways to 19cm H2O, thus causing a negative transpulmonary pressure of -11, which causes compression of the airway. 
  • Hence, during forced expiration, an increase or decrease in the muscular effort will cause an increase or decrease in compression of airways, and thus the end-expiratory flow is unaltered.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with hemoptysis and severe chest pain. After a few hours, the patient died due to a massive stroke. Autopsy of the lungs revealed pulmonary infarct, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true about the type of infarct?

choices.text: It is seen in tissues with dual circulation.
It occurs in solid organs with end arterial circulation.
As time passes, the infarction becomes progressively paler.

questions.solution:
The autopsy specimen of the lung shows hemorrhagic infarct (red infarct). A red infarct usually occurs in tissues with dual blood supply, such as the lungs. All other options are incorrect.

Pulmonary infarction may occur in patients as a result of pulmonary embolism (PE). The clinical features of PE mimic those of myocardial infarction, and the patient presents with severe chest pain, dyspnea, and shock. Some patients may also present with pleuritic pain, and cough. Emboli that lead to pulmonary infarction additionally cause fever and hemoptysis.

 An infarction is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either arterial supply or venous drainage.

  • The infarctions are usually wedge-shaped, with the occluded blood vessel forming the apex and the periphery of the organ, forming the base.
  • Fresh infarcts are poorly defined. Over a few days, the margins become better defined due to congestion caused by the inflammatory reaction surrounding the lesion.
  • Depending on the appearance, infarction may be either a red infarct or a white infarct. 

Red infarcts occur

  • with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion).
  • in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone.
  • in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  • in tissues previously congested by a sluggish venous outflow.
  • when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

The infarcts in the lung are almost always hemorrhagic. The extravasated red RBCs in the red infarct are phagocytosed by the macrophages, which convert the heme iron into hemosiderin. Over time, the infarction appears brown in color due to the accumulation of the hemosiderin-laden macrophages. 

The image below shows red infarct in the lung.

 

White infarcts:

  • They occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney).
  • It is seen in organs, where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.
  • In contrast to red infarct, the white infarcts tend to become paler as time passes.

The image below shows white infarcts in the spleen.

questions.text: An elderly man with schizophrenia, on typical antipsychotics for 2 years, presents with involuntary, painless orofacial movements. The psychiatrist diagnosed it as an extrapyramidal side effect. Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of his presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the long-term extrapyramidal side effect of a typical antipsychotic known as tardive dyskinesia. FDA approved the VMAT2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine for its treatment.

It develops after months to years of initiation of the drug. Choreiform movements affect the mouth, lips, and tongue. In severe cases, trunks, limbs, and respiratory muscles may also be affected.

In one-third of cases, tardive dyskinesia remits within 3 months of stopping the drug, and improvement occurs over several years.

Valbenazine is metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6. Hence, it is to be used with caution with inducers or inhibitors of each. It is also avoided in hepatic impairment. 

Other options: 

Option A: Beta-blockers like propranolol are used for akathisia.

Option B: Dantrolene is used for neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic drug that is used in acute dystonia and parkinsonism.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Features
Treatment

1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine

questions.text: Which of  the following is a tool used in gene editing:
questions.solution:
Guide RNAs called CRISPRs help to selectively alter or correct DNA sequences.

CRISPR is Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats

  • CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material.
  • CRISPRs are transcribed into an RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 to a sequence leading to its cleavage.
  • Gene editing uses an artificial guide RNA that binds Cas9 and is complementary to a DNA sequence of interest and Cas9 induces the break of double-stranded DNA.

One of the first successful diseases used on experimental basis is Sickle Cell Anemia.

Other gene editing tools are:

  • Zinc-finger nucleases (ZNFs)
  • Transcription-Activator Like Effector Nucleases (TALEN)
  • Meganucleases

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna "for the development of the CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: You are monitoring a 45-year-old female patient in the postoperative ward. Her 24-hour urine output is 1.5 mL/min, serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and urine creatinine is 60 mg/dL. What is the patient's creatinine clearance rate?
questions.solution:
The creatinine clearance in this patient is 90 mL/min.

Creatinine clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which creatinine is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

 UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine (mg/dL)

PCr - Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

V - Urine volume (mL/min)

Note: The creatinine clearance is usually expressed in mL/min; hence, the preferred unit of urine volume is mL/min, which is calculated based on the 24-hour urine volume. While calculating, ensure that both the urine creatinine and serum creatinine have the same units (either mg/dL or mg/mL).

In the given question,

UCr = 60 mg/dL

PCr = 1.0 mg/dL

V  = 1.5 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

Creatinine clearance =  UCr × V ⁄ PCr ,

= (60 x 1.5)/1

= 60 x 1.5

= 90 mL/min

Creatinine is a by-product of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body fluids almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is given below. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Which of the following correctly describes the manometric evaluation of this disorder?

IRP: integrated relaxation pressure
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. It is characterized by high median IRP and absent peristalsis.

Disorders of esophageal motility can be classified as:

Disorders of esophago-gastric junction (EGJ) outflow: elevated IRP

  • Achalasia cardia: elevated IRP and peristalsis absent
  • EGJ outflow obstruction: elevated IRP and peristalsis present

Disorders of peristalsis: normal IRP

  • Absent contractility
  • Distal esophageal spasm
  • Hypercontractile esophagus

Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach. This is accompanied by relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median IRP. Moreover, there is a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to megaesophagus.

On upper GI scopy, achalasia can show accumulated saliva or food residue in the lower part of the esophagus, but is often reported normal. Upper GI scopy is an important investigation to rule out a mechanical cause of progressive dysphagia, such as a malignancy. Barium contrast studies show a hold-up of the contrast material in the distal esophagus, giving rise to the bird beak appearance.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with metabolic syndrome. Presence of which of the following additional symptoms in this patient constitutes a component of Syndrome Z?
questions.solution:
Syndrome Z is defined as a combination of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome with metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed based on the NCEP: ATP III Criteria. Three or more of the following must be present :

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL or specific medication
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively, or specific medication
  • Hypertension: Blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥85 mmHg diastolic or specific medication
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

Note: 

NCEP: ATP III - National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant was brought to you with complaints of projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, you were able to palpate a firm ovoid mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant. You suspect Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis and barium contrast studies were performed. The barium study can demonstrate all the following signs, except ______.
questions.solution:
Cervix sign is a USG finding seen in a patient with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and not a finding of barium study.

The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is ultrasound which shows hypoechoic, thickened pyloric muscle and an elongated pyloric canal. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is referred to as the cervix sign and the double-layered, hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach is called the nipple sign.

If ultrasound is inconclusive, contrast studies (barium) are performed, which may demonstrate:

  • An elongated pyloric channel (string sign),
  • A bulge of the pyloric muscle into the antrum (shoulder sign)
  • Parallel streaks of barium are seen in the narrowed channel, producing a “double tract sign.”

The ultrasound image shows the cervix sign.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with complaints of blurred vision and urinary incontinence for the past 2 months. MRI showed scattered plaques in the patient’s brain and spinal cord. Over the next few months, some of these plaques diminished in size, while others appeared in new locations. These plaques would most likely show selective loss of which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of multiple sclerosis, which is associated with selective loss of myelin.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by episodes of neurological deficits occurring at different times, due to patchy white matter lesions that involve various sites of the brain.

The condition is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath.

In most cases, the initial manifestation includes unilateral visual impairment due to the involvement of the optic nerve (optic neuritis). Involvement of the brainstem causes cranial nerve signs such as ataxia, nystagmus, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia. Spinal cord lesions give rise to motor and sensory impairment of the trunk and limbs, spasticity, and loss of bladder control. The course of MS varies, with many relapses and remissions.

Other options:

Option A: Synaptophysin is a neuroendocrine marker seen in small cell carcinoma

Option B: α-synuclein is are the inclusions found in Parkinson disease and Multiple system atrophy

Option C: β-Amyloid is associated with senile cerebral amyloidosis and seen in Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: During your internship, an ophthalmic resident asks you to observe the structures visible on gonioscopy while evaluating a glaucoma patient having Shaffers grade 2 angle width. You would be able to observe which of the following structures?

choices.text: Scleral spur and Anterior part  of Ciliary body

questions.solution:
Trabecular meshwork and Schwalbe’s line can be visualized on gonioscopy examination of glaucoma patient having Shaffers grade 2 angle width.

The angle of the anterior chamber plays an important role in the process of aqueous drainage. It is formed by,

  • Schwalbe’s line (SL)
  • Trabecular meshwork (TM)
  • Scleral spur (SS),
  • Anterior part Ciliary body (CB),
  • Root of the iris.

Clinically, these structures can be visualized by gonioscopic examination.

Shaffer’s system is most commonly used for Gonioscopic grading of the angle width.

Grade

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used for the detection of variations in DNA sequences and gene expression?
questions.solution:
DNA microarray can be used to detect DNA sequence variations.

There are various microarray techniques used in clinical practice which are described below:

DNA Microarray technique or DNA chip:

  • To the DNA chip containing known oligonucleotide sequence, flourescent labelled unknown oligonucleotide is added.
  • The computerised algorithms can decode the unknown oligonucleotide, by detecting the location of flourescent hybridization pattern on the chip.
  • This technique is used for genotyping or genome sequencing.

RNA microarray: RNA microarray can detect gene expression.

  • To the known array of oligonucleotide, flourecently labelled cDNA prepared from unknown mRNA is added, and the unknown cDNA is decoded
  • This technique is used for gene expression studies

Protein microarray:

  • Known antibodies placed on glass slide and flourescently tagged target protein added. Target protein is detected by antigen antibody interaction.
  • This technique is used in study of proteomics

questions.text: All the following drugs act via G-protein-coupled receptors, except _______.
questions.solution:
All the following drugs act via G-protein-coupled receptors, except nicotine. Nicotine acts via ion-channel-coupled receptors.

Ion-channel-coupled receptors are activated by a change in voltage, ligand binding, or membrane stretching. Activation of an ion channel receptor changes the flux of ions through it. This causes depolarization or hyperpolarization of the cell and brings about downstream effects via secondary messengers. A variety of physiological ligands and drugs act through this type of receptor. 

They are also classified as voltage-activated, ligand-activated, store-activated, stretch-activated, and temperature-activated channels.

The ligand-gated nicotinic acetylcholine receptor is an example of an ion channel coupled receptor. It is pentameric and consists of 4 different subunits (α, β, γ, and δ). The structure of nicotinic ACh is different in autonomic ganglia and neuromuscular junction. This difference is essential because rocuronium, an antagonist of this channel binds specifically to the neuromuscular junction receptor, causing only muscle relaxation without any autonomic side effects.

The table shows examples of different drugs and physiological ligands binding to different receptors.

Receptor Family Physiological ligand Drugs
GPCRs β-adrenergic 

 Epinephrine
Norepinephrine
Dopamine		 Dobutamine
Propanolol
  Muscarinic cholinergic Acetylcholine Atropine
  Eicosanoid  Prostaglandins
Leukotrienes		 Montelukast
Misoprostol
Ion channel 
receptors		 Ligand-gated Ach (M2)
GABA
5-HT		 Nicotine
Gabapentin
  Voltage-gated None Lignocaine
Verapamil

Drugs in other options act via G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). They are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times, hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors. G proteins have 3 subunits (α, β, and ɣ). In its resting state, the α subunit is bound to GDP. Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates the G protein within the cell. The α subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP, or Ca2+.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors

Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids

Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors

TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon

Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

GnRH, GHRH, TRH

Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin

Oxytocin

cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide

2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with headache, fever and vomiting. He is -2 SD below the normal weight for age and both his parents work as labourers. On examination, multiple small vesicles are present on the posterior pharyngeal wall as shown in the image.  What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by the presence of ulcerating small vesicles on the oral fauces, or palate or uvula, and the posterior pharyngeal wall as shown in the image. 

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackie A infection (a large subgroup of the enteroviruses) in children, but it can also be caused by Coxsackievirus B virus, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71. The lesions are small vesicles on the fauces and the posterior pharyngeal wall that break down to form ulcers. 

Treatment is usually supportive only, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week. 

 

Other options:

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterised by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. The most common enteroviruses causing this syndrome worldwide are Enterovirus 71 (EV71), Coxsackie A6 (CA6), Coxsackie A16 (CA16), and Coxsackie A10 (CA10). It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is in her 8th week of gestation presents with an increased frequency of vomiting which is associated with retching. She shows no signs of dehydration or volume depletion. Which of the following options would you suggest in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient presents with hyperemesis gravidarum. Mild to moderate symptoms of hyperemesis gravidarum can be treated with a combination of doxylamine and vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) which is approved for nausea and vomiting associated with pregnancy.

The antihistamine effect of doxylamine can contribute to the anti-emetic effect. The mechanism of action of pyridoxine is not known but shows a synergistic action with doxylamine. 

Unrelenting nausea and vomiting that is severe enough to cause weight loss, dehydration, ketosis, alkalosis, or hypokalemia is known as hyperemesis gravidarum. It is most commonly seen in a first pregnancy, young age, low body mass, history of migraine/motion sickness, positive family history, hydatidiform mole, low body mass, and multi-fetal gestation

The pathophysiology includes an increase in human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and estrogen levels. Relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter during pregnancy due to the elevations in estrogen and progesterone. This leads to an increased incidence of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms in pregnancy, and one symptom of GERD is nausea.

Symptoms include vomiting which is increased in frequency with retching. Epigastric pain, oliguria, and constipation may occur.
Signs include features of dehydration and ketoacidosis: Dry coated tongue, sunken eyes, acetone smell in breath, tachycardia, and hypotension.

Complications
Maternal

  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy, beriberi due to thiamine deficiency
  • Pontine myelinolysis
  • Peripheral neuritis
  • Korsakoff’s psychosis
  • Stress ulcer in the stomach
  • Mallory- Weiss syndrome
  • Jaundice, hepatic failure
  • Convulsions and coma
  • Hypoprothrombinemia due to vitamin K deficiency
  • Renal failure

Fetal - Low birth weight

Management of hyperemesis gravidarum: 

  • Mild to moderate symptoms can be treated with dietary modifications, vitamin B6 with doxylamine/diphenhydramine.
  • Severe cases need IV hydration with thiamine and parenteral ondansetron/metoclopramide/promethazine. (Option D)
  • Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV  is given in case of hypotension or in intractable vomiting. Oral prednisolone is also used in severe cases. (Option A and B)

questions.text: Which of the following antifungal drugs is matched correctly with its mechanism of action based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is an amphipathic molecule and incorporates itself in the cell membrane by actively binding to ergosterol (as shown in the image by 'C'). This results in the formation of amphotericin-induced pores which cause leakage of the intracellular contents ultimately resulting in cell death.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides immitis, Aspergillus.

Amphotericin B also has antiprotozoal action along with antifungal properties and is effective against Leishmania.

Adverse effects of amphotericin B include:

  • Infusion-related fever and chills
  • Azotemia/nephrotoxicity- all lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B
  • Renal tubular acidosis 
  • Renal wasting of potassium and magnesium
  • Hypochromic normocytic anemia- due to decreased erythropoietin production from the kidney.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 92/58 mm Hg. The abdomen appears soft, and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. For an acute arterial occlusive disease, the gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and that for management is laparotomy.

An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia. Risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are as follows:

  • Presence of an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. 
  • Previous history of ischemic heart disease

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. With the onset of bowel infarction, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools occur.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of an acute arterial occlusive disease is angiography and that for management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

Note:

A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acute pain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergency operation.

Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association with atrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen, associated with guarding and rigidity on examination.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn which is specific and diagnostic of electric burns and is found at the point of entry.  

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. It is an endogenous thermal burn due to the heat generated in the body from electricity. These marks are round or oval, shallow craters, 1-2 cm in diameter, and raised borders around part or the whole of their circumference.
The crater floor is lined by pale flattened skin. The presence of an areola of blanched skin is seen at the periphery of the joule burn, which survives death and is pathognomonic of electrical damage.

Other important features of electrical injuries:

  • Flash / Spark burns - results when there is a high voltage electrical injury and contact between metal and skin is loose. It is an exogenous burn, keratin melts in the skin producing brownish keratin nodules with pale areola. Very high voltage currents produce massive destruction of tissue with loss of extremities and rupture of organs. 
  • Crocodile burns - multiple nodules on the skin due to high voltage electrical injury over a large body surface. 
  • Bone pearls or wax drippings - heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate which is seen in X-rays of limbs as typical round dense foci. 

Other options:

Option A: Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling, and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Option B: Frost Bite:

Below is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures (-2.5° C), is only produced during life, and cannot be caused postmortem.

Option D: Scalding: Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam (image shown below).

questions.text: A young man presents with recurrent, excruciating, and stabbing type of left-sided headaches. He has been experiencing at least 1 episode every other day. It typically lasts for  an hour and occurs around the same time everyday. Examination reveals nasal congestion and a watery left eye. Which of the following can be given to manage this acute episode?
questions.solution:
A patient with repetitive brief unilateral, excruciating stabbing headaches, occurring almost at the same time everyday, associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea most probably has a diagnosis of cluster headache. The acute episodes in this condition can be treated with 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min. 

High flow oxygen is crucial in the management of an acute attack. The duration of oxygen therapy should last 15 to 20 minutes. Other treatment options for an acute attack of cluster headache include injectable/nasal form of sumatriptan. Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a form of primary headache characterized by excruciating recurrent headache, that is unilateral in nature, and typically lasting between 15 to 180 minutes. The important feature of this headache is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at the same hour each day. 

It also causes severe, unilateral retroorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen.  Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are verapamil (most common), topiramate, gabapentin, etc.

Other options:

Option A. Verapamil is the drug of choice for the prophylaxis of cluster headaches.

Option C. Lorazepam does not have a role in the management of cluster headaches.

Option D. Indomethacin is used in the management of paroxysmal hemicrania. This condition is characterized by unilateral severe headaches lasting between 2 to 45 minutes and can occur more than 5 times a day. Unlike cluster headache, paroxysmal hemicrania has a very good response to indomethacin. 

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua
   Cluster headache Paroxysmal hemicrania   SUNCT/SUNA
Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
