questions.text: A new variant of SARS-COV2 strain has been detected in UK which is more virulent . This variant has been detected by
questions.solution:
The new variant (H69/V70) that has been detected is due to deletion of histidine and valine at 69 and 70 positions. It has been detected by molecular typing.

A virus is classified into a species based on multiple different characteristics. Based on physicochemical characteristics, symmetry, type of genetic material, etc. But even within a species of virus, considerable changes may occur in its structure due to genetic mutations which may impact its clinical presentation, immunity against it, diagnostic test or treatment. For example different strains of the coronovirus species has earlier caused Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV, China-2003) and Middle east respiratory syndrome(MERS-Cov, 2012-Gulf). This time we have SARS-CoV2 as a new strain. Each strain may have ongoing mutations which maybe silent (not affecting symptoms, spread or diagnosis) or maybe significant termed as variants.

The new UK variant (termed as V202012/01) is believed to be due to deletion of nucleotides causing loss of histidine and valine near the spike protein domain. This S-gene encoding it, is one amongst the many targets used to detect the virus via PCR. This variant is believed to have more transmissibility.

Molecular typing thus involves genomic sequencing of the organism and based on how much related or different it is, classifying it to a particular species, strain and variant.

Other methods are usually used in typing of bacterial strains.

Biotyping involves classification of bacteria based on their biochemical properties. 

Serotyping essentially refers to the kind of antibodies produced against the organism. Antibodies produced against one organism are similar because of similar antigenic structure. 

Ribotyping involves sequencing of the ribosomal genes and based on the pattern, classifying into species.

questions.text: On examination of a 26-year-old man, tachycardia was observed during inspiration. The doctor told him that it is respiratory sinus arrhythmia. Which of the following mechanism explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The above mechanism is explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

Tachycardia, in response to increased venous return, is suggestive of Bainbridge reflex. During inspiration, there is an increased venous return due to reduced intrathoracic pressure. This leads to right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria transmit the afferent signals via the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. The efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to result in tachycardia and increase the strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option B: Bezold–Jarisch reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing. It is seen in cases of myocardial ischemia and reperfusion due to the increased synthesis of oxygen free radicals. 

Option C: Cushing reflex: When there is increased intracranial pressure, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. 

Option D: J reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) due to hyperinflation of the lung causes reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia and hypotension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with complaints of double vision, frequent falls, and numbness of both hands. On examination, the radial pulses were not palpable, but the femoral pulses were palpable. An aortic arch angiogram was done, which revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the aortic angiogram showing areas of stenosis in multiple great vessels arising from the aortic arch is suggestive of Takayasu's arteritis, also known as the pulseless disease.

Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities. 

Disease pathology is characterized by transmural fibrous thickening of the aorta. The branches of the aortic arch, when involved, are markedly narrowed or even obliterated, causing absent pulses in the upper extremities. 

In some cases, there may also be involvement of other vessels such as the pulmonary, coronary, and renal arteries.

Histopathology:

  • Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia. 
  • Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy medial necrosis.
  • Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates across all layers of the vessel wall.

Other options:

Option a- Polyarteritis Nodosa is a vasculitis affecting small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It is often seen in renal and visceral vessels, with exception of the pulmonary arteries. Clinical features result from ischemia and infarction of affected tissues and organs.

Option c- Aortic dissection occurs when blood separates the laminar planes of the medial layer to form a blood-filled channel within the aortic wall. The clinical features include sudden onset excruciating pain, which radiates to the back and moves downwards as the dissection progresses.

Shown below are the axial and coronal views of chest CT with IV contrast highlighting a descending aortic dissection:

 

Option d- Kawasaki Disease is an acute, febrile disease seen during infancy and childhood. It usually involves large to medium-sized vessels. Clinical features include conjunctival and oral erythema, blistering, edema of the hands and feet, erythema of the palms and soles, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement. It is associated with many cardiovascular sequelae including coronary arteria ectasia and coronary artery aneurysms.

The image shows an aneurysm of left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery due to Kawasaki disease:

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presented with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea.  On auscultation, a holosystoloic murmur was heard over the left 5th intercostal space, in the mid-clavicular line. Which of the following left ventricular pressure-volume loops is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Holosystolic murmur heard over the left 5th intercostal space in mid-clavicular line is suggestive of mitral regurgitation. The pressure-volume loop represented as 'D' corresponds to mitral regurgitation.

Changes in the pressure-volume loop in mitral regurgitation:

  • At the beginning of the systole, there is no true isovolumetric contraction.
  • As the ventricle begins to contract, the blood flows back (regurgitates) into the left atrium. As a result, the afterload on the left ventricle is reduced.
  • This results in larger stroke volume, and smaller end-systolic volume.
  • There is no true isovolumetric relaxation, because, as long as the intraventricular pressure is more than the atrial pressure, the blood continues to flow back into the left atrium.
  • During diastole, the increased left atrial pressure causes increased ventricular filling, thus increasing the end-diastolic volume.

The LV pressure-volume loops shown corresponds to:

A. Aortic stenosis: The aortic stenosis causes an increase in the ventricular afterload. This leads to a decrease in the stroke volume and a consequent increase in the end-systolic volume. In chronic cases, the ventricle hypertrophies and this decreased compliance presents as an increase in the end-diastolic pressure. The pressure-volume loop is elevated and steeper in this case.

B. Mitral stenosis: The reduced ventricular filling in mitral stenosis causes a reduction in end-diastolic volume (ventricular preload) and consequently the stroke volume. A fall in the afterload due to decreased stroke volume decreases the end-diastolic volume but is not enough to compensate for the fall in end-diastolic volume.

C. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation and backflow of blood into the ventricle cause an increase in the end-diastolic volume (ventricular filling) and thus increased stroke volume. There are no true isovolumetric phases as blood flows through the regurgitant valve whenever a pressure gradient exists across it.

D. Mitral regurgitation

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: All of the following are transcribed by the RNA polymerase that is highly sensitive to alpha amanitin except:
questions.solution:
rRNA is synthesized by RNA polymerase I which is insensitive to alpha-amanitin.

RNA polymerase II is highly sensitive to alpha amanitin. Amanitin inhibits the translocation of RNA polymerase II during phospho-diester bond formation. RNA polymerase II produces mRNA, lncRNA, snRNA & miRNA

RNA Polymerase III shows intermediate sensitivity to alpha amanitin

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

questions.text:
Which among the following incisions is made during LSCS?

LSCS- Lower segment Cesarean section
questions.solution:
Pfannenstiel incision, represented by 4 in the image above is the most common incision made in lower section caesarean delivery.

It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curbvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The various incisions mentioned in the image are:

Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.

Incision '2' - The Maylard incision is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.

Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with complaints of red-colored urine in the morning. The CBC revealed anemia, low serum iron, and an elevated reticulocyte count. Flow cytometry of blood revealed the following finding. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The flow cytogram shows a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (in the left lower quadrant), characteristic of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), which is caused due to mutation in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene.

PIGA encodes for an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.  It is the only hemolytic anemia caused by an acquired genetic defect.

The glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) is a phospholipid that helps certain proteins anchor to the cell membrane. Inactivation of PIGA causes a deficiency of these GPI-linked proteins. PIGA gene is X-linked and is subject to lyonization. As a result, a mutation that occurs even in a single hematopoietic stem cell may affect all of its clonal progeny (red cells, white cells, and platelets) that are deficient in GPI- linked proteins.

In PNH, the blood cells are deficient in three GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: 

  • Decay accelerating factor, or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Disease manifestations:

  • Red cells deficient in GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by complement. It results in intravascular hemolysis, which is caused by the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex. The RBCs have a tendency to lyse during the night due to a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep.
  • The loss of heme iron in the urine leads to iron deficiency anemia.
  • In about 40% of the patients, there is venous thrombosis, involving the hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins. Thrombosis is the leading cause of disease-related death in PNH.
     

Diagnosis - Flow cytometry:

The diagnosis of PNH is made by flow cytometry. It shows a population of red cells that is deficient in both CD55 and CD59 (left-lower quadrant in the image below). Also, a second population of red cells, which are derived from residual normal hematopoietic stem cells may be seen, which are positive for CD55 and CD59 (right-upper quadrant in the image below).

Other options:

b. PML/RARA gene mutation is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia.

c. Mutaionin tyrosine kinase JAK2 is associated with polycythemia vera. It is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets.

d. BCR-ABL gene mutation is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with acute kidney injury was referred to you for further evaluation.  After estimating urine output (UO) and the creatinine clearance (CCL), the child is found to be in Renal Failure according to pRIFLE Criteria. All the following criteria holds true for this child except _______
questions.solution:
Persistent failure >3 months is a feature of End-Stage renal disease.

Renal failure in children is defined as eCCl( estimated creatinine clearance) decrease by 75% or eCCl < 35ml/min/1.73m2 or Urine output <0.3ml/kg/hr for 24 hours or anuria for 12 hours.

Acute kidney injury (AKI), is a clinical syndrome in which a sudden deterioration in renal function results in the inability of the kidneys to maintain fluid and electrolyte homeostasis. 

Pediatric-Modified Rifle (pRIFLE) Criteria includes,

Criteria Estimated Creatine Clearance (eCCL) Urine Output
Risk

eCCl decrease by 25%

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for 8 hr
Injury

eCCl decrease by 50%

<0.5 mL/kg/hr for 16 hr
Failure

eCCl decrease by 75%

<0.3 mL/kg/hr for 24 hr

or Anuric for 12 hr
Loss

Persistent failure >4 wk

  
End-Stage

End-stage renal disease

(persistent failure >3 months)

questions.text: A patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia was started on fludarabine. After 36 hours of starting the therapy, she developed abdominal pain, hematuria, vomiting, and severe muscle cramps. The laboratory investigations reveal hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following is not done in the management of this condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) as the patient developed abdominal pain, hematuria, and muscle cramps with hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia following the administration of fludarabine. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is not done in the management of this condition.

Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate increases uric acid solubility, but a high pH decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate, and increases the likelihood of intratubular crystallization.

It is caused due to destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating cells. It is seen following treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, etc. TLS is also caused following the administration of fludarabine, glucocorticoids, hormonal agents such as letrozole and tamoxifen, and monoclonal antibodies such as rituximab and gemtuzumab.

Metabolic abnormalities in tumor lysis syndrome are 

  • Hyperuricemia-It occurs due to the increased turnover of nucleic acids. These may get precipitated in the renal tubules leading to renal failure.
  • Hyperkalemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular potassium ions
  • Hyperphosphatemia- occurs due to the release of intracellular phosphate stores
  • Hypocalcemia- occurs as a result of increased levels of phosphate
  • Acidosis may also develop.

Management of TLS consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration with normal or 1/2 normal saline. Febuxostat and rasburicase are the other drugs that can be used in the management of high uric acid levels. If the patient develops renal failure, then hemodialysis is necessary.

questions.text: A patient complained of fever with a mild headache associated with difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a patient with fever, headache, difficulty in swallowing, and throat examination findings of swollen glands, whitish membrane over tonsils, and gram stain showing a rod-shaped organism arranged in Chinese letter pattern is faucial diphtheria.

The condition is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. It is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

Image below shows pseudomembrane over tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).  

Other options:

Option A: Gas gangrene is caused by Clostridium perfringens. It usually occurs when the organism invades the wound infections. Gram staining demonstrates gram-positive bacilli with spores as shown below.

Option B: Vincent's angina is a spirochetal infection and is a differential diagnosis of a membrane in the throat. It is caused by Leptotrichia buccalis (earlier known as Fusobacterium) and is demonstrated on gram stain as gram-negative curved rods with pointed ends. They appear as fusiform and spiral shaped bacilli as shown below.

Option D: Streptococcal pharyngitis usually doesn't cause membrane formation and appear as gram positive cocci in chains as shown in image below.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with HIV presents to the ER with fever, headache and generalised tonic-clonic seizures. MRI is done for the patient which is given below and the patient is given the standard treatment for 4-6 weeks. However, the CD4 counts are still low and secondary prophylaxis is continued. When will you stop the secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

choices.text: When CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months
When CD4+ T cell counts are >100/μL for 6 months
When CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 weeks
When CD4+ T cell counts are >100/μL for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
Cerebral toxoplasmosis is the most likely diagnosis, favoured by presentation with seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin is the standard treatment for 4-6 weeks. Secondary prophylaxis/maintenance therapy is given to prevent recurrence if CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL and is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months. 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Focal neurological deficits
    • Seizure
    • Hemiparesis
    • Aphasia
  • Cerebral edema
    • Confusion
    • Lerthargy
    • Coma

Diagnosis is usually based on clinical and MRI findings:

  • Usually multiple lesions in multiple locations, however, in some cases a single lesion may be present.
  • These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI.
  • Sometimes an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring, this so-called eccentric target sign is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis.
  • Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnoses:

  • Primary CNS lymphoma - usually solitary, solid and subependymal lesion
  • CNS TB
  • Fungal or bacterial abscess 

Treatment of toxoplasmosis involves:

  • Standard treatment: Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 
  • Alternative regimens:
    • Clindamycin + pyrimethamine
    • Atovaquone + pyrimethamine
    • Azithromycin +pyrimethamine + rifabutin

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis: Prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection,given to patients with IgG antibody to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL.
    A single double strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given (offers primary protection against P. jirovecii also) 
  • Secondary prophylaxis /maintenance therapy: Prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts <200 cells/μL.
    Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin is given.
    Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months. 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

 

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient with diabetes has uncontrolled blood glucose levels despite taking metformin. Her HbA1C levels are 8.5. She wants to lose weight and is compliant with the medications. Which of the following drugs is best suited for her?
questions.solution:
The best-suited medication for this patient is liraglutide. It will cause weight loss and improve blood glucose levels in this patient.

Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that is administered subcutaneously. It increases insulin and decreases glucagon secretion, thus causing more uptake of glucose into extrahepatic tissues. Furthermore, it slows gastric emptying and improves satiety. It thus causes weight loss. Other GLP-1 analogs also have a similar mechanism of action, and include exenatide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide. Semaglutide is the only GLP-1 analog available as an oral formulation.

There have been reports of an association of pancreatitis with GLP-1 analogs. GLP-1 receptor is also expressed on thyroid C cells and these drugs have a theoretical possibility of stimulating these cells. Thus, GLP-1 analogs are best avoided in patients with medullary carcinoma of thyroid or with a predisposition to pancreatitis.

Other options:

Vildagliptin (option B) belongs to dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP-IV) inhibitors. They act by inhibiting the breakdown of endogenous GLP-1 and prolonging its action. While it increases insulin and decreases glucagon secretion, it does not affect gastric emptying and satiety. Thus, it does not affect the body weight. 

Glimepiride (option C) belongs to sulfonylureas. It increases insulin secretion from the β cells of the pancreas. It causes weight gain and thus is not preferred for this patient.

Subcutaneous insulin (option D) is a reserve drug in type II diabetes mellitus, used in the following scenarios:

  • HbA1C > 10 on presentation
  • Lean patients or those who have had severe weight loss due to diabetes
  • Underlying hepatic and renal diseases which prevent the use of oral antidiabetic drugs
  • Acute illness or hospitalized patient

It also causes weight gain and thus is not preferred in this patient.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student with cystic fibrosis developed acute onset cough which was worsening progressively, along with wheezing and increased sputum production. A probable diagnosis of of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) has been made. Which of the following is the incorrect option regarding the serological diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in a patient with cystic fibrosis. ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the detection of aspergillum-specific IgE or positive skin prick test and serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml. IgG antibodies to Aspergillus flavus are seen in chronic aspergillus sinusitis.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis:

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonisation of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis and respiratory compromise.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or CF typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuated mucus in airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test in response to A.fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He gives influenza pandemics as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Influenza pandemics are an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years.  Examples of the cyclic trend include influenza and rubella. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to defend communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is another type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite. Some epidemiologists consider this a form of cyclic trend.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: While using the base exchange process to reduce the hardness level of the large water supply in a locality, purified water with zero hardness levels was produced. Which of the following should be done next?

choices.text: Water should be mixed with a part of raw water
Water must be passed under UV light for 12 hours
Water must be passed through Ultrafilters

questions.solution:
Following the base exchange process, a part of raw water is mixed with the purified water to have the required hardness. This is because water with zero hardness level is corrosive. The base exchange process using Permutit (a complex compound of sodium, aluminum, and silica) removes both temporary and permanent hardness.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with intermittent jaundice, fatigue, and weight loss. He has a history of ulcerative colitis and also complains of pruritus and abdominal pain. Bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels are raised. MRCP image of the patient shows multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts as shown below. What is the most appropriate management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a man with a history of ulcerative colitis presenting with intermittent jaundice, fatigue, pruritus, and raised bilirubin and ALP levels. MRCP shows intrahepatic stricturing with alternating normal and dilated segments of bile ducts. These findings are typical for primary sclerosing cholangitis. Surgical resection of the extrahepatic part is the most appropriate management in this case.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy for primary sclerosing cholangitis. Surgical management with resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with sclerosing cholangitis with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by inflammatory strictures involving the intra and extra-hepatic biliary tree. It eventually leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis.

The common age group of primary sclerosing cholangitis is 30-45 years. Men are affected twice as commonly as women. It is associated with other conditions such as ulcerative colitis (seen in two-thirds of cases), Riedel’s thyroiditis, and retroperitoneal fibrosis. There is also a strong predisposition to cholangiocarcinoma, gall bladder carcinoma, and colorectal carcinoma. Thus, annual screening for these cancers is mandatory. 

The clinical features include intermittent jaundice, fatigue, weight loss, pruritus, and abdominal pain. The bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels are raised.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERCP) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both the intra- and extra-hepatic biliary tree.

questions.text: A 58-year-old pathologist presented to the Dermatology OPD with the following condition, which he described to be painless and non-tender but has been gradually progressing on the dorsum of the hand for the past 3 months. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The causative organism invades through the exogenous route
Seen in patients with poor immunity

questions.solution:
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is seen in patients with moderate to high degree of immunity.

Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis or Warty Tuberculosis is caused by exogenous inoculation of M. tuberculosis into the skin through open wounds or abrasions. It is also known as ‘anatomist’s warts’, ‘prosector’s warts’ and ‘verruca necrogenica’.  It occurs in a person who is already sensitized by previous exposure to TB. Thus it is a form of post-primary TB. Patients having this condition have good immunity against TB. Because of good immunity, they are effective in clearing the TB bacilli and thus, the lesion is paucibacillary. This condition is treated with anti-tubercular drugs.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of cutaneous tuberculosis

The classification of cutaneous tuberculosis is based on the mode of acquisition.

Type Pathophysiology AFB

Exogenous

Through broken skin or mucosa
Tuberculous chancre Occurs in individuals with no previous sensitization to TB Multibacillary
Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity Paucibacillary

Endogenous

Direct spread from a focus of infection
Scrofuloderma Contiguous spread from affected parts like lymph nodes, joints Multibacillary
Periorificial tuberculosis Autoinoculation at mucocutaneous borders from infected secretions Multibacillary

Hematogenous

Spread from a distant primary focus of TB
Acute cutaneous miliary tuberculosis Occurs in severe disseminated TB Multibacillary
Lupus vulgaris Occurs in previously sensitized individuals with strong immunity. Mostly hematogenous spread, sometimes exogenous. Paucibacillary
Tuberculous gumma/ abscess Occurs in immunocompromised patients Multibacillary

Tuberculids

Hypersensitivity reaction
Lichen scrofulosorum (micropapular) Hematogenous spread of M. tuberculosis antigens to the skin causes type III hypersensitivity which triggers type IV reaction with granuloma formation Very rarely seen
Papulonecrotic tuberculid
Erythema induratum of Bazin (nodular)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to you a week after rejoining school after lockdown with fever and the following facial appearance. Which of the following is true regarding this?

choices.text: Patient is non-infectious during rash appearance
PCR assay should be done to confirm the diagnosis
Treatment with Topical steroids is needed

questions.solution:
The given image shows the classical slapped cheek appearance of erythema infectiosum caused by parvovirus B19. During the rash period, the patient is non-infectious..

Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus and usually presents as a respiratory infection, with an erythematous maculopapular rash and arthralgia. The rash starts as prominent erythema of the cheek, popularly known as a slapped cheek appearance. The rash further spreads to the trunk and limbs followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. It is a clinical diagnosis not requiring investigations usually. However in case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done. It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

Other manifestations of  Parvovirus B19

  • It induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients.
  • Infection during the 2nd or 3rd trimester of pregnancy leads to non-immune fetal hydrops.

Cutaneous manifestations of COVID

  • Morbilliform rash - most common cutaneous manifestation. Seen on trunk usually after COVID recovery.
  • Pernio (chillblain) like acral lesions/ COVID toes- erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules seen without cold exposure. On fingers, toes, lateral aspect of fingers or toes.
  • Livedo reticularis like vascular lesions
  • Retiform purpura/ Necrotic vascular lesions
  • Urticaria
  • Varicella like vesicular eruptions
  • Multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children

 

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: As a first-year anesthesia resident, you intubate a patient for general anesthesia. After placement of the endotracheal tube, your senior performs capnography, which reveals the following graph. What is the likely possibility?
questions.solution:
The likely possibility causing the above capnographic waveform is oesophagal intubation. In oesophageal intubation, there is an initial peak of the graph showing end-tidal CO2 due to some amount of swallowed expired air present in the stomach. Subsequently, the graph approaches zero due to wash out of this swallowed air in a few breaths.

Capnography is the measurement and graphical representation of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide at the airway opening. It uses the technique of infrared light absorption by CO2 by the principle of Beer-Lambert law.

The presence of carbon dioxide in the expired air reveals the functioning of the patient's ventilation, pulmonary blood flow and aerobic metabolism. Thus, it can be used to monitor the correct placement of an airway device, the adequacy of cardiac output, as well as the integrity of a breathing circuit. Capnography can be used to: 

  • Confirm tracheal intubation
  • Assess tracheal tube and tracheostomy patency and position
  • Monitor adequate ventilator support
  • Percutaneous tracheostomy placement
  • Monitoring patients with increased intracranial pressure
  • Monitoring response to treatment of bronchospasm
  • Estimation of cardiac output
  • During cardiac arrest

The time capnogram is a type of capnography that displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases. A normal time capnograph is shown below: 

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was kidnapped and held captive for 2 months until she was rescued. However, it was observed that the girl developed positive feelings towards her kidnapper, and sympathized with his character, and the situations that made him kidnap her. Which of the following defense mechanisms has the girl most likely developed?
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism that the girl has developed is known as introjection.

Introjection refers to unconscious internalisation of the qualities or characters of an object or a person, with the goal of ensuring closeness to, and the constant presence of, the object/person.

The classic example of this is Stockholm syndrome, where victims who were kidnapped or held captive, may develop positive feelings towards the kidnapper, understand their character, emotions, and start sympathizing with them. They internalize the character of the aggressor as one's own character.  As they do so, they may even develop fear towards the police who come to rescue them and even try to escape from the police, and co-operate with the kidnapper's actions.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: You notice the following finding at the limbus of the cornea during the ophthalmic examination of a 10-year-old boy diagnosed with vernal keratoconjunctivitis. These white dots usually consists of _______.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Horner–Trantas seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects young boys

VKC can clinically manifest as

  • Limbal VKC shows opacification of the limbus with nodules ( Horner–Trantas spots) or a wall of gelatinous thickening at the limbus. Presence of Horner–Trantas dots at the limbus is a very characteristic feature of Limbal VKC.
  • Palpebral VKC shows hypertrophied papillae over the upper palpebral conjunctiva. Eosinophilic leucocytes are present in them in great numbers. The color is bluish-white (like milk), and this appearance may also be seen over the lower palpebral conjunctiva.
  • Mixed form

Treatment of VKC:

  • Topical anti-inflammatory therapy:
    • Topical steroids
    • Mast cell stabilizers
    • Antihistaminics
    • Topical cyclosporins
    • Tacrolimus
    • NSAID eye drops
  • Topical lubricating and mucolytics
  • Systemic therapy with antihistaminic and steroids

questions.text: A 78-year-old man was found to be dead at his apartment after his neighbors complained of no signs or replies to their calls. He was found to have lost a lot of weight,  thinned out, and had no food at his house. There were no signs of robbery or physical struggle. Any attempt to contact his children was not useful and it was decided that post mortem autopsy be done to confirm the cause of death. If starvation is the cause, as suspected, which of the following findings will not be seen on autopsy?
questions.solution:
In starvation, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. So bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder and gets distended.

Starvation:

  • Feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30–48 hours.
  • Person can survive for 10–12 days without food and water and for 6–8 weeks without food alone.
  • Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal.
  • Loss of 70–90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal.
  • There is reduction in weight and size of all organs except brain.

Other features of starvation:

  • Dry, lustreless hair
  • Brittle nails 
  • Pale skin with edema around ankles
  • Loss of fat in subcutaneous tissue, in the omentum 
    (sparing of fat in female breast and orbit till later)
  • Atrophy of muscles and darkening due to lipochrome
  • The heart is atrophied with empty chambers
  • Pale and collapsed lung
  • Shrunken liver with necrosis
  • Tissue paper-like intestinal mucosa
  • Empty bladder

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with the following condition of toenails. The discoloration  spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later the entire nail was affected. Gradually, the entire nail became brittle and separated from the nailbed. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of the affected nail, points to a diagnosis of Tinea unguium.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many other fungi may be causative.

Clinically, yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described:

  • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - Most common form
  • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
  • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  • Endonyx onychomycosis
  • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
  • Mixed onychomycosis

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

Mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis are treated topically with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine 

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis. Oral Terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernail infection and 3 months (12 weeks)  for toenail infection.

           FIRST LINE DRUG                   DURATION
 Oral Terbinafine - 250mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks.

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral Itraconazole- 400mg/day for 1week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months

Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is the second-line drug.

Other options:

Option A: In psoriasis, irregular pitting of nails with subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis is seen:

Option C: Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discolouration of the nail. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states such as renal failure:

 

Option D: In chronic arsenic poisoning, nails become irregularly thick and develop transverse white lines called Aldrich-Mees lines:

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)
  • Mesothelioma
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congenital heart disease, Endocarditis

Nail finding

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with complaints of difficulty in initiating and maintaining the stream of urination. Ultrasonography reveals an increase in prostate size. You start him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP. Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Doxazosin - Apoptosis promoting effect on prostate
  • Alfuzosin - Specifically created for BHP, not used as an antihypertensive

Other uses of α1 receptor antagonists include the management of hypertension and short-term management of congestive heart failure.

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: COVID-19 vaccine will be a form of _______ against COVID 19
questions.solution:
Immunization/vaccination is a form of primary prevention.

Primary prevention are designed to promote health or to protect against specific disease 'agents' and hazards in the environment.

Examples include immunization, sanitation, protection of food and water supplies, protection against occupational hazards.

questions.text: A patient presents with a loss of taste sensation on the marked 'A' region of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The area marked as A in the above image is in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. The nerve likely to be affected is the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Nerves mediating the taste sensation in different parts of the tongue: 

  • Chorda tympani branch of facial nerve - anterior 2/3rd of the tongue 
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve -
    • Posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
    • Circumvallate papillae
    • Post-sulcal part of the tongue
    • Palatoglossal arches
    • Oropharynx
  • Internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve - posterior most (vallecullae, epiglottis) tongue.

The glossopharyngeal nerve is the IX cranial nerve. It leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath. Its branches are tympanic, carotid, pharyngeal, muscular, tonsillar, and lingual branches.

Nerve supply by glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Sensory fibers to the uvula, tympanic cavity, pharyngotympanic tube, tonsils, fauces, nasopharynx, and posterior 1/3rd of the tongue
  • Motor fibers to the stylopharyngeus muscle
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland
  • Gustatory fibers for the postsulcal part of the tongue

Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. These plexes mainly supply the pharynx. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion. 

Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve examinations include:

  • Observe the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula at rest and with phonation (“aah”).
  • By assessing the strength of the cough.

Infection, malignancy, and postoperative inflammation of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa will cause referred pain in the ear. This is conducted through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

questions.text: A new resident doctor administers anesthetic in the case of brain tumor surgery. A rise in intracranial pressure is seen. Which of the following anesthetic might be implicated?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is known to increase cerebral blood flow and intracranial tension. It is hence avoided in surgery of space-occupying lesions of the brain.

 

Other options 

Midazolam is a benzodiazepine and does not cause a rise in ICT. It may be administered along with ketamine, to prevent the rise in ICT seen with ketamine.

Propofol is an IV anesthetic causing pain on injection. It however doesn't cause a rise in ICT.

Etomidate also doesn't cause a rise in ICT.

questions.text: There are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells. How is this phenomenon best explained?
questions.solution:
The statement 'there are more osmotically active particles in the cells than in interstitial or intercellular fluid due to the presence of non-diffusible charged proteins in the cells' is explained by the Donnan effect.

The Donnan effect states that, in the presence of a non-diffusible ion such as negatively charged protein, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

For example, let's consider that there are two compartments X and Y, containing potassium and chloride ions, which are diffusible, and negatively charged proteins in compartment X.

As the protein is non-diffusible, the potassium and chloride ions diffuse such that their concentration ratios are equal.

The Donnan effect on the distribution of ions has three effects:

  • Due to the presence of non-diffusible negatively charged proteins in the cells, there are more osmotically active particles in cells than in interstitial or inter-cellular fluid. The presence of more osmotically active particles drags water into the cells, which may eventually cause the cells to swell and rupture. This is prevented by the presence of the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which pumps the ions back out of the cells.
  • At equilibrium, the distribution of the diffusible ions is asymmetric. This causes an electrical difference exists across the membrane.
  • There are more proteins in the plasma than in the interstitial fluid. The resultant Donnan effect is responsible for the movement of the ions across the capillary wall.

Other options:

Option A: Nernst equation is used to determine the magnitude of equilibrium potential. Equilibrium potential is the membrane potential at which an ion exists in equilibrium across the membrane.

Nernst equation for chloride ions:

Where,

Cli - Chloride concentration inside the cell

Clo – Chloride concentration outside the cell

Option C: Henderson–Hasselbalch equation is used for the calculation of pH of a buffer solution.

pH = pKa + log[A−]/[HA]

where, pKa is the acid dissociation constant, A- is the free acid concentration, HA is the bound acid concentration.

Option D: Fick’s Law of Diffusion:

The magnitude of the diffusing tendency from one region to another is directly proportional to the cross-sectional area across which diffusion is taking place and the concentration gradient, or chemical gradient. Thus,

where J is the net rate of diffusion, D is the diffusion coefficient, A is the area, and Δc/Δx is the concentration gradient. The minus sign indicates the direction of diffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is a substrate for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, propionyl CoA acts as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. Though it is an energy-consuming process, it is necessary to maintain blood glucose levels. It is needed as a fuel for erythrocytes and brain.

Other substrates for gluconeogenesis include:

  • Oxaloacetate is a direct precursor of phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Pyruvate, an α-keto acid that can be converted to glucose.
  • Glucogenic amino acids like alanine, cysteine, glycine, etc, by the actions of transaminases, yield pyruvate.  
  • Lactate, obtained from anaerobic glycolysis, is released from skeletal muscles and RBCs into the blood. It is taken up by the liver via Cori cycle to be oxidized to pyruvate, to eventually synthesize glucose.
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue is converted to dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the liver, which itself is an intermediate of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Acetyl CoA and compounds that give rise to acetyl CoA alone like acetoacetate, lysine, and leucine cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose. This is because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. These compounds give rise to ketone bodies instead.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

questions.text: A transgender person who has undergone a gender transformation from male to female would like to sound more like a female. Which of the following phonosurgeries would be advised in this case?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the vocal cords is the phonosurgery to elevate the voice pitch which transforms male character voice to female.

If someone who has undergone gender transformation from female to male would like to lower the voice pitch, a phono surgery involving shortening/relaxation of the vocal cord is advised.

Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presented with headache and blurred vision. She is a known case of hypertension. Renal arteriography shows segmental stenosis, resembling a string of beads. Which of the following histological types is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a hypertensive woman presenting with headache, blurred vision, and renal artery angiography showing segmental stenosis is suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common histological subtype of fibromuscular dysplasia is medial fibroplasia. 

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a hyperplastic disorder characterized by focal irregular thickening in medium and large muscular arteries. It usually involves renal, carotid, iliac, and subclavian arteries. It is predominantly seen in female patients.

Histologically, fibromuscular dysplasia is classified into three main types based on the arterial layer involved:

  • Intimal fibroplasia (focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal). It is further subdivided into:
    • Medial fibroplasia (most common)
    • Perimedial fibroplasia
    • Medial hyperplasia
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial fibroplasia is the most common type. It is characterized by regions of thick fibrodysplastic media alternating with regions of thinned media. In the renal arteries, this can be a cause of renovascular hypertension. 

On angiography, the vessels are said to have a “string of beads” appearance as shown below:

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with a deformity in the left lower limb which had developed over time.  The X-ray showed shepherd's crook deformity.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the presence of Shepherd's crook deformity are suggestive of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which the area of trabecular bone is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue. If this occurs in the weight-bearing bones like the femur, it will lead to the bending of bones called ‘Shepherd’s crook' deformity. 

Patients usually present in childhood or adolescence with pain, limp, deformity, or pathological fracture. Occasionally the bone disorder is associated with cafe-au-lait spots on the skin and in some girls with precocious sexual development (Albright's syndrome).

questions.text: On an X-ray of the ankle joint of a patient, an incidental finding is seen which is marked in the x-ray shown below. What could be this finding?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the X-ray is Os trigonum which is an accessory bone seen behind the talus.

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus.
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon. Also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

Fabella is a sesamoid bone. It is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle. Radiological mage of fabella is given below.

Rider's bone is an example of heterotopic calcification involving the Adductor longus muscle.

questions.text: Select a correct and rational drug prescription for the given hypertensive patients

choices.text: A 28 year old male with gout - Chlorthalidone
A 36 year old male with migraine - Propanolol
A multigravida 16 weeks of gestation with known case of hypertension - Captopril
A 54 year old lady with heart failure on digoxin - Verapamil

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Propanolol in a case of migraine is a rational prescription as it might be useful in preventing migraine attacks.
 
Other options:
Chlorthalidone (thiazide diuretics) should be avoided in a case of gout because of hyperuricemia induced by thiazides.
Captopril (ACE inhibitor) should be avoided in pregnancy because of its known teratogenic effect
Verapamil (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) should be avoided in HF due to the worsening of HF or along with statin or digoxin due to decreased metabolism and toxicity.
 
Conditions associated with hypertension

Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

questions.text: A 35-year-old female comes to the orthopedic OPD with pain and paresthesia along the ulnar aspect of her arms. The orthopedic resident asks the patient to abduct the shoulders to 90 degrees and flex the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is then made to open and close the hand slowly for three minutes. Which of the following test is being done?
questions.solution:
The test which is performed is Roo's test to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome, the test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side. 

Thoracic outlet syndrome is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicles, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

The provocative tests for thoracic outlet syndrome include Adson's test, Halstead's manoeuvre, Wright's test, and Roos's test.

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: A patient visited the OPD with multiple, painless masses on his hand as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows verruca vulgaris or common warts and the most common causative organism of it is HPV-2 (human papilloma virus -2). These common warts are also closely related to HPV 1, 4, 27, and 57.

Viral warts show acanthosis and hyperkeratosis, usually with the characteristic koilocytosis of upper keratinocytes. Most of them also show papillomatosis.

Appearance: Common warts present as firm papules with a rough horny surface.

Site: They can occur anywhere on the skin but most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers. In children they can be seen on the knees. New lesions can also occur along the sites of trauma known as pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.

Usually asymptomatic. 

Management:

  • Salicylic acid with or without lactic acid - first line treatment
  • Cryotherapy - second line treatment

Other options: 

Options A and C: HPV-6 and HPV-11 are associated with anogenital warts and laryngeal papillomas.

Option B: HPV-16 is associated with anogenital warts and cervical carcinoma. 

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV 6 and 11
