questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair of neurotransmitter and precursor.
questions.solution:
Option A is incorrect. Melatonin is a metabolic derivative of tryptophan, not tyrosine.

The important tryptophan metabolites are serotonin (option C) and melatonin. Tryptophan is hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase to form 5-hydroxy tryptophan. This undergoes decarboxylation to form serotonin or 5-hydroxy tryptamine.

Serotonin is further converted to melatonin in the pineal gland via acetylation and methylation. S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) acts as the methyl donor. Melatonin is involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Other options:

Option B: Glutamate is decarboxylated by l-glutamate decarboxylase to form the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA.

Option D: The catecholamines are synthe­sized from tyrosine. Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosine hydroxylase to form 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine or DOPA. DOPA is decarboxylated to dopamine, which is hydroxylated to form norepinephrine.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: The agglutination test of a 2-day-old baby born to an Rh-negative mother is given below. The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of?
questions.solution:
The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of the D antigen. The given agglutination test shows agglutination only with the Rh antiserum. The Rh antigen in the given options is the D antigen.

From the given agglutination test, the blood group of the baby is O-positive, as there is agglutination with the Rh antiserum, but no agglutination with A or B antisera. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. 

In an Rh-positive individual, the presence of the D antigen is specific and carries antigenic properties responsible for hemolytic reactions. 

There are six common types of Rh antigens (C, D, E and c, d, e) each of which is called an Rh factor. The type D antigen is more antigenic than the others. Individuals who have the type D antigen are said to be Rh-positive, whereas those who don't have it are Rh-negative.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

 

Blood type Genotype

Agglutinogen

Agglutinins
A AA or OA A Anti-B
B BB or OB B Anti-A
O OO - Anti-A, Anti-B
AB AB A, B -

 

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. Absence of this H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

However, the O blood group has an H antigen. Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.  

Other less common systems of blood grouping include MNSs, Lutheran, Kell, and Kidd systems of blood grouping.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. Her speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. She says, "walk dog", and nods her head when asked if she meant to say, "I want to take the dog for a walk". The comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what she wants to say. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere
Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Broca’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of vascular damage to Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus due to occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

A lesion in this region leads to motor/Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what he wants to say.

For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say, "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog for a walk". Speech therapy in Broca's aphasia is more successful than in Wernicke’s aphasia.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language due to damage to the brain. It occurs either secondary to brain injury or degeneration and involves the left cerebral hemisphere to a greater extent. Both written and spoken communication are affected. Audio-visual understanding is also deranged.

There is difficulty in finding words, leading to poorly understood content for the listener. These patients also find it difficult to repeat sentences and name things properly. Aphasia is diagnosed in patients with deficits in the formal aspects of language, such as word-finding, word choice, comprehension, spelling, or grammar.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-peri-sylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical, sometimes called the isolation of the speech area syndrome.

Wernicke’s aphasia occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken for a pond in a village. Which of the following synthetic insecticides are not recommended for such measures?
questions.solution:
DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) is not recommended for anti-larval measures. It is mainly used as a residual spray for the control of adult mosquitoes.

Compounds such as DDT and HCH (lindane) are organochlorine compounds. These are not recommended for larvicidal operations for the following reasons: 

  • Long residual effect 
  • Risk of water contamination
  • Risk of developing resistance in the vector mosquitoes

The most effective larvicides are malathion, fenthion, chlorpyrifos, and abate which can quickly hydrolyze in water. Malathion can be used as a low-volume spray to prevent mosquito-borne epidemics, vector-borne diseases during floods and dengue hemorrhagic fever.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was brought to you with complaints of mucosal and joint bleeds. Laboratory investigation revealed the complete absence of  Von Willebrand factor (VWF) protein. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Complete quantitative deficiency of vWF protein is seen in Type 3 Von Willebrand disease.

von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Patients with VWD typically present with mucosal bleeding. VWD may be caused by quantitative or qualitative defects in VWF

  • Type 1 VWD: Partial quantitative deficiency of vWF 
  • Type 2 VWD: Qualitative deficiency of vWF
  • Type 3 VWD: Complete quantitative deficiency of vWF

Note: 

  • Type 1 VWD is the most common type, accounting for 60-80% of all VWD patients.
  • Most severe type is Type 3
  • Most common inheritance: Autosomal dominant

Characteristics of the subtypes of VWD are summarized below:

Type Inheritance Mechanism Important characteristics
1 AD Partial, quantitative deficiency of VWF Most common type
3 AR Complete quantitative deficiency Most severe VWD
2A AD Loss of VWF multimers (increased cleavage by ADAMS13) Platelet adhesion defect
2B AD Increased binding of VWF to platelets causing VWF-platelet complex destruction Thrombocytopenia
2M AD Decreased affinity of VWF to platelets Platelet adhesion defect, very rare
2N AR Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Autosomal hemophilia

AD: autosomal dominant

AR: autosomal recessive

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence. Which of the following is likely to be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient presents with increased lacrimation, salivation, sweating, and urinary incontinence which are muscarinic symptoms, likely due to pesticide(organophosphorus compounds) poisoning. 

Organophosphorus compounds are constituents of pesticides. They block the acetylcholinesterase thereby causing persistent parasympathetic muscarinic and nicotinic receptors activation resulting in the symptoms. They can be absorbed through the skin, mucosa, or gastrointestinal tract.

Four clinical syndromes are identified with respect to organophosphate exposure. They include: 

  • Acute poisoning - This results in CNS, muscarinic, nicotinic, and somatic motor manifestations.
  • Intermediate syndrome -  Usually observed 1-5 days after organophosphate exposure. It is characterized by paralysis of neck flexors, muscles innervated by cranial nerves, proximal limb muscles, and respiratory muscles.
  • Chronic toxicity - It is seen primarily in agricultural workers with daily exposure. It manifests as symmetrical sensorimotor axonopathy.
  • Organophosphate-induced delayed neuropathy - Characterized by cognitive dysfunction, extrapyramidal symptoms, and peripheral neuropathy. It can lead to flaccid paralysis and muscle wasting

A diagnosis can be made by measuring the pseudocholinesterase levels in RBC, which if less than 50%, confirms the diagnosis. Treatment involves the administration of atropine.  

Postmortem appearances - Congestion and frothy hemorrhagic exudate is seen in respiratory passages. Stomach contents smell of kerosene.

Other options: 

Option A: Arsenic clinical features can be divided into fulminant type, gastrointestinal type, or narcotic form. The fulminant type is characterized by death due to shock and peripheral vascular failure. The gastrointestinal type is a common form and is similar to food poisoning, akin to cholera. The narcotic form is characterized by giddiness, muscle tenderness, coma, and death.

Option B: Strychnine(spinal poison) consumption is responsible for opisthotonus, emprosthotonus, and pleurosthotonus. These symptoms occur due to convulsions and muscle rigidity caused by action on the spinal reflex centres. Risus sardonicus, where the jaws and facial muscles are contracted and drawn back, may also occur. 

Option D: Aconite(cardiac poison), if swallowed, causes tingling and numbness of the mouth, tongue, and pharynx. Salivation, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea then follow, and subsequently, the patient would develop dry mouth, thirst, and dysphagia. Paresthesia, ataxia, slurred speech, and muscle twitching. Hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia with AV block occur.

questions.text: In an experiment, a researcher has introduced a knockout gene mutation in a cell line. Following which, he noticed that the survival of the cell-line rapidly reduced. On microscopic examination, the dead cells appeared shrunken, with intact cell membranes. Which of the following genes is most likely to be affected by this mutation?
questions.solution:
A knockout gene mutation removes the affected gene. Cell shrinkage and intact cell membrane indicates apoptosis. BCL-2 is an anti-apoptotic gene, which protects the cells from undergoing apoptosis. Therefore, the removal of the BCL2 gene causes increased apoptosis.
 
Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:
  • BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic proteins that are stimulated by growth factors and other survival signals.
  • BAX and BAK, are pro-apoptotic factors, which insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

A. Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

  • Cell injury results in the release of cytochrome C and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria.
  • These then activate caspase 9 which causes nuclear fragmentation and the formation of apoptotic bodies.

B. Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

  • In this pathway, activation of death receptors causes apoptosis by activating caspase-8.
  • Prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who is a known case of ulcerative colitis presents with exacerbation of symptoms. His stool frequency suddenly increased to 10-12 times in the past 24 hours, with blood in stools. Investigations revealed a CRP of 60 mg/L. Which of the following is used to define the severity of this disease?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presented with acute severe ulcerative colitis. Truelove-Witts criteria is used to define acute severe colitis.

Truelove-Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

  1. ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs
  2. Plus, one or more of the following features suggestive of systemic toxicity:
    • Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).
    • Mild fever (>100.04°F).
    • Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).
    • High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).

Other options :

Option B: The 2017 revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

Option C: The Montreal classification is used for classifying Crohn's disease.

Option D: The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF).

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has the following deformity of his left upper limb. The correct combination of the deformity seen and the late complication that you can expect in him are:
questions.solution:
This image shows a cubitus valgus deformity, which is usually a complication of lateral condyle humerus fractures. Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication associated with this.

Complications of lateral condyle humerus fractures:

  • Most common - Non-union
  • Malunion -> Lateral spur formation -> Tardy ulnar nerve palsy (Late complication)
  • Growth arrest
  • Avascular necrosis
  • Fishtail deformity

questions.text: A 28-year-old  male with a h/o atopy developed sudden onset breathlessness, and wheezing while performing a stand-up comedy at a bonfire night party. He is able to speak only a few words and was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is not a part of the mainstay of treatment in this case?

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added if response is not good to SABA

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of severe, acute attack of asthma. In an attack of acute severe asthma, sedatives should be never be given as they may depress ventilation. 

Management of acute attack of asthma:

  • A high concentration of oxygen should be given by face mask and oxygen saturation should be maintained at >90%.
  • The mainstay of treatment are high doses of SABA given either by nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer.
  • In severely ill patients with impending respiratory failure, IV β2-agonists may be given.
  • A nebulized anticholinergic may be added if there is not a good response to β2-agonists alone.
  • In patients who are refractory to inhaled therapies, a slow infusion of aminophylline can also be given.

Features of Acute severe attack of asthma include:

  • Inability to speak a complete sentence in one breath
  • Pulse >120/min
  • Respiratory rate >25/min
  • FEV1 between 33 to 50% of predicted
  • Pulsus paradoxus of >10 mmHg

Classification of severity of asthma exacerbations:

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with difficult delivery for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: This is done for the management of shoulder dystocia
Turtle sign is positive in this condition
Maternal diabetes mellitus is a risk factor
It is known as Zavanelli maneuver

questions.solution:
The image depicts rotation of the posterior shoulder to 180º in a corkscrew manner, this is Woods corkscrew maneuver for shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign (Option B) may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes(Option C), post-term pregnancy, and multiparity.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia.

The correct sequence of shoulder dystocia drill is as follows:

  • Call for help and mobilize labor assistants, anesthesia, and pediatric doctors.
  • 1st line of management - Mc Roberts maneuver (flexion and abduction of thigh) in conjunction with suprapubic pressure application.
  • 2nd line of management - Woods corkscrew maneuver (rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion). Other maneuvers like Rubin's, Gaskin's (all four's position), Hubbard, and Barnum's maneuvers can be attempted too.
  • 3rd line of management - Zavanelli maneuver (replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis) followed by cesarean delivery
  • The last line of management (Not preferred nowadays):
    • Cleidotomy(fracture of the clavicle of the baby) 
    • Symphysiotomy (divide pubic symphysis of mother)

questions.text: A 30-year-old mother who had prolonged labor delivered a full-term male baby by spontaneous vaginal delivery.  Following this, the patient went into a state of shock due to uterine inversion. Which of the following methods can be used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
O’Sullivan's method is used for replacing the uterus in case of uterine inversion.

Uterine inversion is most commonly caused due to mismanagement of 3rd stage of labor. The usual risk factors include an enlarged uterus, prolonged labor, large fetal size (macrosomia), uterine malformations, morbidly adherent placenta, a short umbilical cord, tocolysis (use of medications to stop preterm labor), and manual placenta removal. Women with collagen disorders like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are more susceptible to this condition.

The mother presents with shock immediately after delivery, the degree of the shock is out of proportion to the amount of bleeding. It is both neurogenic and hemorrhagic. During the abdominal examination, a cup or dimpled appearance is observed on the surface of the fundus. In cases of the complete variety, a pear-shaped mass protrudes from the vulva, with a broad end pointing downward and looking reddish purple in color.

The ideal treatment is an immediate replacement of the uterus. It should be immediately reposited by exerting firm and constant pressure on the inverted uterine fundus. If the placenta is attached to the uterus, it must not be removed until after the replacement has been effected. The best method of replacing the uterus has been described by O’Sullivan. 

O’Sullivan's method:  Here the patient is anesthetized and a gallon of warm sterile water is used for irrigation into the vagina, using an irrigating can raised 3 to 4 feet above the level of the patient. After gently pushing the inverted uterine fundus back into the vagina, the nozzle of the irrigating cannula is inserted into the vagina, and the vaginal orifice is closed by the hands of the operator and an assistant. Around 3-5L of fluid may be required, and the inversion will be slowly corrected by the hydrostatic pressure. If this method fails, manual repositioning may be attempted under deep anesthesia. 

Reposition of the uterus may be done by abdominal operation after trying manual and hydrostatic methods.

Schultze method Duncan's method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

 

Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus. The procedure is used only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

questions.text: Which of the following is more likely to produce transfusion-related infection despite storage at appropriate temperature?
questions.solution:
Platelets are more likely to promote contamination and growth of bacteria since they are stored at around 22°C which is optimum for bacterial growth. Unlike other blood products which are stored at 1-6° C or even lower.

The source of contamination is usually donor bacteremia or skin commensals from donors. It is hence advised to check the blood bag thoroughly for any leak, clots, turbidity, or hemolysis before transfusion.

Moreover, It is for this very reason, guidelines have been laid for transfusion to complete fast, to avoid the growth of bacteria in blood components once it is out of storage conditions.

 

Duration times for transfusion
Blood products  Start transfusion  Complete transfusion
Whole blood / PRBC Within 30 minutes of removing it from the refrigerator

≤ 4 hours 

Discard unit if this period is exceeded
Platelet concentrate  Immediately Within 30 minutes
Fresh frozen plasma As soon as possible Within 30 minutes
Cryoprecipitate As soon as possible Within 30 minutes

questions.text: A 40-year-old baker presented with crust formation in his nose, mostly confined to the anterior part of the nasal septum. When he tried to remove those crusts, it caused ulceration and epistaxis. A diagnosis of rhinitis sicca is made. The pathophysiology in this case is ___________________

choices.text: Squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland hypertrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Non-Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland hypertrophy
Squamous metaplasia of Non-Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of Rhinitis sicca, the pathophysiology is squamous metaplasia of Ciliated columnar epithelium along with seromucinous gland atrophy.

Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is confined to the anterior third of nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment or one with an antibiotic and steroid to the affected part.

questions.text: A 39-year-old morbidly-obese female patient presented with deranged liver function test. Ultrasound showed a grade 2 fatty liver with hepatic fibrosis and inflammation. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive, and has no history of smoking or drinking. A diagnosis of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has been made. Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is considered the first-line treatment for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). In many studies, vitamin E was well-tolerated, showed modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

Most of the patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work. Some patients with NASH can present with right upper quadrant pain due to stretching of the liver capsule from hepatomegaly, or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance or with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis. Currently, a biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia). Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Other options:

Option A- Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C- Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH as it has not been known to improve liver histology.

Option D- N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.solution:
The given cannula is a 26 gauge IV cannula as its color is Violet.

The flow rate in cannula of this gauge is 13mL/minute

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the drug delivery system shown in the image below?

choices.text: Ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug till patch is applied
Drug absorption versus time graph has more peaks compared to an oral drug
Ensures hundred percent bioavailability of the drug
Absorption is independent of the surface area over which it is applied

questions.solution:
The image shows a transdermal patch for transdermal drug delivery. It ensures continuous constant absorption of the drug.

Transdermal patches like these are available for 

  • Nicotine for smoking cessation
  • Oestradiol for HRT
  • GTN for angina
  • Fentanyl for analgesia

The site of the application of the transdermal patches may affect the systemic drug concentration as absorption through dermal circulation is a bit different over different areas of skin. For example, absorption from nicotine patches applied over the upper arm and back was higher compared to when it was applied to the abdomen.

The below diagram explains the parts of a transdermal patch.

Other options:

B. Drug absorption versus time graph has fewer peaks compared to an oral drug and hence fewer toxicities.

C. A hundred percent bioavailability is possible only with intravenous administration

D. The absorption of the drug is dependent on the surface area on which the transdermal patch is applied and the lipid solubility of the drug.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child brought by his mother has a history of passing hard stools and straining during defecation. On examination, the lower abdomen feels hard on palpation. All of the following can be used in this child, except _______.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests the features of constipation. All the drugs mentioned above can be used for the treatment of constipation except loperamide.

Loperamide is an anti-diarrheal agent. It acts on peripheral μ-opioid receptors and also has mild anticholinergic properties.

It is used in non-infective diarrhea or diarrhea associated with AIDS. It should not be used in acute infective diarrhea because it inhibits the clearance of toxins or infective organisms. 

It is contraindicated in children less than 2-4 years of age because of serious complications of toxic megacolon. It poorly penetrates the CNS and does not have abuse liability.

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusate (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulfate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analog - lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was diagnosed with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Electron microscopy of the lung tissue showed type 2 pneumocytes containing small surfactant lamellae with electron-dense cores. The given condition is associated with which of the following gene mutations?
questions.solution:
The presence of abnormal type 2 pneumocytes containing small surfactant lamellae with electron-dense cores, is characteristic of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis associated with ABCA3 mutations.

Surfactant dysfunction disorders:

They are diseases caused due to mutations in genes, which encode proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion. The commonly mutated genes include:

  • ATP-binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3): It is the most common genetic mutation in surfactant dysfunction disorders. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive mode. The disease usually presents in the first few months of life, rarely in older children. It is associated with rapidly progressive respiratory failure followed by death.
  • SFTPC gene: It is the second most commonly mutated, which normally encodes for surfactant protein C. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant mode.
  • SFTPB gene: It is the third most commonly mutated gene, which normally encodes for surfactant protein B.  It is inherited in an autosomal recessive mode. The infant is full-term and develops progressive respiratory distress shortly after birth. If early lung transplantation is not done, the infants may die between 3 and 6 months of age.

Morphology:

  • The alveoli are filled with pink granular material.
  • It is associated with type II pneumocyte hyperplasia, interstitial fibrosis, and alveolar simplification.
  • In the case of mutations involving SFTPB or SFTPC genes, immunohistochemical stains show the lack of surfactant proteins B and C, respectively.
  • Electron microscopy shows abnormalities in lamellar bodies in type II pneumocytes, in all three types.
  • Small lamellar bodies with electron-dense cores are diagnostic for ABCA3 mutation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presented with vesicoureteral reflux due to the following congenital anomaly. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The condition has a male preponderance
The lower border usually lies in front of T12 vertebra due to arrest of descent
It is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys
Wilms tumor is a common association

questions.solution:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lies in front of the L3 vertebra due to the arrest of ascent.

Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. It has a male preponderance of 2:1. The common associations of horseshoe kidneys are:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Wilms tumor
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney
  • Turner’s syndrome

questions.text: In a case-control study, lung compliance of two different groups (1 and 3) was compared against that of the control group (2) and recorded as shown in the graph below. Which of the following cases likely represents groups 1 and 3, respectively?
questions.solution:
Graphs 1 and 3 correspond to decreased and increased compliance, respectively. Among the given options, pulmonary fibrosis is associated with decreased compliance, and pulmonary emphysema is associated with increased compliance.

The extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure is called lung compliance. The total compliance of both lungs together in normal, adult averages about 200 mL of air/cm H2O transpulmonary pressure.

  • The curve is shifted downwards in case of decreased compliance. 
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance.

Here the compliance is 3 > 2> 1.

Compliance is increased in normal ageing lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched). 

Compliance is decreased in pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary edema, and unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive airway disease in which there is scarring and stiffening of the lungs. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A female patient with mitral valve prolapse was admitted to the labor room at 38 weeks of gestation. She insists on a normal delivery of the baby. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Vaginal delivery is preferred to Cesarean section
Delay second stage of labor  to prevent cardiac stress
Facilitate delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction
The left decubitus position is preferred to lithotomy

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the management of this patient is option B. In a cardiac patient, such as a patient with mitral valve prolapse, it is better to cut short the second stage by facilitating the delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction

For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred. A cesarean section is reserved for obstetric indications. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will be conducted with the laboring woman in the left decubitus position. This minimizes aortocaval compression.

Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiac compromise. Suppose the cardiac disease is moderate to severe, it is better to avoid the active second stage by using regional anesthesia. It allows the fetal head to descend to the perineum without active pushing and then facilitate delivery by forceps or vacuum extraction.

Management of labor in patients with heart disease:

First stage:

  • Lateral recumbent or propped up position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural
  • Fluids infused should not be more than 75 ml/hr
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labor and 48 hours after delivery
  • Pulse oximetry and cardiac monitoring

Second stage:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse extraction.

The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.

Third stage:

  • Oxytocin by infusion
  • IV frusemide if needed

Oxytocin is preferred over ergometrine in all heart disease patients in the third stage of labor.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for 3 months but the disease is still progressing. What would you recommend for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in the management of rheumatoid arthritis when the patient is not responding to initial treatment.

Joints commonly affected in rheumatoid arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involvement) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints

DMARDS, glucocorticoids, and biologicals are used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA):

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs): They are the mainstay of treatment. Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, 1-2 week bursts of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules. They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

  • Anti-TNF alpha agents: Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, and certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.
  • Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist
  • Tocilizumab: IL-6 antagonist
  • Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells
  • Rituximab: Anti CD-20
  • Tofacitinib: JAK 3 inhibitor

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

Related Pearl: The 'most commons' of rheumatoid arthritis

Feature of RA Most common  
Involved joints MCP, Wrist, PIP(DIP spared) 
Spine involvement Cervical spine
Extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules (mostly extensor surface)
Cardiac manifestation Pericarditis
Valvular abnormality Mitral regurgitation
Pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
Hematological manifestation Normochromic normocytic anemia
Neurological manifestation Compression neuropathies (mostly carpal tunnel syndrome)
Ocular manifestation  Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Lymphoma Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Cause of death Cardiovascular disease (coronary artery disease)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a chronic smoker presented to the hospital with intermittent claudication and pain in both the calves on walking for about 500m. Which of the following is most commonly involved in this condition?

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the popliteal artery
Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with superficial femoral artery involvement which presents as intermittent claudication and pain in the calf region.

Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery. Classically muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease. The most common artery involved is the superficial femoral artery which presents as intermittent claudication pain in the calf region.

Aortoiliac disease may cause thigh or buttock claudication.

questions.text: Urinary alkalinization will promote excretion of all of the following drugs except?
questions.solution:
Propanolol is a weakly basic drug, its excretion will not be increased with alkalinization of urine.

When the urine is alkaline, weakly acidic drugs like Phenytoin, barbiturates, valproic acid, Warfarin are present in highly ionised form and excreted more rapidly.

 

Acidic urine

Alkaline urine

Weak acid 

  • Barbiturates
  • Salicylates
  • Phenytoin
  • Valproate

Reabsorbed

Excreted

Weak base

  • Propanolol
  • Chlorpromazine
  • Diazepam
  • Quinidine

Excreted

Reabsorbed

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complained of acute onset vertigo. The physician prescribed Cinnarizine. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the given drug?

choices.text: Antihistaiminic action by blocking H2 receptor

questions.solution:
Cinnarizine acts by blocking H1 receptor, not H2 receptor.

It is known to exert its action by more than one mechanism, including:

  • inhibits smooth muscle cell contraction in the vasculature by blocking L-and T-type voltage-gated calcium channels
  • labyrinthine suppressant action
  • peripheral anti-vasoconstrictive effects

 

H1 antagonists are classified into 2 generations: 

First-generation antihistamine- They have a strong sedative property and also have an antimuscarinic function. They include:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine
  • Pheniramine, 
  • Chlorpheniramine, Dexchlorpheniramine
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Cyclizine, Meclizine, Buclizine
  • Cinnarizine
  • Clemastine

Second-generation antihistamine- They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine, Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine
  • Azelastine, Mizolastine, Ebastine
  • Olopatadine
  • Rupatadine

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with right-sided large acoustic neuroma. On examination, there is hypoesthesia along the posterior meatal wall of the right ear. This is likely to be due to the involvement of _______.
questions.solution:
Hypoesthesia of the posterosuperior meatal wall is known as Hitzelberger's sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma as sensory fibers of the facial nerve (VII nerve) will be affected. The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers of CN VII (through the auricular branch of the vagus) which is the reason for the manifestation.

Cranial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma:

Cranial nerve involved Clinical features
Vth nerve Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of face
VIIth nerve Hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall (Hitzelberger’s sign), loss of taste, delayed blink reflex, and reduced lacrimation
IXth and Xth nerves Dysphagia and hoarseness

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof - the auriculotemporal branch of the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII).

questions.text: A histological slide is shown to medical students. The type of cartilage depicted in the given slide stained with Trichrome-Masson stain is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a section of fibrocartilage stained with Trichrome - Masson stain. It is seen in the acetabular labrum.

Fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • Menisci of the knee
  • Glenoid and acetabular labra
  • Lining of the bony grooves for tendons
  • Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing abundant collagen fibres

 Other options:

Option A: Arytenoid cartilages, except its apices, are mainly composed of hyaline cartilage.

Option C and D: Auricle (pinna) and apices of the arytenoid cartilages are composed of elastic cartilage.

 

Note: The colour of cartilage should not be considered while deciding its type, as it largely depends on the type of stain used. Instead, the structure or organisation of the cartilage tissue should be considered.

3 types of cartilages: Hyaline cartilage, elastic cartilage, and fibrocartilage. 

  • Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have perichondrium
  • Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium. 

The following are the images of Hyaline cartilage and Elastic cartilage respectively.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presented with complaints of shortness of breath and dry cough, for over a year. On examination, the patient's face was puffy and red. He sat in a hunched-over position and was breathing through pursed lips. Physical examination shows a barrel chest, hyper resonance on percussion. Prolonged breathing and wheezing were noted.  Exposure to which of the following proteins is most likely associated with the pathogenesis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The classic clinical features given in the question, are suggestive of emphysema. The pathogenesis involves the destruction of the alveolar walls due to exposure to elastase, due to deficiency of α1 Antitrypsin. This is referred to as protease-antiprotease imbalance.

Emphysema is defined by irreversible enlargement of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole, accompanied by destruction of their walls.

 

Pathogenesis of emphysema:

Proteases are secreted by the neutrophils during inflammation. α1-Antitrypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages, is a major inhibitor of proteases (especially, elastase). Deficiency of α1-Antitrypsin leads to exposure of the alveolar walls to elastase during inflammatory conditions, which causes destruction of the alveolar walls due to digestion of elastic tissue, leading to emphysema. The protease-antiprotease imbalance markedly enhances the tendency to develop emphysema that is compounded by smoking

Destruction of the alveolar walls may also be caused due to increased oxidative stress, and the release of inflammatory mediators (such as leukotriene B4, interleukin-8, TNF) in chronic smokers.

Loss of elastic tissue in the walls of the alveoli surrounding the respiratory bronchioles reduces radial traction, leading to the collapse of respiratory bronchioles during expiration.

 

Clinical features:

  • Patients with emphysema, are often described as pink puffers, due to their appearance (thin, rapid breathing, and pink coloured). The pink coloured skin is due to adequate oxygenation, despite the disease condition, due to compensation caused by increased respiratory rate.
  • Classically, the patient is barrel-chested and dyspneic, with prolonged expiration.
  • The patient sits forward in a hunched-over position and breathes through pursed lips.
  • There may be a significant weight loss, as seen in cancer patients.
  • Patients have a mild cough, with severe overdistention of the lungs, and low diffusion capacity. The blood gas values are relatively normal at rest.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: During the skeletal age assessment of a 9-year-old, which of the following ossification centers would you not expect to see?
questions.solution:
The ossification center of Pisiform appears at 10-12 years of age. 

It is the last to appear among the carpal bones. Other carpal bones ossification centers appear at less than 12 years

  • Capitate - 2month IUL
  • Hamate - 3 month IUL
  • Triquetral - 2-3 years
  • Lunate - 3-4 years
  • Schaphoid,trapezoid - 5-6 years
  • Trapezium - 6 years
  • Pisiform -10-12 years 

Radiographs of the hand and wrist should be taken to ascertain whether the child is more or less than 12 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following molecular motors is mainly responsible for the ciliary movement?
questions.solution:
The interaction of the axonemal dynein with the microtubules is responsible for the ciliary movement.

Molecular motors are ATPases that move proteins, organelles, and other cellular components collectively referred to as 'cargo' to various parts of the cell. They convert the energy of ATP into movement along the cytoskeleton, taking their cargo with them. There are three superfamilies of molecular motors, which include dynein, kinesin and myosin.

Dyneins:

  • They have two heads, with their neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
  • Cytoplasmic dyneins are similar to conventional kinesin, except they move particles and membranes to the minus (–) end of the microtubules.
  • Axonemal dyneins are present with the axonemes of the cilia. An axoneme consists of a unique arrangement of nine outer microtubule doublets and two inner microtubules ("9+2" arrangement). The coordinated dynein–microtubule interactions within the axoneme are responsible for the ciliary and sperm movement.

Kinesin:

  • The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule that moves its cargo toward the plus (“+”) ends of microtubules.
  • Some kinesins are associated with mitosis and meiosis.
  • Other kinesins perform different functions, and may also move cargo to the minus (“–”) end of microtubules.

Myosins:

  • There are about 18 classes of myosins.
  • The heads of some myosin molecules (myosin II) bind to actin and produce motion by bending their neck regions.
  • Some myosin molecules (myosin V) may move the cargo, by walking along microfilaments, one head after the other.

Other options:

Option C: Dynamin is a GTPase responsible for clathrin-mediated endocytosis.

questions.text: A patient was administered rocuronium as a muscle relaxant during surgery. However, the surgeon was able to finish the procedure sooner than expected. What specific reversal agent will you use?
questions.solution:
The specific reversal agent that can terminate the action of rocuronium is sugammadex.

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Rocuronium at higher doses can be used in rapid sequence intubation. However, the only downside is its long duration of action. This obstacle can be overcome by sugammadex, which will reverse its effects.

Other options-

Option (A): Neostigmine reversal requires a baseline twitch response. Sugammadex, on the other hand, can be administered at any depth muscle blockade, thereby making it more useful.

Option (C) and Option (D): Atropine and glycopyrrolate are administered along with anticholinesterases pre-operatively to reduce muscarinic side effects like bradycardia. They are not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:
    • Hepatic clearance: Pancuronium, rapacuronium and vecuronium
    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

questions.text: A child was brought to you with the complaints of purple papulonodular lesions as shown in the below image. You suspect blueberry muffin rash in this child. Which of the following conditions represent this cutaneous manifestation?
questions.solution:
The rash seen in the given image is the characteristic blueberry muffin rash, which represents dermal erythropoiesis.

Blueberry muffin rash refers to purple papulonodular lesions. Histologically, The reticular dermis shows aggregates of nucleated and nonnucleated erythrocyte precursors. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Viral infections such as rubella, cytomegalovirus, and parvovirus
  • Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and acute myeloid leukemia
  • Rh hemolytic disease.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic man wanted to overcome his alcohol addiction and abstained from alcohol for 3 days. On the third day, he developed tremors and hallucinations. He was brought to the emergency and was found to be disoriented. His heart rate and blood pressure were increased. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features is delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. The patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. Visual or tactile hallucinations along with features of autonomic hyperactivity like tremors, tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, insomnia, and increased blood pressure are also seen. 

It usually occurs within 72 hours of abstinence, however, may occur within a week of alcohol withdrawal. Acute infection, hepatitis, and pancreatitis predispose delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is treated with benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Alcohol withdrawal-related hallucinations- These are usually auditory hallucinations occurring during alcohol withdrawal. In this condition, the patient has a clear sensorium, which differentiates it from delirium tremens.

Option B: Korsakoff's psychosis is an amnestic syndrome that occurs due to thiamine deficiency. The clinical features include impairment of memory, confabulations, and disordered temporal sequencing. Thiamine supplementation and nutritional support are given to these patients. However, the patients show only a little improvement because of irreversible damage to the medial thalamic nuclei and mammillary bodies caused by thiamine deficiency.

Option D: Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a syndrome characterized by dementia and seizures, associated with degeneration of the corpus callosum. It has been observed in male Italian red wine drinkers.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

Related Pearl: Delirium vs Dementia

Features

Delirium

Dementia
Presentation

Hallmark is impaired consciousness

Loss of memory and intellectual abilities

Commonly seen in 

Children and elderly 

Elderly 

Associated physical findings
  • Acute medical illness 
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Abnormal EEG 
  • Carphologia or floccillation (picking movements at cover-sheets and clothes) 
  • No medical illness
  • Little autonomic dysfunction
  • Normal EEG 

Psychological findings
  • Impaired consciousness
  • Illusion, delusion 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 
  • Normal consciousness
  • Depressed mood 
  • Personality changes in early stages in Pick’s disease 
  • Sundowning (symptoms much worse at night) 

Course
  • Develops quickly
  • Fluctuating course with lucid intervals (waxing and waning) 
  • Insidious-onset
  • Progressive downhill course
 

Etiology
  • CNS disease (E.g: Huntington or Parkinson disease)
  • CNS trauma
  • CNS infection (E.g: Meningitis)
  • Systemic disease (E.g., hepatic, cardiovascular)
  • Substance abuse/withdrawal
  • HIV infection
  • Prescription drug overdose (E.g: atropine) 
  • Alzheimer's disease
  • Vascular disease (15-30% of all dementias)
  • CNS disease (E.g., Huntingtons or Parkinsons disease)
  • CNS infection (HIV, Prion diseases)
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Pick's disease (Frontotemporal dementia) 
 

Treatment:

 

Treat the underlying medical cause

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine) and NMDA antagonist (memantine)

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features

Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.

Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.

Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.

Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.

Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: Which glucose transporter is present in erythrocytes?
questions.solution:
GLUT 1 is the glucose transporter present in erythrocytes. 

It mediates basal glucose uptake. GLUT 1 is also the major glucose transporter in the brain and placenta and is widely distributed. 

Related Pearl: Glucose transporters and their locations

GLUT 4
Heart, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue Insulin-dependent glucose uptake
GLUT 5
Small intestine, testis, sperm Fructose transporter
GLUT 8
Blastocyst, testis, brain Insulin-dependent glucose uptake in blastocyst. Transports glucose to Mature spermatozoa.
GLUT 9
