questions.text: A 30-year-old salesman is brought to the ER with the following findings after he fell whilst trying to get up from the bed. There is a history of ATT intake 2 years back and low mood and lethargy for the past 2 months. Vitals were as follows: PR: 100 bpm; BP: 110/70 mmHg in the supine position and 90/60 mmHg on standing. RBS is 120 mg/dL. ABG results: Na - 120 mEq/L, K - 6 mEq/L. How would you manage this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute adrenal crisis in Addison's disease. It is treated with an IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus, followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone.

The features favoring the diagnosis are low mood and lethargy, hyperpigmentation on gums, dorsum of hands and other exposed areas, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.

Most common causes of Addison’s disease:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries 
  • Autoimmune (idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries

An acute adrenal crisis occurs after a prolonged period of nonspecific complaints and is more frequently observed in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. The clinical features occur due to the loss of both glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid secretion. It may be precipitated by any illness, stress, infection, or hyperthyroidism contributing to increased utilization of glucocorticoids.

It can be confirmed by the ACTH stimulation test.

It is treated with an IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus. Followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone. Mineralocorticoid replacement and adrenal androgen replacement are required in definite management.

Other options:


Option B:  IV propylthiouracil and propranolol are used in the management of thyrotoxicosis/ thyroid storm. The scenario will not have low BP or postural hypotension as in this case. It will have symptoms of increased metabolism, increased appetite, increased pulse, and high BP.

Option C: IV antibiotics and chlorpromazine are used in the treatment of acute labyrinthitis in which the patients might present with a history of falls and will complain of vertigo. It will not have features of hyponatremia or hypotension.

Option D: IV steroids and anti-tubercular drugs are used in the treatment of particular forms of tuberculosis such as extrapulmonary, and pediatric TB. It is often used in cases with features of meningitis, hydrocephalus, or pericarditis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: An elderly man living in a drought area has been consuming a lifetime daily intake of 3.0-6.0mg/L of fluoride in the drinking water brought through bore wells. The type fluorosis associated with this case is ______
questions.solution:
Skeletal fluorosis is seen with a lifetime daily fluoride intake of 3.0-6.0mg/L or more.

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10mg/L

Genu valgum is seen in people consuming jowar(sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Note: Nalgonda technique is used for defluoridation which involves addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation and filtration.

questions.text: Penicillin is most likely to kill the bacteria in which phase of the bacterial growth curve shown below?
questions.solution:
The log (logarithmic) phase, also known as the exponential phase is when rapid cell division occurs. β -Lactam drugs, such as penicillin, act during this phase because the drugs are effective when cells are making peptidoglycan (i.e., when they are dividing).

The first is the lag phase, during which vigorous metabolic activity occurs but cells do not divide. This can last for a few minutes up to many hours.
The stationary phase occurs when nutrient depletion or toxic products cause growth to slow until the number of new cells produced balances the number of cells that die, resulting in a steady-state.
The final phase is the death phase, which is marked by a decline in the number of viable bacteria.

questions.text: A high school graduate went to the army recruitment drive but was not selected because of his flat foot. This condition is caused due to the involvement of which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
A flat foot is caused due to the involvement of the spring ligament.

Pes planus or flat foot is caused to due the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and can be either congenital or acquired. Its causes include rupture of spring ligament, tarsal coalition, disruption of tibialis posterior tendon, tarsometatarsal arthritis, and hindfoot degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

It supports the head of the talus which if fails or is destroyed, leads to separation of the navicular and calcaneus, in turn allowing the talar head, the highest point of the arch, to descend and leading to a flat-foot deformity.

Other options:

The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilizes the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are most common when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture. Both the deltoid and spring ligaments are present on the medial side and their injuries are common in eversion sprains.

The anterior talofibular ligament is the “ankle sprain ligament” because it is the one that is most often damaged when the ankle is rolled.

The posterior talofibular ligament functions to stabilize the ankle joint and subtalar joint. Injuries are rare to this ligament unless there is an ankle dislocation or subluxation. The talofibular ligaments are present on the lateral side and their injuries are common in inversion sprains.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Features

Medial Longitudinal arch

Lateral longitudinal arch

Anterior pillar

Talus, navicular, 3 cuneiform and 1st, 2nd and 3rd metatarsal

Cuboid and 4th, 5th metatarsals

Posterior pillar

Medial half of calcaneum

Lateral half of calcaneum

Main joint involved

Talo calcaneonavicular joint (TCN)

Calcaneocuboid joint

Summit

Superior articular surface of Talus

Superior articular surface of Calcaneum (at the leveled Subtalar joint)

Extremities (piers)

Tuberosity of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 1st, 2nd, 3rd metatarsal anteriorly

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly

Ligament/intersegmental ties

Plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament)

Long and short plantar ligaments

Tie beams

Plantar aponeurosis (medial part)

Abductor hallucis

Medial part of  flexor digitorum brevis

Plantar aponeurosis (lateral part)

Abductor digiti minimi

Slings

Tibialis anterior 

Tibialis posterior

Flexor hallucis longus

Flexor digitorum longus

 

Peroneus longus

Peroneus brevis

questions.text: The following is the cross-section of chorionic villi. What type of villi is it?
questions.solution:
The given image is the cross-section of secondary chorionic villi, as it contains the mesodermal core surrounded by cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts.

The following image shows different types of villi.

questions.text: Which of the following anticonvulsants most commonly produces the following side effect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gum hypertrophy which is commonly seen with phenytoin.

This can be prevented by maintaining good oral hygiene.

Other side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly)

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

questions.text: The most important step for disease prevention and control in the post-disaster phase is:
questions.solution:
The most important step for disease prevention & control in the post-disaster phase is the chlorination of all water bodies.

After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of feces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/liter.

Minimum recommended free residual chlorine levels:

Cholera epidemic: 0.5 mg/L

Disaster/ Natural calamities: 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L

In normal conditions, water should have free residual chlorine (FRC) of 0.2 - 0.5 mg/L. However, during a disaster, there is an increased risk of fecal contamination of water sources from sewage systems. Therefore, it is necessary to increase FRC to 0.7 - 0.9 mg/L.

The WHO does not recommend typhoid, cholera or tetanus vaccines for the general population after a disaster. However, healthcare workers are recommended to take these vaccines.

Supply of safe drinking water and proper disposal of excreta are the most practical and effective strategies of preventing diseases, post-disaster.
